By the sound of it — everywhere. Dervish and Banges, the wizarding equipment shop, Zonko’s Joke Shop, into the Three Broomsticks for foaming mugs of hot butterbeer, and many places besides. The post office, Harry! About two hundred owls, all sitting on shelves, all color-coded depending on how fast you want your letter to get there! Honeydukes has got a new kind of fudge; they were giving out free samples, there’s a bit, look — We think we saw an ogre, honestly, they get all sorts at the Three Broomsticks — Wish we could have brought you some butterbeer, really warms you up —
What did you do? Did you get any work done?
No, Lupin made me a cup of tea in his office. And then Snape came in. . . .
Lupin drank it? Is he mad?
We’d better go down, you know, the feast’ll be starting in five minutes. . . .

Scene: “There’s no point hiding it from you any longer, Potter,” she said in a very serious voice. “I know this will come as a shock to you, but Sirius Black —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I know he’s after me, I heard Ron’s dad telling his mum. Mr. Weasley works for the Ministry of Magic.
We’ve got our first match on Saturday! I’ve got to train, Professor!

Scene: “We’re not playing Slytherin!” he told them, looking very angry. “Flint’s just been to see me. We’re playing Hufflepuff instead.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: There’s nothing wrong with Malfoy’s arm! He’s faking it!

Scene: “Sorry I’m late, Professor Lupin, I —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Sorry I’m late, Professor Lupin, I —
Where’s Professor Lupin?
What’s wrong with him?
Please, sir,
But, sir, we’re not supposed to do werewolves yet, we’re due to start hinkypunks —
Please, sir, the werewolf differs from the true wolf in several small ways. The snout of the werewolf —
You asked us a question and she knows the answer! Why ask if you don’t want to be told?

Scene: “Very poorly explained . . . That is incorrect, the kappa is more commonly found in Mongolia. . . . Professor Lupin gave this eight out of ten? I wouldn’t have given it three. . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Snape’s never been like this with any of our other Defense Against the Dark Arts teachers, even if he did want the job, Why’s he got it in for Lupin? D’you think this is all because of the boggart?
I don’t know, But I really hope Professor Lupin gets better soon. . . . Ron!
Why couldn’t Black have hidden in Snape’s office, eh? He could have finished him off for us!

Scene: “Stand and fight, you mangy cur!” yelled Sir Cadogan.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oh, shut up,

Scene: The Hufflepuffs were approaching from the opposite side of the field, wearing canary-yellow robes. The Captains walked up to each other and shook hands; Diggory smiled at Wood but Wood now looked as though he had lockjaw and merely nodded. Harry saw Madam Hooch’s mouth form the words, “Mount your brooms.” He pulled his right foot out of the mud with a squelch and swung it over his Nimbus Two Thousand. Madam Hooch put her whistle to her lips and gave it a blast that sounded shrill and distant — they were off.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What’s the score?
I’ve got no chance with these on,
I’ve had an idea, Harry! Give me your glasses, quick! Impervius! There! They’ll repel water!
Brilliant!
Okay, team, let’s go for it!
Stand aside, you silly girl . . . stand aside, now. . . .
That was the scariest thing I’ve ever seen in my life.

Scene: “Not Harry! Please . . . have mercy . . . have mercy. . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What happened?
What happened? What happened? Are we doing a replay?
Where is Wood?

Dumbledore was really angry, I’ve never seen him like that before. He ran onto the field as you fell, waved his wand, and you sort of slowed down before you hit the ground. Then he whirled his wand at the dementors. Shot silver stuff at them. They left the stadium right away. . . . He was furious they’d come onto the grounds. We heard him —
Then he magicked you onto a stretcher, And walked up to school with you floating on it. Everyone thought you were . . .
Did someone get my Nimbus?
Er —
What?
Hmm . . .
And?
And it hit — it hit — oh, Harry — it hit the Whomping Willow.
And?
Hmm . . . It — it doesn’t like being hit.
Professor Flitwick brought it back just before you came around,

Scene: “If Snape’s teaching Defense Against the Dark Arts again, I’m skiving off,” said Ron as they headed toward Lupin’s classroom after lunch. “Check who’s in there, Hermione.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: If Snape’s teaching Defense Against the Dark Arts again, I’m skiving off, Check who’s in there, Hermione.
It’s okay!
Oh no, I’ve already finished it!
No, The tree smashed it to bits.
Did you hear about the dementors too?
Yes, Why? Why do they affect me like that? Am I just — ?
Why did they have to come to the match?
Azkaban must be terrible,
But Sirius Black escaped from them, He got away. . . .
But if the dementors come to another Quidditch match, I need to be able to fight them —
We can do all our Christmas shopping there! Mum and Dad would really love those Toothflossing Stringmints from Honeydukes!

Scene: “Psst — Harry!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What are you doing? How come you’re not going to Hogsmeade?
What’s that supposed to be?
And what do I need with a bit of old parchment?
Don’t tell me —
And you know how to work it? “You’re winding me up,”

Scene: What did he have to do? He pulled out the map again and saw, to his astonishment, that a new ink figure had appeared upon it, labeled Harry Potter. This figure was standing exactly where the real Harry was standing, about halfway down the third-floor corridor. Harry watched carefully. His little ink self appeared to be tapping the witch with his minute wand. Harry quickly took out his real wand and tapped the statue. Nothing happened. He looked back at the map. The tiniest speech bubble had appeared next to his figure. The word inside said, “Dissendium.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Dissendium! Lumos! Mischief managed!

Scene: There were shelves upon shelves of the most succulent-looking sweets imaginable. Creamy chunks of nougat, shimmering pink squares of coconut ice, fat, honey-colored toffees; hundreds of different kinds of chocolate in neat rows; there was a large barrel of Every Flavor Beans, and another of Fizzing Whizbees, the levitating sherbet balls that Ron had mentioned; along yet another wall were “Special Effects” sweets: Drooble’s Best Blowing Gum (which filled a room with bluebell-colored bubbles that refused to pop for days), the strange, splintery Toothflossing Stringmints, tiny black Pepper Imps (“Breathe fire for your friends!”), Ice Mice (“Hear your teeth chatter and squeak!”), peppermint creams shaped like toads (“Hop realistically in the stomach!”), fragile sugar-spun quills, and exploding bonbons.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Ugh, no, Harry won’t want one of those, they’re for vampires, I expect,
How about these?
Definitely not,
Harry! What are you doing here?
Wow! you’ve learned to Apparate!
’Course I haven’t,
How come Fred and George never gave it to me! I’m their brother!
But Harry isn’t going to keep it! He’s going to hand it in to Professor McGonagall, aren’t you, Harry?
No, I’m not!
Are you mad? Hand in something that good?
If I hand it in, I’ll have to say where I got it! Filch would know Fred and George had nicked it!
But what about Sirius Black? He could be using one of the passages on that map to get into the castle! The teachers have got to know!

He can’t be getting in through a passage, There are seven secret tunnels on the map, right? Fred and George reckon Filch already knows about four of them. And of the other three — one of them’s caved in, so no one can get through it. One of them’s got the Whomping Willow planted over the entrance, so you can’t get out of it. And the one I just came through — well — it’s really hard to see the entrance to it down in the cellar, so unless he knew it was there . . .

See? I’d like to see Black try and break into Honeydukes with dementors swarming all over the village. Anyway, Hermione, the Honeydukes owners would hear a break-in, wouldn’t they? They live over the shop!

Yes, Look, Harry still shouldn’t be coming into Hogsmeade. He hasn’t got a signed form! If anyone finds out, he’ll be in so much trouble! And it’s not nightfall yet — what if Sirius Black turns up today? Now?
He’d have a job spotting Harry in this, Come on, Hermione, it’s Christmas. Harry deserves a break.
Are you going to report me?

Oh — of course not — but honestly, Harry — Seen the Fizzing Whizbees, Harry? And the Jelly Slugs? And the Acid Pops? Fred gave me one of those when I was seven — it burnt a hole right through my tongue. I remember Mum walloping him with her broomstick. Reckon Fred’d take a bit of Cockroach Cluster if I told him they were peanuts?

Scene: “Where is everyone?” said Harry.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Where is everyone?
Gone! It’s the first day of the holidays, remember? It’s nearly lunchtime; I was going to come and wake you up in a minute.
You really don’t look well, you know,
I’m fine,
Harry, listen, you must be really upset about what we heard yesterday. But the thing is, you mustn’t go doing anything stupid.
Like what?
Like trying to go after Black,
Harry?

I can hear my mum screaming and pleading with Voldemort. And if you’d heard your mum screaming like that, just about to be killed, you wouldn’t forget it in a hurry. And if you found out someone who was supposed to be a friend of hers betrayed her and sent Voldemort after her —

There’s nothing you can do! The dementors will catch Black and he’ll go back to Azkaban and — and serve him right! You heard what Fudge said. Black isn’t affected by Azkaban like normal people are. It’s not a punishment for him like it is for the others.
So what are you saying?
You want to — to kill Black or something? Harry? Harry doesn’t want to kill anyone, do you, Harry?
Say You-Know-Who, will you?
— so obviously, the Malfoys knew Black was working for Voldemort —

— and Malfoy’d love to see you blown into about a million pieces, like Pettigrew! Get a grip. Malfoy’s just hoping you’ll get yourself killed before he has to play you at Quidditch. Harry, please, please be sensible. Black did a terrible, terrible thing, but d-don’t put yourself in danger, it’s what Black wants. . . . Oh, Harry, you’d be playing right into Black’s hands if you went looking for him. Your mum and dad wouldn’t want you to get hurt, would they?   They’d never want you to go looking for Black!
I’ll never know what they’d have wanted, because thanks to Black, I’ve never spoken to them,
Look, it’s the holidays! It’s nearly Christmas! Let’s — let’s go down and see Hagrid. We haven’t visited him for ages!
No! Harry isn’t supposed to leave the castle, Ron —
Yeah, let’s go, and I can ask him how come he never mentioned Black when he told me all about my parents!
Or we could have a game of chess, or Gobstones. Percy left a set —
No!

Scene: So they got their cloaks from their dormitories and set off through the portrait hole (“Stand and fight, you yellow-bellied mongrels!”), down through the empty castle and out through the oak front doors.

Dialogue.Dialogue: He’s not out, is he?
There’s a weird noise, Listen — is that Fang? Think we’d better go and get someone?
Hagrid! Hagrid, are you in there?

Scene: Ron and Hermione watched Harry nervously all through dinner, not daring to talk about what they’d overheard, because Percy was sitting close by them. When they went upstairs to the crowded common room, it was to find Fred and George had set off half a dozen Dungbombs in a fit of end-of-term high spirits. Harry, who didn’t want Fred and George asking him whether he’d reached Hogsmeade or not, sneaked quietly up to the empty dormitory and headed straight for his bedside cabinet. He pushed his books aside and quickly found what he was looking for — the leather-bound photo album Hagrid had given him two years ago, which was full of wizard pictures of his mother and father. He sat down on his bed, drew the hangings around him, and started turning the pages, searching, until . . .

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hagrid, what is it?
What’s this, Hagrid?
Hagrid!
You’ll have to put up a good strong defense, Hagrid, I’m sure you can prove Buckbeak is safe.
What about Dumbledore, Hagrid?
Listen, Hagrid, you can’t give up. Hermione’s right, you just need a good defense. You can call us as witnesses —
I’m sure I’ve read about a case of hippogriff-baiting, where the hippogriff got off. I’ll look it up for you, Hagrid, and see exactly what happened.
Er — shall I make a cup of tea? It’s what my mum does whenever someone’s upset,
We do like them!
Yeah, they’re great! Er — how are the flobberworms?
Oh no!
Is it awful in there, Hagrid?
But you were innocent!

Scene: “Here’s something . . . there was a case in 1722 . . . but the hippogriff was convicted — ugh, look what they did to it, that’s disgusting —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Here’s something . . . there was a case in 1722 . . . but the hippogriff was convicted — ugh, look what they did to it, that’s disgusting —
Look, No!

Scene: “Oi! Presents!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oi! Presents! Another sweater from Mum . . . maroon again . . . see if you’ve got one. What’s that?
Dunno . . .
I don’t believe it, Who sent it to you?
Look and see if there’s a card,
Nothing! Blimey, who’d spend that much on you?
Well, I’m betting it wasn’t the Dursleys.
I bet it was Dumbledore, He sent you the Invisibility Cloak anonymously. . . .
That was my dad’s, though, Dumbledore was just passing it on to me. He wouldn’t spend hundreds of Galleons on me. He can’t go giving students stuff like this —

That’s why he wouldn’t say it was from him! In case some git like Malfoy said it was favoritism. Hey, Harry Malfoy! Wait till he sees you on this! He’ll be sick as a pig! This is an international standard broom, this is!
Which?
I know, I know who it could’ve been — Lupin!
What? Lupin?
Yeah, but he likes you, And he was away when your Nimbus got smashed, and he might’ve heard about it and decided to visit Diagon Alley and get this for you —
What d’you mean, he was away? He was ill when I was playing in that match.
Well, I was there, cleaning out the bedpans on that detention from Snape, remember?
I can’t see Lupin affording something like this.
What?
Don’t bring him in here!
Who sent it to you? Who sent you that?
No idea, There wasn’t a card or anything with it.
What’s the matter with you?
No idea, but it’s a bit odd, isn’t it? I mean, this is supposed to be quite a good broom, isn’t it?
It’s the best broom there is, Hermione,
So it must’ve been really expensive. . . .
Probably cost more than all the Slytherins’ brooms put together,
Well,
Who cares? Listen, Harry, can I have a go on it? Can I?
I don’t think anyone should ride that broom just yet!
What? GET — HIM — OUT — OF — HERE!
I forgot about that! I never wear those socks if I can help it. . . .
You’d better take that cat out of here, Hermione, Can’t you shut that thing up?
He’s not looking too good, is he?
It’s stress! He’d be fine if that big stupid furball left him alone!

Scene: “Merry Christmas!” said Dumbledore as Harry, Ron, and Hermione approached the table. “As there are so few of us, it seemed foolish to use the House tables. . . . Sit down, sit down!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Dunno,
Coming?
No! I want a quick word with Professor McGonagall.
Probably trying to see if she can take any more classes,

Scene: “Merry — hic — Christmas! Password?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Scurvy cur,
No,
What? Why?
Strip it down?
There’s nothing wrong with it! Honestly, Professor —
What did you go running to McGonagall for?
Because I thought — and Professor McGonagall agrees with me — that that broom was probably sent to Harry by Sirius Black!

Scene: “Ah,” said Wood, his expression clearing. “Well, in that case — I really didn’t want to lose you as Seeker, Harry. And have you ordered a new broom yet?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Still looks ill, doesn’t he?
What d’you reckon’s the matter with him?
And what are you tutting at us for?
Nothing,
Yes, you were, I said I wonder what’s wrong with Lupin, and you —
Ah,
If you don’t want to tell us, don’t,
Fine,
She doesn’t know, She’s just trying to get us to talk to her again.

Scene: “What! You’d better get a move on, you know — you can’t ride that Shooting Star against Ravenclaw!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What!
Okay,
How does it work?
What does a Patronus look like?
And how do you conjure it?
Right,
Expecto Patronum, Expecto Patronum. Expecto Patronum, Expecto Patronum
Oh — yeah — Expecto Patronum, Expecto Patronum. Expecto Patrono — no, Patronum — sorry — Expecto Patronum, Expecto Patronum — Did you see that? Something happened!
Yes, Expecto Patronum! Expecto Patronum! Expecto — Expecto Patronum! Expecto Pat — EXPECTO PATRONUM! EXPECTO PATRONUM!
Sorry,
Yes . . . It’s getting worse,
I do! I’ve got to! What if the dementors turn up at our match against Ravenclaw? I can’t afford to fall off again. If we lose this game we’ve lost the Quidditch Cup!
Ready,
Expecto Patronum! Expecto Patronum! Expecto — Expecto Patronum! Expecto Pat — EXPECTO PATRONUM! EXPECTO PATRONUM!
I heard my dad, That’s the first time I’ve ever heard him — he tried to take on Voldemort himself, to give my mum time to run for it. . . .
Oh — yeah — Ah,
No! I’ll have one more go! I’m not thinking of happy enough things, that’s what it is. . . . Hang on. . . .
Expecto Patronum! Expecto Patronum! Expecto Patronum! EXPECTO PATRONUM! EXPECTO PATRONUM!
Can we have another go? Just one more go?
Fine, Professor Lupin? If you knew my dad, you must’ve known Sirius Black as well.
Nothing — I mean, I just knew they were friends at Hogwarts too. . . .

Scene: “How’s she doing it?” Ron muttered to Harry one evening as Harry sat finishing a nasty essay on Undetectable Poisons for Snape. Harry looked up. Hermione was barely visible behind a tottering pile of books.

Dialogue.Dialogue: How’s she doing it?
What!

Getting to all her classes! I heard her talking to Professor Vector, that Arithmancy witch, this morning. They were going on about yesterday’s lesson, but Hermione can’t’ve been there, because she was with us in Care of Magical Creatures! And Ernie Macmillan told me she’s never missed a Muggle Studies class, but half of them are at the same time as Divination, and she’s never missed one of them either!
I’m not buying anything Malfoy thinks is good,

Scene: “No, Potter, you can’t have it back yet,” Professor McGonagall told him the twelfth time this happened, before he’d even opened his mouth. “We’ve checked for most of the usual curses, but Professor Flitwick believes the broom might be carrying a Hurling Hex. I shall tell you once we’ve finished checking it. Now, please stop badgering me.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: You said it’s harder if there are loads of them,
Butterbeer! Yeah, I like that stuff! Oh — Ron and Hermione brought me some back from Hogsmeade,
What!
What!
What!
He deserves it, Yes, For . . . for some things . . .

Scene: “Do watch where you’re going, Potter!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Sorry, Professor —
I can have it back? Seriously?
She gave it to you? Excellent! Listen, can I still have a go on it? Tomorrow?
Yeah . . . anything . . . ,  You know what — we should make up with Hermione. . . . She was only trying to help. . . .
Okay,

Scene: “Oddsbodikins,” said Harry to Sir Cadogan, who looked extremely disappointed and reluctantly swung forward to let them into the common room. There was a sudden, excited murmur as every head turned and the next moment, Harry was surrounded by people exclaiming over his Firebolt.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oddsbodikins,
I got it back,
See, Hermione? There wasn’t anything wrong with it!
Well — there might have been! I mean, at least you know now that it’s safe!
I’ll take it! I’ve got to give Scabbers his rat tonic.
Can I sit down, then?
I suppose so,
How are you getting through all this stuff?
Oh, well — you know — working hard,
Why don’t you just drop a couple of subjects?
I couldn’t do that!
Arithmancy looks terrible,
It’s my favorite subject! It’s —
LOOK! LOOK!
What!
LOOK! BLOOD! HE’S GONE! AND YOU KNOW WHAT WAS ON THE FLOOR?
N-no,

Scene: “Okay, side with Ron, I knew you would!” she said shrilly. “First the Firebolt, now Scabbers, everything’s my fault, isn’t it! Just leave me alone, Harry, I’ve got a lot of work to do!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Okay, side with Ron, I knew you would! First the Firebolt, now Scabbers, everything’s my fault, isn’t it! Just leave me alone, Harry, I’ve got a lot of work to do!
He bit Goyle for us once! Remember, Harry?
Yeah, that’s true,

Scene: In a last-ditch attempt to cheer Ron up, Harry persuaded him to come along to the Gryffindor team’s final practice before the Ravenclaw match, so that he could have a ride on the Firebolt after they’d finished. This did seem to take Ron’s mind off Scabbers for a moment (“Great! Can I try and shoot a few goals on it?”) so they set off for the Quidditch field together.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Great! Can I try and shoot a few goals on it?
Yeah,
I’m staying out for a bit; Ron wants a go on the Firebolt, Here you go,

Scene: “Did you see his face?” said Ron gleefully, looking back at Malfoy. “He can’t believe it! This is brilliant!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Did you see his face? He can’t believe it! This is brilliant!
Yeah, reckon so,
Pity you can’t attach an extra arm to yours, Malfoy, Then it could catch the Snitch for you.

Scene: “Wood, Davies, shake hands,” Madam Hooch said briskly, and Wood shook hands with the Ravenclaw Captain.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Expecto Patronum!
Yes! Yes!  Yes! Yes!
The dementors didn’t affect me at all! I didn’t feel a thing!
Right,

Scene: “Did you even come to the match?” he asked her.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Did you even come to the match?
Of course I did, And I’m very glad we won, and I think you did really well, but I need to read this by Monday.
Come on, Hermione, come and have some food, I can’t, Harry. I’ve still got four hundred and twenty-two pages to read! Anyway . . . He doesn’t want me to join in.
If Scabbers hadn’t just been eaten, he could have had some of those Fudge Flies. He used to really like them —
Can’t you give her a break?
No, If she just acted like she was sorry — but she’ll never admit she’s wrong, Hermione. She’s still acting like Scabbers has gone on vacation or something.

Scene: “AAAAAAAAAAAAAARRRRRRRRRRRRGGGGGHHHHH! NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: AAAAAAAAAAAAAARRRRRRRRRRRRGGGGGHHHHH! NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!
Black! Sirius Black! With a knife!
Here! Just now! Slashed the curtains! Woke me up!
Look at the curtains! I tell you, he was here!

Scene: “Who shouted?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What’re you doing?
I’m telling you, I saw him!
Professor McGonagall told us to go to bed!
Woke me up! In our dormitory! With a knife! Woke me up!
I’m telling you —

Scene: “D’you reckon we should tell someone?” Harry asked Ron.

Dialogue.Dialogue: D’you reckon we should tell someone?

We know he’s not coming in through Honeydukes, We’d’ve heard if the shop had been broken into. . . . I was asleep, and I heard this ripping noise, and I thought it was in my dream, you know? But then there was this draft . . . I woke up and one side of the hangings on my bed had been pulled down. . . . I rolled over . . . and I saw him standing over me . . . like a skeleton, with loads of filthy hair . . . holding this great long knife, must’ve been twelve inches . . . and he looked at me, and I looked at him, and then I yelled, and he scampered. Why, though? Why did he run?

He must’ve known he’d have a job getting back out of the castle once you’d yelled and woken people up, He’d’ve had to kill the whole House to get back through the portrait hole . . . then he would’ve met the teachers. . . .

Scene: “Run for it, Neville,” Ron advised.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Run for it, Neville,
Ouch! Oh — thanks, Hedwig.
He probably wants to hear all about Black! All right, Hagrid! S’pose you want to hear about Saturday night, do you?

Scene: “What are they for, Hagrid?” said Harry.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What are they for, Hagrid?
What?
What about her?
— ate Scabbers!
Hagrid, we should’ve helped as well — sorry —
If she’d just get rid of that cat, I’d speak to her again! But she’s still sticking up for it! It’s a maniac, and she won’t hear a word against it!

Scene: “Ah, well, people can be a bit stupid abou’ their pets,” said Hagrid wisely. Behind him, Buckbeak spat a few ferret bones onto Hagrid’s pillow.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hogsmeade, next weekend! What d’you reckon?
Well, Filch hasn’t done anything about the passage into Honeydukes. . . .
Harry! Harry, if you go into Hogsmeade again . . . I’ll tell Professor McGonagall about that map!
Can you hear someone talking, Harry?
Ron, how can you let him go with you? After what Sirius Black nearly did to you! I mean it, I’ll tell —
So now you’re trying to get Harry expelled! Haven’t you done enough damage this year? So how about it? Come on, last time we went you didn’t see anything. You haven’t even been inside Zonko’s yet!
Okay, But I’m taking the Invisibility Cloak this time.

Scene: “It’s me,” he muttered.

Dialogue.Dialogue: It’s me,
What kept you?
Snape was hanging around. . . .

Scene: “Even the Hogwarts ghosts avoid it,” said Ron as they leaned on the fence, looking up at it. “I asked Nearly Headless Nick . . . he says he’s heard a very rough crowd lives here. No one can get in. Fred and George tried, obviously, but all the entrances are sealed shut. . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Even the Hogwarts ghosts avoid it, I asked Nearly Headless Nick . . . he says he’s heard a very rough crowd lives here. No one can get in. Fred and George tried, obviously, but all the entrances are sealed shut. . . .
Leave him to me,
Very haunted up here, isn’t it?
Harry! you’d better run for it! If Malfoy tells anyone — you’d better get back to the castle, quick —
See you later,

Scene: “Sit,” said Snape.

Dialogue.Dialogue: “I don’t know, Professor.”
No,
No,
SHUT UP!
“I told you to shut up about my dad!” “I know the truth, all right? He saved your life! Dumbledore told me! You wouldn’t even be here if it wasn’t for my dad!”
“Spare bit of parchment,” “No!”
“No,”

Scene: “Professor, I —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: “Professor, I —”
Why did Snape think I’d got it from the manufacturers?
Do you know them?
It’s my fault, I persuaded you to go. Lupin’s right, it was stupid, we shouldn’t’ve done it — Come to have a good gloat? Or have you just been to tell on us?
“No,” “No,” I just thought you ought to know . . . Hagrid lost his case. Buckbeak is going to be executed.

Scene: “You’re late, boys!” said Professor Flitwick reprovingly as Harry opened the classroom door. “Come along, quickly, wands out, we’re experimenting with Cheering Charms today, we’ve already divided into pairs —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: “Where’s Hermione gone?”
That’s weird, Maybe — maybe she went to the bathroom or something?
She could’ve done with a Cheering Charm on her too,

Scene: They passed the security trolls, gave the Fat Lady the password (“Flibbertigibbet”), and scrambled through the portrait hole into the common room.

Dialogue.Dialogue: W-what? Is it time to go? W-which lesson have we got now?
Divination, but it’s not for another twenty minutes, Hermione, why didn’t you come to Charms?

with
I don’t believe it! Was Professor Flitwick angry?

Scene: “I can’t believe I missed Cheering Charms! And I bet they come up in our exams; Professor Flitwick hinted they might!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I can’t believe I missed Cheering Charms! And I bet they come up in our exams; Professor Flitwick hinted they might!
I thought we weren’t starting crystal balls until next term,
Don’t complain, this means we’ve finished palmistry, I was getting sick of her flinching every time she looked at my hands.
Well, honestly . . . ‘the fates have informed her’ . . . who sets the exam? She does! What an amazing prediction!
Flibbertigibbet
Yeah, there’s a burn on this table, Someone’s spilled their candle.
This is such a waste of time, I could be practicing something useful. I could be catching up on Cheering Charms —
I don’t need help, It’s obvious what this means. There’s going to be loads of fog tonight.
Oh, for goodness’ sake! Not that ridiculous Grim again!
“Fine!” “Fine!” “I give up! I’m leaving!”

Scene: “Call this a holiday!” Seamus Finnigan roared at the common room one afternoon. “The exams are ages away, what’re they playing at?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I KNOW, OLIVER!

Scene: “I can’t work, I can’t concentrate,” she said nervously.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I can’t work, I can’t concentrate, You’re going to be fine,
You’ve got a Firebolt!
Yeah . . . ,
Ron! Ron! Wake up!
Huh?
I need you to tell me if you can see something!
What? What’re you on about?
Down here —

Scene: Relieved, Harry zoomed away, gazing around for the Snitch, but still making sure he caught every word of Lee’s commentary. It was essential that he hold Malfoy off the Snitch until Gryffindor was more than fifty points up —

Dialogue.Dialogue: “You —”
Go! Go! Go!  YES!

Scene: “Hello there, Harry!” he said. “Just had an exam, I expect? Nearly finished?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yes,
Does that mean the appeal’s already happened?
Then you might not have to witness an execution at all! The hippogriff might get off!
Why’d you stop me? Did you see them? They’ve even got the axe ready! This isn’t justice!
As long as Hagrid keeps his head this time, and argues his case properly, they can’t possibly execute Buckbeak. . . .
Nope,

Scene: “She says the crystal ball’s told her that if I tell you, I’ll have a horrible accident!” squeaked Neville as he clambered back down the ladder toward Harry and Ron, who had now reached the landing.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah, Wish she’d hurry up . . .
How’d it go?
Rubbish, Couldn’t see a thing, so I made some stuff up. Don’t think she was convinced, though. . . .
Meet you in the common room,

Dialogue.Dialogue: A hippogriff,
Yes,
No!
No! It looks fine, it’s — flying away. . . .
S-sorry?
You — you just told me that the — the Dark Lord’s going to rise again . . . that his servant’s going to go back to him. . . .
But you just said it! You said the Dark Lord —

Scene: Lost appeal. They’re going to execute at sunset.Nothing you can do. Don’t come down. I don’t wantyou to see it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Buckbeak lost, Hagrid’s just sent this.
We’ve got to go, He can’t just sit there on his own, waiting for the executioner!
Sunset, though, We’d never be allowed . . . ’specially you, Harry. . . .
If we only had the Invisibility Cloak. . . .
Where is it?
. . . if Snape sees me anywhere near there again, I’m in serious trouble,
Yeah, If he sees you. . . . How do you open the witch’s hump again?
She hasn’t gone to get it? Hermione, I don’t know what’s gotten into you lately! First you hit Malfoy, then you walk out on Professor Trelawney —

Scene: “It’s us,” Harry hissed. “We’re wearing the Invisibility Cloak. Let us in and we can take it off.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: It’s us, We’re wearing the Invisibility Cloak. Let us in and we can take it off.
Hagrid Hagrid
Hagrid
Hagrid
Ron! I — I don’t believe it — it’s Scabbers!
What are you talking about? What? Scabbers, what are you doing here? Scabbers! No cats! There’s nothing here to hurt you!

Scene: “It’s okay, Beaky,” said Hagrid softly. “It’s okay . . .” He turned to Harry, Ron, and Hermione. “Go on,” he said. “Get goin’.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hagrid
We’ll tell them what really happened —
They can’t kill him —

Scene: “Hagrid,” Harry muttered. Without thinking about what he was doing, he made to turn back, but both Ron and Hermione seized his arms.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hagrid,
We can’t, He’ll be in worse trouble if they know we’ve been to see him. . . .
How — could — they? How could they?
Come on, Scabbers, keep still, What’s the matter with you, you stupid rat? Stay still — OUCH! He bit me!
He won’t — stay — put — What’s the matter with him?
Crookshanks!
Scabbers — NO!
Ron!
Get away from him — get away — Scabbers, come here — Gotcha! Get off, you stinking cat —
Lumos! Ron!
Harry — we’ve got to go for help —
No! That thing’s big enough to eat him; we haven’t got time —
We’re never going to get through without help —
If that dog can get in, we can,
Oh, help, help, please . . . Crookshanks! How did he know — ?
He’s friends with that dog, I’ve seen them together. Come on — and keep your wand out —

Scene: “Where’s Ron?” she whispered in a terrified voice.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Where’s Ron?
This way,
Where does this tunnel come out?
I don’t know. . . . It’s marked on the Marauder’s Map but Fred and George said no one’s ever gotten into it. . . . It goes off the edge of the map, but it looked like it ends up in Hogsmeade. . . .

Scene: “Ghosts didn’t do that,” he said slowly.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry, I think we’re in the Shrieking Shack.
Ghosts didn’t do that,

Scene: “Ron — are you okay?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Ron — are you okay?
Where’s the dog?
Harry, Harry, it’s a trap —
What — He’s the dog . . . he’s an Animagus. . . .
Harry!
Harry,
Did you hear me? You’ll have to kill all three of us!
Why’s that? Didn’t care last time, did you? Didn’t mind slaughtering all those Muggles to get at Pettigrew. . . . What’s the matter, gone soft in Azkaban?
Harry! Be quiet!
HE KILLED MY MUM AND DAD! No
Argh! NO YOU DON’T! Get out of the way!
You killed my parents, The whole story? You sold them to Voldemort. That’s all I need to know.
I understand a lot better than you think, You never heard her, did you? My mum . . . trying to stop Voldemort killing me . . . and you did that . . . you did it. . . .
WE’RE UP HERE! WE’RE UP HERE — SIRIUS BLACK — QUICK!
Professor, what’s going on — ?
I DON’T BELIEVE IT! You — you —
— you and him!
I trusted you, and all the time you’ve been his friend!
Harry,
“Get away from me, werewolf!”
Ages, Since I did Professor Snape’s essay. . . .
“Both,”
I’m not, If I’d been a bit cleverer, I’d have told everyone what you are!
Dumbledore hired you when he knew you were a werewolf? Is he mad?
AND HE WAS WRONG! YOU’VE BEEN HELPING HIM ALL THE TIME!
If you haven’t been helping him, how did you know he was here?
You know how to work it?
You wrote — ?
How d’you know about the Cloak?
What? No, we weren’t!
No one was with us!
One of us!
What? What’s Scabbers got to do with it?
What? What’s my rat got to do with anything?
What d’you mean — of course he’s a rat —

Scene: “You’re both mental.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: You’re both mental.
Ridiculous!
Peter Pettigrew’s dead! He killed him twelve years ago!
You’re nutters, both of you, I’ve had enough of this. I’m off.
There were witnesses who saw Pettigrew die, A whole street full of them . . .
But Professor Lupin . . . Scabbers can’t be Pettigrew . . . it just can’t be true, you know it can’t . . .

Because . . . because people would know if Peter Pettigrew had been an Animagus. We did Animagi in class with Professor McGonagall. And I looked them up when I did my homework — the Ministry of Magic keeps tabs on witches and wizards who can become animals; there’s a register showing what animal they become, and their markings and things . . . and I went and looked Professor McGonagall up on the register, and there have been only seven Animagi this century, and Pettigrew’s name wasn’t on the list —
This place is haunted!
Shh!
My dad too?
But how did that help you?
What sort of animal — ?
So that’s why Snape doesn’t like you, because he thought you were in on the joke?

Scene: “Professor Lupin could have killed me about a hundred times this year,” Harry said. “I’ve been alone with him loads of times, having defense lessons against the dementors. If he was helping Black, why didn’t he just finish me off then?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Professor Lupin could have killed me about a hundred times this year, I’ve been alone with him loads of times, having defense lessons against the dementors. If he was helping Black, why didn’t he just finish me off then?
Expelliarmus!
We attacked a teacher. . . . We attacked a teacher . . . , Oh, we’re going to be in so much trouble —
I’m still not saying I believe you,
Come off it, Are you trying to say he broke out of Azkaban just to get his hands on Scabbers? I mean . . .
What about it?
Look, Scabbers probably had a fight with another rat or something! He’s been in my family for ages, right —
We — we’ve been taking good care of him!
He’s been scared of that mad cat!
What do you mean?
And why did he fake his death? Because he knew you were about to kill him like you killed my parents! And now you’ve come to finish him off!
Then I should’ve let Snape take you!
THAT’S NOT TRUE! HE WAS THEIR SECRET-KEEPER! HE SAID SO BEFORE YOU TURNED UP. HE SAID HE KILLED THEM!
What are you going to do with him if I give him to you?
Professor Lupin? Can — can I say something?
Well — Scabbers — I mean, this — this man — he’s been sleeping in Harry’s dormitory for three years. If he’s working for You-Know-Who, how come he never tried to hurt Harry before now?
Er — Mr. Black — Sirius? If you don’t mind me asking, how — how did you get out of Azkaban, if you didn’t use Dark Magic?
The guards say he’s been talking in his sleep . . . always the same words . . . ‘He’s at Hogwarts.’
I let you sleep in my bed!
NO! You can’t kill him, You can’t.
I know, We’ll take him up to the castle. We’ll hand him over to the dementors. . . . He can go to Azkaban . . . but don’t kill him.
Get off me, I’m not doing this for you. I’m doing it because I don’t reckon my dad would’ve wanted his best friends to become killers — just for you.
He can go to Azkaban, If anyone deserves that place, he does. . . .
That’s better,
What about Professor Snape?
And me,

Scene: “You know what this means?” Sirius said abruptly to Harry as they made their slow progress along the tunnel. “Turning Pettigrew in?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: You’re free,
Yeah, I knew that,
Leave the Dursleys?
Are you insane? Of course I want to leave the Dursleys! Have you got a house? When can I move in?
Yeah, I mean it!

Scene: But Harry couldn’t run. Ron was chained to Pettigrew and Lupin. He leapt forward but Sirius caught him around the chest and threw him back.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Expelliarmus! “Stay where you are!” “Sirius, he’s gone, Pettigrew transformed!”
What did he do to him?
“I don’t know. . . .” “We’d better get them up to the castle and tell someone,”
“Come —”
“Sirius,

Scene: Shocking business . . . shocking . . . miracle none of them died . . . never heard the like . . . by thunder, it was lucky you were there, Snape. . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I need to see the headmaster,
WHAT?
Minister, listen! Sirius Black’s innocent! Peter Pettigrew faked his own death! We saw him tonight! You can’t let the dementors do that thing to Sirius, he’s —
YOU HAVEN’T! YOU’VE GOT THE WRONG MAN!
Minister, listen, please, I saw him too. It was Ron’s rat, he’s an Animagus, Pettigrew, I mean, and —
WE’RE NOT CONFUNDED!
Professor Dumbledore, Sirius Black —
Professor!
— he escaped when Professor Lupin turned into a werewolf —
— he’s a rat —
— Pettigrew’s front paw, I mean, finger, he cut it off —
— Pettigrew attacked Ron, it wasn’t Sirius —
Professor Lupin can tell you —
But —
But you believe us.
But —
Good luck? Three turns? What’s he talking about? What are we supposed to do?
Quick! Quick!
“Here —”
“Ready?
“What are we doing?” WHAT?

Scene: “In here!” Hermione seized Harry’s arm and dragged him across the hall to the door of a broom closet; she opened it, pushed him inside among the buckets and mops, then slammed the door behind them.

Dialogue.Dialogue: In here!
WHAT?
We’ve gone back in time, Three hours back . . .
But —
Shh! Listen! Someone’s coming! I think — I think it might be us!
Footsteps across the hall . . . yes, I think it’s us going down to Hagrid’s! Are you telling me, that we’re here in this cupboard and we’re out there too?
Yes, I’m sure it’s us. It doesn’t sound like more than three people . . . and we’re walking slowly because we’re under the Invisibility Cloak — We’ve gone down the front steps. . . .
Where did you get that hourglass thing?

It’s called a Time-Turner, and I got it from Professor McGonagall on our first day back. I’ve been using it all year to get to all my lessons. Professor McGonagall made me swear I wouldn’t tell anyone. She had to tell them that I was a model student, and that I’d never, ever use it for anything except my studies. . . . I’ve been turning it back so I could do hours over again, that’s how I’ve been doing several lessons at once, see? But . . . Harry, I don’t understand what Dumbledore wants us to do. Why did he tell us to go back three hours? How’s that going to help Sirius?
There must be something that happened around now he wants us to change, What happened? We were walking down to Hagrid’s three hours ago. . . .
This is three hours ago, and we are walking down to Hagrid’s, We just heard ourselves leaving. . . .
Dumbledore just said — just said we could save more than one innocent life. . . . Hermione, we’re going to save Buckbeak!
But — how will that help Sirius?

Dumbledore said — he just told us where the window is — the window of Flitwick’s office! Where they’ve got Sirius locked up! We’ve got to fly Buckbeak up to the window and rescue Sirius! Sirius can escape on Buckbeak — they can escape together!
If we manage that without being seen, it’ll be a miracle!
Well, we’ve got to try, haven’t we? Doesn’t sound like anyone’s there. . . . Come on, let’s go. . . .

Scene: “If anyone’s looking out of the window —” Hermione squeaked, looking up at the castle behind them.

Dialogue.Dialogue: If anyone’s looking out of the window —
We’ll run for it, Straight into the forest, all right? We’ll have to hide behind a tree or something and keep a lookout —

Okay, but we’ll go around by the greenhouses! We need to keep out of sight of Hagrid’s front door, or we’ll see us! We must be nearly at Hagrid’s by now! Right, We need to sneak over to Hagrid’s. . . . Keep out of sight, Harry. . . .
Let us in and we can take it off.

Scene: “Yeh shouldn’ve come!” Hagrid whispered. He stood back, then shut the door quickly.

Dialogue.Dialogue: This is the weirdest thing we’ve ever done,
Let’s move along a bit, We need to get nearer to Buckbeak!
Now?
No! If we steal him now, those Committee people will think Hagrid set him free! We’ve got to wait until they’ve seen he’s tied outside!
That’s going to give us about sixty seconds,
No! Don’t you understand? We’re breaking one of the most important Wizarding laws! Nobody’s supposed to change time, nobody! You heard Dumbledore, if we’re seen —
We’d only be seen by ourselves and Hagrid!

Harry, what do you think you’d do if you saw yourself bursting into Hagrid’s house? Exactly! You wouldn’t understand, you might even attack yourself! Don’t you see? Professor McGonagall told me what awful things have happened when wizards have meddled with time. . . . Loads of them ended up killing their past or future selves by mistake!
Okay!
We’re about to come out!

Scene: The Patronus turned. It was cantering back toward Harry across the still surface of the water. It wasn’t a horse. It wasn’t a unicorn, either. It was a stag. It was shining brightly as the moon above . . . it was coming back to him. . . .

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry,
Come on! Where are you? Dad, come on —
Look! Did anyone see you?
Yes, haven’t you been listening? I saw me but I thought I was my dad! It’s okay!
Harry,
I knew I could do it this time, because I’d already done it. . . . Does that make sense?
Harry,

Scene: “Harry, I can’t believe it. . . . You conjured up a Patronus that drove away all those dementors! That’s very, very advanced magic. . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Right, We’ve got about forty-five minutes until Dumbledore locks the door to the hospital wing. We’ve got to rescue Sirius and get back into the ward before anybody realizes we’re missing. . . .
D’you reckon he’s up there yet?
Look! Who’s that? Someone’s coming back out of the castle!
Hermione! The executioner! He’s gone to get the dementors! This is it, Hermione —

Scene: “Whoa!” he said, pulling backward as hard as he could.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Whoa! He’s there!
Stand back!
“Get on — there’s not much time, Okay, Buckbeak, up!

Scene: Hermione was tugging at his sleeve, staring at her watch. “We’ve got exactly ten minutes to get back down to the hospital wing without anybody seeing us — before Dumbledore locks the door —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: We’ve got exactly ten minutes to get back down to the hospital wing without anybody seeing us — before Dumbledore locks the door —
Okay, let’s go. . . .

Scene: Harry clenched his teeth. He caught a glimpse of Snape’s smirk as he and Fudge passed Harry and Hermione’s hiding place. Their footsteps died away. Harry and Hermione waited a few moments to make sure they’d really gone, then started to run in the opposite direction. Down one staircase, then another, along a new corridor — then they heard a cackling ahead.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Peeves! In here!
Sirius

Scene: “Oh, he’s horrible,” whispered Hermione, her ear to the door. “I bet he’s all excited because the dementors are going to finish off Sirius. . . .” She checked her watch. “Three minutes, Harry!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: “Three minutes, Harry!”
Hermione — what’ll happen — if we don’t get back inside — before Dumbledore locks the door?
We did it! Sirius has gone, on Buckbeak. . . .

Scene: Dumbledore beamed at them.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Really — they’ll wake everybody up! What do they think they’re doing?

Scene: “OUT WITH IT, POTTER!” he bellowed. “WHAT DID YOU DO?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry? Why are we in here? Where’s Sirius? Where’s Lupin? What’s going on?
You explain,

Scene: “Know I shouldn’ feel happy, after wha’ happened las’ night,” he said. “I mean, Black escapin’ again, an’ everythin’ — but guess what?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What?
That’s wonderful!
What?
What? Why?
I’m going to see him,
— doesn’t sound like there’s anything we can do —
I don’t care. I still want to see him. I’ll meet you back here.

Scene: “I saw you coming,” said Lupin, smiling. He pointed to the parchment he had been poring over. It was the Marauder’s Map.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I just saw Hagrid, And he said you’d resigned. It’s not true, is it?
What? The Ministry of Magic don’t think you were helping Sirius, do they?
You’re not leaving just because of that!
You’re the best Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher we’ve ever had! Don’t go!
How d’you know about that? What else could have driven the dementors back?
You told me Moony, Wormtail, Padfoot, and Prongs would’ve wanted to lure me out of school . . . you said they’d have thought it was funny.
It didn’t make any difference, Pettigrew got away.
Professor Dumbledore — yesterday, when I was having my Divination exam, Professor Trelawney went very — very strange.

Yes . . . her voice went all deep and her eyes rolled and she said . . . she said Voldemort’s servant was going to set out to return to him before midnight. . . . She said the servant would help him come back to power.  “And then she sort of became normal again, and she couldn’t remember anything she’d said. Was it — was she making a real prediction?” But — I stopped Sirius and Professor Lupin from killing Pettigrew! That makes it my fault if Voldemort comes back!
I don’t want a bond with Pettigrew! He betrayed my parents!

Last night . . . I thought it was my dad who’d conjured my Patronus. I mean, when I saw myself across the lake . . . I thought I was seeing him. It was stupid, thinking it was him, I mean, I knew he was dead.

Scene: So — after many tantrums, after arguments that shook Harry’s bedroom floor, and many tears from Aunt Petunia — the new regime had begun. The diet sheet that had been sent by the Smeltings school nurse had been taped to the fridge, which had been emptied of all Dudley’s favorite things — fizzy drinks and cakes, chocolate bars and burgers — and filled instead with fruit and vegetables and the sorts of things that Uncle Vernon called “rabbit food.” To make Dudley feel better about it all, Aunt Petunia had insisted that the whole family follow the diet too. She now passed a grapefruit quarter to Harry. He noticed that it was a lot smaller than Dudley’s. Aunt Petunia seemed to feel that the best way to keep up Dudley’s morale was to make sure that he did, at least, get more to eat than Harry.

Dialogue.Dialogue: So what?
She did put enough stamps on, then,
So — can I go then?
You’ve seen her, She’s my friend Ron’s mother, she was meeting him off the Hog — off the school train at the end of last term.
It’s a sport,
Normal for us, you know, owl post. That’s what’s normal for wizards.
Only after Dudley finished with them,
“Okay, I can’t see the World Cup. Can I go now, then? Only I’ve got a letter to Sirius I want to finish. You know — my godfather.”
Well — yeah, It’s been a while since he heard from me, and, you know, if he doesn’t, he might start thinking something’s wrong.
Well, all right then.

Scene: “I hope you told them to dress properly, these people,” he snarled at once. “I’ve seen the sort of stuff your lot wear. They’d better have the decency to put on normal clothes, that’s all.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Er, I think so,

Scene: “They’re late!” he snarled at Harry.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I know, Maybe — er — the traffic’s bad, or something.

Scene: “What is it?” gasped Aunt Petunia, who had backed into the wall and was staring, terrified, toward the fire. “What is it, Vernon?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: They — they’ve tried to get here by Floo powder, Mr. Weasley? Can you hear me? Mr. Weasley, it’s Harry . . . the fireplace has been blocked up. You won’t be able to get through there.
They’ve got an electric fire,
What are we doing here? Has something gone wrong?
It’s upstairs,
Yep, that’s Dudley.
the Burrow! the Burrow!
Well . . .’bye then,
It doesn’t matter, Honestly, I don’t care.
See you, See you,
the Burrow!

Scene: “Did he eat it?” said Fred excitedly, holding out a hand to pull Harry to his feet.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What is it? What was it?
Yeah, he is, Mr. Weasley,
Why don’t you show Harry where he’s sleeping, Ron?
He knows where he’s sleeping, in my room, he slept there last —
We can all go,
Well, Right.

Scene: Mrs. Weasley had just entered the kitchen. She was a short, plump woman with a very kind face, though her eyes were presently narrowed with suspicion.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What is it?

Mum found this stack of order forms when she was cleaning Fred and George’s room, Great long price lists for stuff they’ve invented. Joke stuff, you know. Fake wands and trick sweets, loads of stuff. It was brilliant, I never knew they’d been inventing all that . . .

Only, most of the stuff — well, all of it, really — was a bit dangerous, and, you know, they were planning to sell it at Hogwarts to make some money,  and Mum went mad at them. Told them they weren’t allowed to make any more of it, and burned all the order forms. . . . She’s furious at them anyway. They didn’t get as many O. W.L.s as she expected.
Hi, Percy,
We’re not thundering, We’re walking. Sorry if we’ve disturbed the top-secret workings of the Ministry of Magic.
What are you working on?
That’ll change the world, that report will,

Scene: “Shut up, Pig,” said Ron, edging his way between two of the four beds that had been squeezed into the room. “Fred and George are in here with us, because Bill and Charlie are in their room,” he told Harry. “Percy gets to keep his room all to himself because he’s got to work.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Shut up, Pig, Fred and George are in here with us, because Bill and Charlie are in their room, Percy gets to keep his room all to himself because he’s got to work.
Er — why are you calling that owl Pig?

Yep, Ginny named him, She reckons it’s sweet. And I tried to change it, but it was too late, he won’t answer to anything else. So now he’s Pig. I’ve got to keep him up here because he annoys Errol and Hermes. He annoys me too, come to that.
Where’s Crookshanks?
Out in the garden, I expect, He likes chasing gnomes. He’s never seen any before.
Percy’s enjoying work, then?

Enjoying it? I don’t reckon he’d come home if Dad didn’t make him. He’s obsessed. Just don’t get him onto the subject of his boss. . . Mr. Crouch is of the opinion . . . Mr. Crouch was telling me . . . They’ll be announcing their engagement any day now.
Have you had a good summer,  Did you get our food parcels and everything?
Yeah, thanks a lot, They saved my life, those cakes.
And have you heard from — ?
I think they’ve stopped arguing, Shall we go down and help your mum with dinner?

Scene: “It’s got to be Ireland,” said Charlie thickly, through a mouthful of potato. “They flattened Peru in the semifinals.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What is this?
So — have you heard from Sirius lately?
Wow — hope it does this time!

Scene: “What d’you think?” he asked anxiously. “We’re supposed to go incognito — do I look like a Muggle, Harry?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah, very good.
You have to pass a test to Apparate?
Er — Splinched?
Were they okay?
But Bill and Charlie and Percy can all do it?
Walk? What, are we walking to the World Cup?

Scene: “So how does everyone get there without all the Muggles noticing?” he asked.

Dialogue.Dialogue: So how does everyone get there without all the Muggles noticing?
What sort of objects are Portkeys?

Scene: “Amos!” said Mr. Weasley, smiling as he strode over to the man who had shouted. The rest of them followed.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Er — yeah,

Scene: “Morning, Basil,” said Mr. Weasley, picking up the boot and handing it to the kilted wizard, who threw it into a large box of used Portkeys beside him; Harry could see an old newspaper, an empty drinks can, and a punctured football.

Dialogue.Dialogue: A twenty, Ah yes, so it is. . . . I don’t know, these little bits of paper . . .

Scene: “How many times, Kevin? You don’t — touch — Daddy’s — wand — yecchh!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Er — is it my eyes, or has everything gone green?
Like we’d say anything else surrounded by that lot.
I wonder what the Bulgarians have got dangling all over their tents?
Let’s go and have a look,
Krum,
What?
Krum!
He looks really grumpy,
‘Really grumpy’? Who cares what he looks like? He’s unbelievable. He’s really young too. Only just eighteen or something. He’s a genius, you wait until tonight, you’ll see.

Scene: “I bought this in a Muggle shop,” said the old wizard stubbornly. “Muggles wear them.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Who d’you reckon they are? They don’t go to Hogwarts, do they?

’Spect they go to some foreign school, I know there are others. Never met anyone who went to one, though. Bill had a penfriend at a school in Brazil . . . this was years and years ago . . . and he wanted to go on an exchange trip but Mum and Dad couldn’t afford it.

Scene: “You’ve been ages,” said George when they finally got back to the Weasleys’ tents.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Met a few people, You not got that fire started yet?
Come here, Mr. Weasley,
They’re what?

Scene: “Been saving my pocket money all summer for this,” Ron told Harry as they and Hermione strolled through the salesmen, buying souvenirs. Though Ron purchased a dancing shamrock hat and a large green rosette, he also bought a small figure of Viktor Krum, the Bulgarian Seeker. The miniature Krum walked backward and forward over Ron’s hand, scowling up at the green rosette above him.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Been saving my pocket money all summer for this,
Wow, look at these!
Wish I hadn’t bought this now,
Three pairs,
No — don’t bother,
You won’t be getting anything for Christmas, For about ten years, mind.
Fair enough,
Oooh, thanks, Harry, And I’ll get us some programs, look —

Scene: Harry disentangled himself from Ron and got to his feet. They had arrived on what appeared to be a deserted stretch of misty moor. In front of them was a pair of tired and grumpy-looking wizards, one of whom was holding a large gold watch, the other a thick roll of parchment and a quill. Both were dressed as Muggles, though very inexpertly: The man with the watch wore a tweed suit with thigh-length galoshes; his colleague, a kilt and a poncho.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Dobby?
Sorry, I just thought you were someone I knew.
Yeah, I am,
How is he? How’s freedom suiting him?
Why? What’s wrong with him?
Why not?
Paying? Well — why shouldn’t he be paid?
Well, it’s about time he had a bit of fun,
Why’s he sent you up here, if he knows you don’t like heights?
So that’s a house-elf? Weird things, aren’t they?
Dobby was weirder,
Wild! I can make that old bloke down there pick his nose again . . . and again . . . and again . . .
‘A display from the team mascots will precede the match,’
Slimy gits,
What are veel — ?
Harry, what are you doing?
Huh?
Honestly!
Excellent!
There you go, for the Omnioculars! Now you’ve got to buy me a Christmas present, ha!
That’s him, that’s him!
Hawkshead Attacking Formation,
What? But Levski’s got the Quaffle!
Harry, if you’re not going to watch at normal speed, you’re going to miss things!
They’re going to crash!
Look at the referee!
Time-out! Ah, come on, he can’t play like that, look at him —
He’s seen the Snitch! He’s seen it! Look at him go!
They’re going to crash!
They’re not!
Lynch is!
He’s got it — Krum’s got it — it’s all over!
What did he catch the Snitch for? He ended it when Ireland were a hundred and sixty points ahead, the idiot!
He knew they were never going to catch up! The Irish Chasers were too good. . . . He wanted to end it on his terms, that’s all. . . .
He was very brave, wasn’t he? He looks a terrible mess. . . .

Scene: “Harry Potter, you know,” he told the Bulgarian minister loudly, who was wearing splendid robes of black velvet trimmed with gold and didn’t seem to understand a word of English. “Harry Potter . . . oh come on now, you know who he is . . . the boy who survived You-Know-Who . . . you do know who he is —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: That’s sick, That is really sick. . . .
What happened? Ron, where are you? Oh this is stupid — Lumos!
Tripped over a tree root,
What’s that supposed to mean?
Hermione’s a witch,
You watch your mouth!
Never mind, Ron,
Where’re your parents? Out there wearing masks, are they?
Oh come on, let’s go and find the others.
C’mon,
I’ll bet you anything his dad is one of that masked lot!
Well, with any luck, the Ministry will catch him! Oh I can’t believe this. Where have the others got to?
Er — what?
Beauxbatons,
Sorry?
They must go to Beauxbatons, You know . . . Beauxbatons Academy of Magic . . . I read about it in An Appraisal of Magical Education in Europe.
Oh . . . yeah . . . right,
Fred and George can’t have gone that far,
Ah, no, I don’t believe it . . . I’ve lost my wand!
You’re kidding!
Maybe it’s back in the tent,
Maybe it fell out of your pocket when we were running?
Yeah, maybe . . .
What happened? Why can’t she run properly?
Bet she didn’t ask permission to hide,

You know, house-elves get a very raw deal! It’s slavery, that’s what it is! That Mr. Crouch made her go up to the top of the stadium, and she was terrified, and he’s got her bewitched so she can’t even run when they start trampling tents! Why doesn’t anyone do something about it?
Well, the elves are happy, aren’t they? You heard old Winky back at the match . . . ‘House-elves is not supposed to have fun’ . . . that’s what she likes, being bossed around. . . .
It’s people like you, Ron, who prop up rotten and unjust systems, just because they’re too lazy to —
Let’s just keep moving, shall we?

Scene: The Bulgarian wizard suddenly spotted Harry’s scar and started gabbling loudly and excitedly, pointing at it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Did I tell you I’ve invented a broomstick that’ll reach Jupiter?
Honestly! I reckon we can just wait here, you know. We’ll hear anyone coming a mile off.
Well — there’s a sort of riot going on,
At the campsite . . . some people have got hold of a family of Muggles. . . .
Not exactly on top of things, Mr. Bagman, is he?
He was a great Beater, though, The Wimbourne Wasps won the league three times in a row while he was with them.
I hope the others are okay,
They’ll be fine,
Imagine if your dad catches Lucius Malfoy, He’s always said he’d like to get something on him.
That’d wipe the smirk off old Draco’s face, all right,
Those poor Muggles, though, What if they can’t get them down?
They will, They’ll find a way.
Mad, though, to do something like that when the whole Ministry of Magic’s out here tonight! I mean, how do they expect to get away with it? Do you think they’ve been drinking, or are they just —

Scene: Clutching their purchases, Mr. Weasley in the lead, they all hurried into the wood, following the lantern-lit trail. They could hear the sounds of thousands of people moving around them, shouts and laughter, snatches of singing. The atmosphere of feverish excitement was highly infectious; Harry couldn’t stop grinning. They walked through the wood for twenty minutes, talking and joking loudly, until at last they emerged on the other side and found themselves in the shadow of a gigantic stadium. Though Harry could see only a fraction of the immense gold walls surrounding the field, he could tell that ten cathedrals would fit comfortably inside it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hello? Who’s there? MORSMORDRE!
What the — ?
Who’s there?
Harry, come on, move!
What happened?
It’s the Dark Mark, Harry! You-Know-Who’s sign!
Voldemort’s — ?
Harry, come on!
DUCK!
We didn’t do that!
We didn’t do anything! What did you want to attack us for?
Over there, There was someone behind the trees . . . they shouted words — an incantation —
Hey — that’s mine!
That’s my wand! I dropped it!
I didn’t drop it there, anyway, I missed it right after we got into the wood.
It wasn’t her! Winky’s got a squeaky little voice, and the voice we heard doing the incantation was much deeper! It didn’t sound anything like Winky, did it?
No, It definitely didn’t sound like an elf.
Yeah,
But she was frightened! Your elf’s scared of heights, and those wizards in masks were levitating people! You can’t blame her for wanting to get out of their way!

Scene: Clutching their purchases, Mr. Weasley in the lead, they all hurried into the wood, following the lantern-lit trail. They could hear the sounds of thousands of people moving around them, shouts and laughter, snatches of singing. The atmosphere of feverish excitement was highly infectious; Harry couldn’t stop grinning. They walked through the wood for twenty minutes, talking and joking loudly, until at last they emerged on the other side and found themselves in the shadow of a gigantic stadium. Though Harry could see only a fraction of the immense gold walls surrounding the field, he could tell that ten cathedrals would fit comfortably inside it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: She didn’t do anything — she was just in the wrong place at the wrong time!
She didn’t run amok! She just picked it up off the ground!
Look, can someone just explain what that skull thing was? It wasn’t hurting anyone. . . . Why’s it such a big deal?
I told you, it’s You-Know-Who’s symbol, Ron, I read about it in The Rise and Fall of the Dark Arts.
I don’t get it, I mean . . . it’s still only a shape in the sky. . . .
What? What are Death Eaters?
Yeah, Dad, we met Draco Malfoy in the woods, and he as good as told us his dad was one of those nutters in masks! And we all know the Malfoys were right in with You-Know-Who!
But if they were the Death Eaters, why did they Disapparate when they saw the Dark Mark? They’d have been pleased to see it, wouldn’t they?
So . . . whoever conjured the Dark Mark . . . were they doing it to show support for the Death Eaters, or to scare them away?

Scene: “I knew it,” said Mr. Weasley heavily. “Ministry blunders . . . culprits not apprehended . . . lax security . . . Dark wizards running unchecked . . . national disgrace . . . Who wrote this? Ah . . . of course . . . Rita Skeeter.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Mrs. Weasley, Hedwig hasn’t arrived with a letter for me, has she?
All right if I go and dump my stuff in your room, Ron?
Yeah . . . think I will too, Hermione?
Yes,

Scene: “What’s up, Harry?” said Ron, the moment they had closed the door of the attic room behind them.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What’s up, Harry?
There’s something I haven’t told you, On Saturday morning, I woke up with my scar hurting again.
But — he wasn’t there, was he? You-Know-Who? I mean — last time your scar kept hurting, he was at Hogwarts, wasn’t he?
I’m sure he wasn’t on Privet Drive, But I was dreaming about him . . . him and Peter — you know, Wormtail.   I can’t remember all of it now, but they were plotting to kill . . . someone.
It was only a dream, Just a nightmare.
Yeah, but was it, though? It’s weird, isn’t it? . . . My scar hurts, and three days later the Death Eaters are on the march, and Voldemort’s sign’s up in the sky again.
Don’t — say — his — name!
And remember what Professor Trelawney said? At the end of last year?
Oh Harry, you aren’t going to pay attention to anything that old fraud says?

You weren’t there, You didn’t hear her. This time was different. I told you, she went into a trance — a real one.   she said the Dark Lord would rise again . . . greater and more terrible than ever before . . . and he’d manage it because his servant was going to go back to him . . . and that night Wormtail escaped.
Why were you asking if Hedwig had come, Harry? Are you expecting a letter?
I told Sirius about my scar, I’m waiting for his answer.
Good thinking! I bet Sirius’ll know what to do!
I hoped he’d get back to me quickly,
But we don’t know where Sirius is . . . he could be in Africa or somewhere, couldn’t he? Hedwig’s not going to manage that journey in a few days.
Yeah, I know,
Come and have a game of Quidditch in the orchard, Harry, Come on — three on three, Bill and Charlie and Fred and George will play. . . . You can try out the Wronski Feint. . . .
Ron, Harry doesn’t want to play Quidditch right now. . . . He’s worried, and he’s tired. . . . We all need to go to bed. . . .
Yeah, I want to play Quidditch, Hang on, I’ll get my Firebolt.
Boys.

Scene: Ron and Hermione looked curiously at Harry. With a meaningful look at both of them he said, “All right if I go and dump my stuff in your room, Ron?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Ron, Ron, you don’t reckon Sirius has been caught, do you?
Nah, it would’ve been in the Daily Prophet, The Ministry would want to show they’d caught someone, wouldn’t they?
Yeah, I suppose. . . .
Look, here’s the stuff Mum got for you in Diagon Alley. And she’s got some gold out of your vault for you . . . and she’s washed all your socks. What is that supposed to be?
Mum, you’ve given me Ginny’s new dress,
What
You’ve got to be kidding, I’m not wearing that, no way. Never.
I’ll go starkers before I put that on,
Well, they’re okay! Why couldn’t I have some like that?
I’m not wearing that, no way. Never.
Why is everything I own rubbish?

Scene: “Did someone say Mad-Eye?” Bill asked. “What’s he been up to now?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Who is Mad-Eye?

Scene: “I might be seeing you all sooner than you think,” said Charlie, grinning, as he hugged Ginny good-bye.

Dialogue.Dialogue: A bit of what?
Thanks for having us to stay, Mrs. Weasley,
Yeah, thanks for everything, Mrs. Weasley,
Mum! What d’you three know that we don’t?

Scene: “Bagman wanted to tell us what’s happening at Hogwarts,” he said grumpily, sitting down next to Harry. “At the World Cup, remember? But my own mother won’t say. Wonder what —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Bagman wanted to tell us what’s happening at Hogwarts, At the World Cup, remember? But my own mother won’t say. Wonder what —
Shh!
So he thinks Durmstrang would have suited him, does he? I wish he had gone, then we wouldn’t have to put up with him.
Durmstrang’s another Wizarding school?
Yes, and it’s got a horrible reputation. According to An Appraisal of Magical Education in Europe, it puts a lot of emphasis on the Dark Arts.
I think I’ve heard of it, Where is it? What country?
Well, nobody knows, do they?
Er — why not?
There’s traditionally been a lot of rivalry between all the magic schools. Durmstrang and Beauxbatons like to conceal their whereabouts so nobody can steal their secrets,
Come off it, Durmstrang’s got to be about the same size as Hogwarts — how are you going to hide a great big castle?
But Hogwarts is hidden,
Just you, then, So go on — how d’you hide a place like Hogwarts?
It’s bewitched, If a Muggle looks at it, all they see is a moldering old ruin with a sign over the entrance saying DANGER, DO NOT ENTER, UNSAFE.
So Durmstrang’ll just look like a ruin to an outsider too?
Maybe, or it might have Muggle-repelling charms on it, like the World Cup stadium. And to keep foreign wizards from finding it, they’ll have made it Unplottable —
Come again?
Well, you can enchant a building so it’s impossible to plot on a map, can’t you?
Er . . . if you say so,
But I think Durmstrang must be somewhere in the far north, Somewhere very cold, because they’ve got fur capes as part of their uniforms.
Ah, think of the possibilities, It would’ve been so easy to push Malfoy off a glacier and make it look like an accident. . . . Shame his mother likes him. . . .
It was, Look at this, Neville. . . .
We saw him right up close, as well,
Don’t remember asking you to join us, Malfoy,
Eat dung, Malfoy!
What are you talking about?
Either explain what you’re on about or go away, Malfoy,
Ron! Reparo!
Him! Get to me! ? As if!
Hi, Hagrid!
Oooh, I wouldn’t fancy crossing the lake in this weather,

Scene: “Not doing nothing!” cackled Peeves, lobbing a water bomb at several fifth-year girls, who screamed and dived into the Great Hall. “Already wet, aren’t they? Little squirts! Wheeeeeeeeee!” And he aimed another bomb at a group of second years who had just arrived.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Says who? Hope they hurry up with the Sorting. I’m starving.
Hi, Colin,
Er — good,
Er — yeah, all right, Brothers and sisters usually go in the same Houses, don’t they?
Oh no, not necessarily, You’d think they’d be together, wouldn’t you? Where’s the new Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher? Maybe they couldn’t get anyone!
Oh hurry up, I could eat a hippogriff.

Scene: “That’s not the song it sang when it Sorted us,” said Harry, clapping along with everyone else.

Dialogue.Dialogue: That’s not the song it sang when it Sorted us,
Sings a different one every year, It’s got to be a pretty boring life, hasn’t it, being a hat? I suppose it spends all year making up the next one.
Oh hurry up,
’Course it is, if you’re dead,
About time,
Aaah, ’at’s be’er,
Why? Wha’ ’appened?
Yeah, we thought Peeves seemed hacked off about something, So what did he do in the kitchens?
There are house-elves here? Here at Hogwarts?
I’ve never seen one!
But they get paid? They get holidays, don’t they? And — and sick leave, and pensions, and everything?
Oh c’mon, ’Er-my-knee, Oops — sorry, ’Arry — You won’t get them sick leave by starving yourself!
Slave labor, That’s what made this dinner. Slave labor.
Treacle tart, Hermione! Spotted dick, look! Chocolate gateau!
Hmph!
Why?

Scene: “May I introduce our new Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher?” said Dumbledore brightly into the silence. “Professor Moody.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Moody? Mad-Eye Moody? The one your dad went to help this morning?
Must be,
Wha’ ’appened? What happened to his face?
Dunno,
Death toll?
Yeah, Yeah, a thousand Galleons . . .
Come on, we’ll be the only ones left here if you don’t move.

Scene: “Who’s this impartial judge who’s going to decide who the champions are?” said Harry.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Who’s this impartial judge who’s going to decide who the champions are?
Dumbledore knows you’re not of age, though,
People have died, though!
What d’you reckon? Be cool to enter, wouldn’t it? But I s’pose they might want someone older. . . . Dunno if we’ve learned enough. . . .
Shut it, you,

Scene: Harry, Ron, and Neville climbed up the last, spiral staircase until they reached their own dormitory, which was situated at the top of the tower. Five four-poster beds with deep crimson hangings stood against the walls, each with its owner’s trunk at the foot. Dean and Seamus were already getting into bed; Seamus had pinned his Ireland rosette to his headboard, and Dean had tacked up a poster of Viktor Krum over his bedside table. His old poster of the West Ham football team was pinned right next to it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Mental, I might go in for it, you know, if Fred and George find out how to . . . the tournament . . . you never know, do you?
“S’pose not. . . .”

Scene: “Today’s not bad . . . outside all morning,” said Ron, who was running his finger down his schedule. “Herbology with the Hufflepuffs and Care of Magical Creatures . . . damn it, we’re still with the Slytherins. . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Today’s not bad . . . outside all morning, Herbology with the Hufflepuffs and Care of Magical Creatures . . . damn it, we’re still with the Slytherins. . . .
Double Divination this afternoon,
You should have given it up like me, shouldn’t you? Then you’d be doing something sensible like Arithmancy.
You’re eating again, I notice,
I’ve decided there are better ways of making a stand about elf rights,
Yeah . . . and you were hungry,

Scene: “Good day,” said the misty voice of Professor Trelawney right behind Harry, making him jump.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry!
What?
Born under — what, sorry?
No, I was born in July.

Scene: “I’ve got two Neptunes here,” said Harry after a while, frowning down at his piece of parchment, “that can’t be right, can it?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I’ve got two Neptunes here, that can’t be right, can it?
Aaaaah, when two Neptunes appear in the sky, it is a sure sign that a midget in glasses is being born, Harry. . . .
Can I have a look at Uranus too, Lavender?
Miserable old bat, That’ll take all weekend, that will. . . .
Lots of homework? Professor Vector didn’t give us any at all!
Well, bully for Professor Vector,

Scene: “Weasley! Hey, Weasley!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What?
Get stuffed, Malfoy, C’mon, Ron. . . .
You know your mother, Malfoy? that expression she’s got, like she’s got dung under her nose? Has she always looked like that, or was it just because you were with her?
Keep your fat mouth shut, then,
No, missed.
The what?

Scene: “Don’t talk to me,” Ron said quietly to Harry and Hermione as they sat down at the Gryffindor table a few minutes later, surrounded by excited talk on all sides about what had just happened.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Don’t talk to me,
The what?
Because I want to fix that in my memory forever, Hermione! you’re ruining the best moment of my life!
Don’t tell me you’re going back to the library this evening?
Got to, Loads to do.
But you told us Professor Vector —
It’s not schoolwork,
What was it like?
The what?
Doing what?
We haven’t got him till Thursday!

Scene: The next two days passed without great incident, unless you counted Neville melting his sixth cauldron in Potions. Professor Snape, who seemed to have attained new levels of vindictiveness over the summer, gave Neville detention, and Neville returned from it in a state of nervous collapse, having been made to disembowel a barrel full of horned toads.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You know why Snape’s in such a foul mood, don’t you?
Yeah, Moody. I reckon Snape’s a bit scared of him, you know,
Imagine if Moody turned Snape into a horned toad, and bounced him all around his dungeon. . . .
Been in the —
Library. C’mon, quick, or we won’t get decent seats.
What, aren’t you staying?
Er, my dad told me about one. . . . Is it called the Imperius Curse, or something?
Stop it!
Avada Kedavra,

Scene: “Hurry up,” she said tensely to Harry and Ron.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hurry up,
Not the ruddy library again?
No, Neville. Neville?
Neville, are you all right?
Yes,
What was that about?

Scene: “Wouldn’t Moody and Dumbledore be in trouble with the Ministry if they knew we’d seen the curses?” Harry asked as they approached the Fat Lady.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Wouldn’t Moody and Dumbledore be in trouble with the Ministry if they knew we’d seen the curses?
Ah, Attacks first and asks questions later — look at his dustbins. Balderdash.
Shall we get our Divination stuff, then?
I s’pose,

Scene: “Shall we get our Divination stuff, then?” said Harry.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Neville?

Scene: “I haven’t got a clue what this lot’s supposed to mean,” he said, staring down at a long list of calculations.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I haven’t got a clue what this lot’s supposed to mean,
You know, I think it’s back to the old Divination standby.
What — make it up?
Yeah, Next Monday, I am likely to develop a cough, owing to the unlucky conjunction of Mars and Jupiter. You know her — just put in loads of misery, she’ll lap it up.
Right, Okay . . . on Monday, I will be in danger of — er — burns.
Right then, we’re seeing the skrewts again on Monday. Okay, Tuesday, I’ll . . . erm . . .
Lose a treasured possession,
Good one, Because of . . . erm . .Mercury. Why don’t you get stabbed in the back by someone you thought was a friend?
Yeah . . . cool . . . because . . . Venus is in the twelfth house. And on Wednesday, I think I’ll come off worst in a fight.
Ah, Okay, I’ll lose a bet.
Yeah, you’ll be betting I’ll win my fight. . . .

Scene: “Hedwig!” he shouted, and he launched himself out of his chair and across the room to pull open the window.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hedwig! About time!
She’s got an answer!
What does it say? He’s flying north? He’s coming back?
Harry — Harry — what’s up?
I shouldn’t’ve told him!
What are you on about?

It’s made him think he’s got to come back! Coming back, because he thinks I’m in trouble! And there’s nothing wrong with me! And I haven’t got anything for you, you’ll have to go up to the Owlery if you want food.
Harry
I’m going to bed, See you in the morning.

Scene: It took him a while to persuade her to wake up and then to look at him, as she kept shuffling around on her perch, showing him her tail. She was evidently still furious about his lack of gratitude the previous night. In the end, it was Harry suggesting she might be too tired, and that perhaps he would ask Ron to borrow Pigwidgeon, that made her stick out her leg and allow him to tie the letter to it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry You didn’t imagine your scar hurting and you know it.
So what? He’s not going back to Azkaban because of me.
Drop it,

Scene: “But — but you said it’s illegal, Professor,” said Hermione uncertainly as Moody cleared away the desks with a sweep of his wand, leaving a large clear space in the middle of the room. “You said — to use it against another human was —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: But — but you said it’s illegal, Professor,
The way he talks, you’d think we were all going to be attacked any second.

Yeah, I know, Talk about paranoid . . . No wonder they were glad to get shot of him at the Ministry. Did you hear him telling Seamus what he did to that witch who shouted ‘Boo’ behind him on April Fools’ Day? And when are we supposed to read up on resisting the Imperius Curse with everything else we’ve got to do?

Scene: “Brilliant!” said Harry. “It’s Potions last thing on Friday! Snape won’t have time to poison us all!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Brilliant! It’s Potions last thing on Friday! Snape won’t have time to poison us all!
Cedric?
Diggory, He must be entering the tournament.
That idiot, Hogwarts champion?
He’s not an idiot. You just don’t like him because he beat Gryffindor at Quidditch, I’ve heard he’s a really good student — and he’s a prefect.
You only like him because he’s handsome,
Excuse me, I don’t like people just because they’re handsome!
Lockhart!

Scene: “It’s a bummer, all right,” George was saying gloomily to Fred. “But if he won’t talk to us in person, we’ll have to send him the letter after all. Or we’ll stuff it into his hand. He can’t avoid us forever.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Who’s avoiding you?
What’s a bummer?
TRIWIZARD TOURNAMENT Thought any more about trying to enter?
Harry You know, I bet we could do them, Harry. We’ve done dangerous stuff before. . . .
Who are the judges?
