Well, the Heads of the participating schools are always on the panel, because all three of them were injured during the Tournament of 1792, when a cockatrice the champions were supposed to be catching went on the rampage. It’s all in Hogwarts: A History. Though, of course, that book’s not entirely reliable. A Revised History of Hogwarts would be a more accurate title. Or A Highly Biased and Selective History of Hogwarts, Which Glosses Over the Nastier Aspects of the School.
What are you on about?
House-elves! Not once, in over a thousand pages, does Hogwarts: A History mention that we are all colluding in the oppression of a hundred slaves!
No, of course not,
That’s because they’re uneducated and brainwashed!
Why d’you have to keep changing owls?
Hedwig’ll attract too much attention, She stands out. A snowy owl that keeps returning to wherever he’s hiding . . . I mean, they’re not native birds, are they?
Thanks, Hedwig,

Scene: “Weasley, straighten your hat,” Professor McGonagall snapped at Ron. “Miss Patil, take that ridiculous thing out of your hair.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Nearly six, How d’you reckon they’re coming? The train?
I doubt it,
How, then? Broomsticks?
I don’t think so . . . not from that far away. . . .
A Portkey? Or they could Apparate — maybe you’re allowed to do it under seventeen wherever they come from?
You can’t Apparate inside the Hogwarts grounds, how often do I have to tell you?

Scene: “My dear Madame Maxime,” he said. “Welcome to Hogwarts.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Skrewts,
Well, if they’re any bigger than this lot, even Hagrid won’t be able to handle them, That’s if he hasn’t been attacked by his skrewts. Wonder what’s up with them?
Maybe they’ve escaped,
Oh don’t say that, Imagine that lot loose on the grounds. . . .

Scene: “For heaven’s sake, Ron, he’s only a Quidditch player,” said Hermione.

Dialogue.Dialogue: For heaven’s sake, Ron, he’s only a Quidditch player,
Only a Quidditch player? Hermione — he’s one of the best Seekers in the world! I had no idea he was still at school!
Really,
I’m getting his autograph if I can, You haven’t got a quill, have you, Harry?
Nope, they’re upstairs in my bag,

Scene: “The moment has come,” said Dumbledore, smiling around at the sea of upturned faces. “The Triwizard Tournament is about to start. I would like to say a few words of explanation before we bring in the casket —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: The what?

Scene: “Anyone put their name in yet?” Ron asked a third-year girl eagerly.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Anyone put their name in yet?
All the Durmstrang lot, But I haven’t seen anyone from Hogwarts yet.
Me, I would’ve if it had been me . . . wouldn’t have wanted everyone watching. What if the goblet just gobbed you right back out again?
What?
I’m not sure this is going to work, you know, I’m sure Dumbledore will have thought of this.

Scene: “There’s a rumor going around that Warrington got up early and put his name in,” Dean told Harry. “That big bloke from Slytherin who looks like a sloth.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Listen!
You’re kidding!
Are you seventeen, then?
’Course she is, can’t see a beard, can you?
Well, I’m glad someone from Gryffindor’s entering, I really hope you get it, Angelina!
What’re we going to do today, then?
We haven’t been down to visit Hagrid yet,
Okay, just as long as he doesn’t ask us to donate a few fingers to the skrewts.
I’ve just realized — I haven’t asked Hagrid to join S.P. E.W. yet! Wait for me, will you, while I nip upstairs and get the badges?
What is it with her?
Hey, Ron, It’s your friend . . .

Scene: Ron and Harry discuss what happens to students not chosen for the tournament as the Beauxbatons students submit their names to the Goblet of Fire.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What d’you reckon’ll happen to the ones who aren’t chosen? Reckon they’ll go back to school, or hang around to watch the tournament?
Dunno, Hang around, I suppose. . . . Madame Maxime’s staying to judge, isn’t she?
Where are they sleeping, then?
Oh good, hurry up

Session-366.Scene: “You wait,” he said, grinning. “You jus’ wait. Yer going ter see some stuff yeh’ve never seen before. Firs’ task . . . ah, but I’m not supposed ter say.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Go on, Hagrid!
But Harry set Dobby free, and he was over the moon about it! And we heard he’s asking for wages now!

Session-367.Scene: “I’ll come with yeh,” said Hagrid, putting away his darning. “Jus’ give us a sec.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hagrid, what’s that?
Is that aftershave?
Eau de cologne? Hagrid?
And what’s with the hair and the suit?
Look!
He’s going up to the castle with her! I thought he was waiting for us!
He fancies her! Well, if they end up having children, they’ll be setting a world record — bet any baby of theirs would weigh about a ton.

Session-368.Scene: “Hope it’s Angelina,” said Fred as Harry, Ron, and Hermione sat down.

Dialogue.Dialogue: So do I! Well, we’ll soon know!
No surprises there!
It’s her, Ron!
Oh look, they’re all disappointed,
No!

Session-369.Scene: “What is it?” she said. “Do zey want us back in ze Hall?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: You know I didn’t.
You know I didn’t.

Session-370.Scene: “So,” said Cedric, with a slight smile. “We’re playing against each other again!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I s’pose, Ah . . . okay,

Session-371.Scene: “Well, well, well,” said the Fat Lady, “Violet’s just told me everything. Who’s just been chosen as school champion, then?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Balderdash,

Session-372.Scene: “You should’ve told us you’d entered!” bellowed Fred; he looked half annoyed, half deeply impressed.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I didn’t,
I’m not hungry, I had enough at the feast — I didn’t, I don’t know how it happened. I’m tired! No, seriously, George — I’m going to bed —

Session-373.Scene: “Hello,” she said, holding up a stack of toast, which she was carrying in a napkin. “I brought you this. . . . Want to go for a walk?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hello, I brought you this. . . . Want to go for a walk?
Good idea,

Well, of course I knew you hadn’t entered yourself, The look on your face when Dumbledore read out your name! But the question is, who did put it in? Because Moody’s right, Harry . . . I don’t think any student could have done it . . . they’d never be able to fool the goblet, or get over Dumbledore’s —
Have you seen Ron?
Erm . . . yes . . . he was at breakfast,
Does he still think I entered myself?
Well . . . no, I don’t think so . . . not really,
What’s that supposed to mean, ‘not really’?
Oh Harry, isn’t it obvious? He’s jealous!
Jealous? Jealous of what? He wants to make a prat of himself in front of the whole school, does he?

Look, it’s always you who gets all the attention, you know it is. I know it’s not your fault, I know you don’t ask for it . . . but — well — you know, Ron’s got all those brothers to compete against at home, and you’re his best friend, and you’re really famous — he’s always shunted to one side whenever people see you, and he puts up with it, and he never mentions it, but I suppose this is just one time too many. . . .
Great, Tell him from me he’s welcome to it. . . . People gawping at my forehead everywhere I go. . . .

I’m not telling him anything, Tell him yourself. It’s the only way to sort this out. That’s not funny, That’s not funny at all. Harry, I’ve been thinking — you know what we’ve got to do, don’t you? Straight away, the moment we get back to the castle?
Yeah, give Ron a good kick up the —

Write to Sirius. You’ve got to tell him what’s happened. He asked you to keep him posted on everything that’s going on at Hogwarts. . . . It’s almost as if he expected something like this to happen. I brought some parchment and a quill out with me —
Come off it, He came back to the country just because my scar twinged. He’ll probably come bursting right into the castle if I tell him someone’s entered me in the Triwizard Tournament — How?

Harry, this isn’t going to be kept quiet, This tournament’s famous, and you’re famous. I’ll be really surprised if there isn’t anything in the Daily Prophet about you competing. . . . You’re already in half the books about You-Know-Who, you know . . . and Sirius would rather hear it from you, I know he would.
Okay, okay, I’ll write to him, Whose owl am I going to use? He told me not to use Hedwig again.
Ask Ron if you can borrow —
I’m not asking Ron for anything,
Well, borrow one of the school owls, then, anyone can use them,

Session-374.Scene: He could understand the Hufflepuffs’ attitude, even if he didn’t like it; they had their own champion to support. He expected nothing less than vicious insults from the Slytherins — he was highly unpopular there and always had been, because he had helped Gryffindor beat them so often, both at Quidditch and in the Inter-House Championship. But he had hoped the Ravenclaws might have found it in their hearts to support him as much as Cedric. He was wrong, however. Most Ravenclaws seemed to think that he had been desperate to earn himself a bit more fame by tricking the goblet into accepting his name.

Dialogue.Dialogue: It’s really not that difficult, Harry,
Wonder why that was, Still — never mind, eh? Double Potions to look forward to this afternoon. . . .
ignore them, ignore them,

Session-375.Scene: “Like them, Potter?” said Malfoy loudly as Harry approached. “And this isn’t all they do — look!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oh very funny, really witty.
Harry!
Furnunculus!
Hermione!

Session-376.Scene: “And what is all this noise about?” said a soft, deadly voice.

Dialogue.Dialogue: We attacked each other at the same time!
Hermione! Look!

Session-377.Scene: “It’s amazing, isn’t it, Harry?” said Colin, starting to speak the moment Harry had closed the dungeon door behind him. “Isn’t it, though? You being champion?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah, really amazing, What do they want photos for, Colin?
Great, Exactly what I need. More publicity.

Session-378.Scene: You told me to keep you posted on what’s happening at Hogwarts, so here goes — I don’t know if you’ve heard, but the Triwizard Tournament’s happening this year and on Saturday night I got picked as a fourth champion. I don’t know who put my name in the Goblet of Fire, because I didn’t. The other Hogwarts champion is Cedric Diggory, from Hufflepuff.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Wand weighing?
Er —

Session-379.Scene: “Maybe not that small, Ludo,” said Rita Skeeter, her eyes on Harry.

Dialogue.Dialogue: A what?
Er —
I didn’t, I don’t know how my name got into the Goblet of Fire. I didn’t put it in there.
But I didn’t enter,
I haven’t really thought . . . yeah, nervous, I suppose,
Well . . . they say it’s going to be a lot safer this year,
Er,
I didn’t enter,
No,
I have NOT got tears in my eyes!

Session-380.Scene: “You’ve had an owl,” said Ron brusquely the moment he walked in. He was pointing at Harry’s pillow. The school barn owl was waiting for him there.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You’ve had an owl,
Oh — right,
And we’ve got to do our detentions tomorrow night, Snape’s dungeon,

Session-381.Scene: From the moment the article had appeared, Harry had had to endure people — Slytherins, mainly — quoting it at him as he passed and making sneering comments.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah, that’s right! I’ve just been crying my eyes out over my dead mum, and I’m just off to do a bit more. . . .
Oh — right — sorry,
Ignore it, Just ignore it, Harry.
I didn’t start this, It’s his problem.
You miss him!
Miss him? I don’t miss him. . . . Wronski Feint,”

Session-382.Scene: “What about Ron, though?” he said. “Don’t you want to go with him?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What about Ron, though? Don’t you want to go with him?
. . . well I thought we might meet up with him in the Three Broomsticks. . . .
No,
Oh Harry, this is so stupid —
I’ll come, but I’m not meeting Ron, and I’m wearing my Invisibility Cloak.
Oh all right then . . . but I hate talking to you in that Cloak, I never know if I’m looking at you or not.

Session-383.Scene: “I look like such an idiot, sitting here on my own,” she muttered. “Lucky I brought something to do.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I look like such an idiot, sitting here on my own, Lucky I brought something to do. You know, maybe I should try and get some of the villagers involved in S.P. E.W.,
Yeah, right, Hermione, when are you going to give up on this spew stuff?
When house-elves have decent wages and working conditions! You know, I’m starting to think it’s time for more direct action. I wonder how you get into the school kitchens?
No idea, ask Fred and George,
Look, it’s Hagrid!
Hello,
Can your eye — I mean, can you — ?
Why does Hagrid want me to meet him at midnight?
Does he? I wonder what he’s up to? I don’t know whether you should go, Harry. . . . It might make you late for Sirius.

Session-385.Scene: At half past eleven that evening, Harry, who had pretended to go up to bed early, pulled the Invisibility Cloak back over himself and crept back downstairs through the common room. Quite a few people were still in there. The Creevey brothers had managed to get hold of a stack of Support Cedric Diggory! badges and were trying to bewitch them to make them say Support Harry Potter! instead. So far, however, all they had managed to do was get the badges stuck on POTTER STINKS. Harry crept past them to the portrait hole and waited for a minute or so, keeping an eye on his watch. Then Hermione opened the Fat Lady for him from outside as they had planned. He slipped past her with a whispered “Thanks!” and set off through the castle.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Thanks!

Session-386.Scene: The grounds were very dark. Harry walked down the lawn toward the lights shining in Hagrid’s cabin. The inside of the enormous Beauxbatons carriage was also lit up; Harry could hear Madame Maxime talking inside it as he knocked on Hagrid’s front door.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah, What’s up?
What’re you showing me?
... I Hagrid, what — ?

Session-387.Scene: “Balderdash!” he gasped at the Fat Lady, who was snoozing in her frame in front of the portrait hole.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Balderdash!
Sirius — how’re you doing?
I’m — . . . and now Hagrid’s just shown me what’s coming in the first task, and it’s dragons, Sirius, and I’m a goner,
What?
Yes — he — what?
Karkaroff got released? Why did they release him?
Okay, But . . . are you saying Karkaroff put my name in the goblet? Because if he did, he’s a really good actor. He seemed furious about it. He wanted to stop me from competing.
— you and the rest of the world,
What? Karkaroff’s trying to kill me? But — why?
Yeah,
So . . . so Voldemort could have found out about the tournament? Is that what you mean? You think Karkaroff might be here on his orders?
Looks like a really good plan from where I’m standing, They’ll just have to stand back and let the dragons do their stuff.
Yeah,
Go! Go! There’s someone coming!

Session-388.Scene: “Who were you talking to?” he said.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Who were you talking to?
What’s that got to do with you? What are you doing down here at this time of night? Does he?
Sorry about that, Should’ve realized you didn’t want to be disturbed. I’ll let you get on with practicing for your next interview in peace.
There you go, Something for you to wear on Tuesday. You might even have a scar now, if you’re lucky. . . . That’s what you want, isn’t it?

Session-389.Scene: “Let’s just try and keep you alive until Tuesday evening,” she said desperately, “and then we can worry about Karkaroff.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Let’s just try and keep you alive until Tuesday evening, and then we can worry about Karkaroff. ‘Talon-clipping by charms . . . treating scale-rot . . .’ This is no good, this is for nutters like Hagrid who want to keep them healthy. . . . ‘Dragons are extremely difficult to slay, owing to the ancient magic that imbues their thick hides, which none but the most powerful spells can penetrate . . .’ But Sirius said a simple one would do it. . . .
Let’s try some simple spellbooks, then,

Well, there are Switching Spells . . . but what’s the point of Switching it? Unless you swapped its fangs for wine-gums or something that would make it less dangerous. . . . The trouble is, like that book said, not much is going to get through a dragon’s hide. . . . I’d say Transfigure it, but something that big, you really haven’t got a hope, I doubt even Professor McGonagall . . . unless you’re supposed to put the spell on yourself? Maybe to give yourself extra powers? But they’re not simple spells, I mean, we haven’t done any of those in class, I only know about them because I’ve been doing O. W.L. practice papers. . . .
Hermione, will you shut up for a bit, please? I’m trying to concentrate.
Oh no, he’s back again, why can’t he read on his stupid ship? Come on, Harry, we’ll go back to the common room . . . his fan club’ll be here in a moment, twittering away. . . .

Session-390.Scene: Somehow, the knowledge that he would rather be here and facing a dragon than back on Privet Drive with Dudley was good to know; it made him feel slightly calmer. He finished his bacon with difficulty (his throat wasn’t working too well), and as he and Hermione got up, he saw Cedric Diggory leaving the Hufflepuff table.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hermione, Go on, I’ll catch you up.
Harry, you’ll be late, the bell’s about to ring —
I’ll catch you up, okay?
Diffindo!
Cedric, the first task is dragons.
Dragons, They’ve got four, one for each of us, and we’ve got to get past them.
Dead sure, I’ve seen them.
Never mind, But I’m not the only one who knows. Fleur and Krum will know by now — Maxime and Karkaroff both saw the dragons too.
It’s just . . . fair, isn’t it? We all know now . . . we’re on an even footing, aren’t we?

Session-392.Scene: “Come with me, Potter,” he growled. “Diggory, off you go.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Er — Professor, I’m supposed to be in Herbology —

Session-393.Scene: Harry looked at him blankly. What did he need?

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hermione, Hermione — I need you to help me.
What d’you think I’ve been trying to do, Harry?
Hermione,
Concentrate, Harry, concentrate. . . .

What d’you think I’m trying to do? A great big dragon keeps popping up in my head for some reason. . . . Okay, try again. . . . Well, that’s good, just as long as it’s not drawn-out. I don’t want to suffer.

Session-394.Scene: “That’s better, Harry, that’s loads better,” Hermione said, looking exhausted but very pleased.

Dialogue.Dialogue: That’s better, Harry, that’s loads better,
Well, now we know what to do next time I can’t manage a spell, threaten me with a dragon. Right . . . Accio Dictionary!
Harry, I really think you’ve got it!
Just as long as it works tomorrow, The Firebolt’s going to be much farther away than the stuff in here, it’s going to be in the castle, and I’m going to be out there on the grounds. . . .
It’s all right, Just as long as you’re concentrating really, really hard on it, it’ll come. Harry, we’d better get some sleep . . . you’re going to need it.

Session-395.Scene: “Potter, the champions have to come down onto the grounds now. . . . You have to get ready for your first task.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Okay,
Good luck, Harry, You’ll be fine!
Yeah,

Session-396.Scene: “Now, don’t panic,” she said, “just keep a cool head. . . . We’ve got wizards standing by to control the situation if it gets out of hand. . . . The main thing is just to do your best, and nobody will think any the worse of you. . . . Are you all right?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yes, Yes, I’m fine.
Thanks,

Session-397.Scene: Harry felt oddly separate from everyone around him, whether they were wishing him good luck or hissing “We’ll have a box of tissues ready, Potter” as he passed. It was a state of nervousness so advanced that he wondered whether he mightn’t just lose his head when they tried to lead him out to his dragon, and start trying to curse everyone in sight. Time was behaving in a more peculiar fashion than ever, rushing past in great dollops, so that one moment he seemed to be sitting down in his first lesson, History of Magic, and the next, walking into lunch . . . and then (where had the morning gone? the last of the dragon-free hours?), Professor McGonagall was hurrying over to him in the Great Hall. Lots of people were watching.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Er . . . yes,
What? I — no, nothing.
Thanks, no — I — I know what I’m going to do, thanks.
No, I’m fine, I’ve got a plan worked out, I —

Session-398.Scene: It was worse than Harry could ever have imagined, sitting there and listening. The crowd screamed . . . yelled . . . gasped like a single many-headed entity, as Cedric did whatever he was doing to get past the Swedish Short-Snout. Krum was still staring at the ground. Fleur had now taken to retracing Cedric’s steps, around and around the tent. And Bagman’s commentary made everything much, much worse. . . . Horrible pictures formed in Harry’s mind as he heard: “Oooh, narrow miss there, very narrow” . . . “He’s taking risks, this one!” . . . “Clever move — pity it didn’t work!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Accio Firebolt! Okay, diversionary tactics . . . let’s go. . . .
Come on, come on, come and get me . . . up you get now . . .

Session-399.Scene: “That was excellent, Potter!” cried Professor McGonagall as he got off the Firebolt — which from her was extravagant praise. He noticed that her hand shook as she pointed at his shoulder. “You’ll need to see Madam Pomfrey before the judges give out your score. . . . Over there, she’s had to mop up Diggory already. . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Thanks, Hagrid,

Session-400.Scene: “Thanks, Hagrid,” said Harry loudly, so that Hagrid wouldn’t blunder on and reveal that he had shown Harry the dragons beforehand.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry, you were brilliant! You were amazing! You really were! Harry,
Harry, whoever put your name in that goblet — I — I reckon they’re trying to do you in!
Caught on, have you? Took you long enough. It’s all right, Forget it. Forget it,
No,
Forget it. Forget it, There’s nothing to cry about!
You two are so stupid!
Harry, Harry, c’mon, they’ll be putting up your scores. . . .

Session-401.Scene: “You were the best, you know, no competition. Cedric did this weird thing where he Transfigured a rock on the ground . . . turned it into a dog . . . he was trying to make the dragon go for the dog instead of him. Well, it was a pretty cool bit of Transfiguration, and it sort of worked, because he did get the egg, but he got burned as well — the dragon changed its mind halfway through and decided it would rather have him than the Labrador; he only just got away. And that Fleur girl tried this sort of charm, I think she was trying to put it into a trance — well, that kind of worked too, it went all sleepy, but then it snored, and this great jet of flame shot out, and her skirt caught fire — she put it out with a bit of water out of her wand. And Krum — you won’t believe this, but he didn’t even think of flying! He was probably the best after you, though. Hit it with some sort of spell right in the eye. Only thing is, it went trampling around in agony and squashed half the real eggs — they took marks off for that, he wasn’t supposed to do any damage to them.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: You were the best, you know, no competition. Cedric did this weird thing where he Transfigured a rock on the ground . . . turned it into a dog . . . he was trying to make the dragon go for the dog instead of him. Well, it was a pretty cool bit of Transfiguration, and it sort of worked, because he did get the egg, but he got burned as well — the dragon changed its mind halfway through and decided it would rather have him than the Labrador; he only just got away. And that Fleur girl tried this sort of charm, I think she was trying to put it into a trance — well, that kind of worked too, it went all sleepy, but then it snored, and this great jet of flame shot out, and her skirt caught fire — she put it out with a bit of water out of her wand. And Krum — you won’t believe this, but he didn’t even think of flying! He was probably the best after you, though. Hit it with some sort of spell right in the eye. Only thing is, it went trampling around in agony and squashed half the real eggs — they took marks off for that, he wasn’t supposed to do any damage to them. It’s marks out of ten from each one, Not bad! I suppose she took marks off for your shoulder. . . . Looking good!
Ten? But . . . I got hurt. . . . What’s he playing at?
Harry, What? Four? You lousy, biased scumbag, you gave Krum ten!
And you,
Yeah, you can have a word, Good-bye.

Session-403.Scene: “Blimey, this is heavy,” said Lee Jordan, picking up the golden egg, which Harry had left on a table, and weighing it in his hands. “Open it, Harry, go on! Let’s just see what’s inside it!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: He’s supposed to work out the clue on his own, It’s in the tournament rules. . . .
I was supposed to work out how to get past the dragon on my own too,
Yeah, go on, Harry, open it!
Did you get all this from the kitchens, Fred?
How do you get in there?
Nothing,

Session-404.Scene: “Who’re you?” Hagrid asked Rita Skeeter as he slipped a loop of rope around the skrewt’s sting and tightened it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: They’re very interesting, aren’t they? Aren’t they, Harry?
What?  Oh yeah . . . ouch . . . interesting,
Yes,
She’ll twist everything he says,
Just as long as he didn’t import those skrewts illegally or anything,
Blast-Ended Skrewts, Worst that can happen is Hagrid’ll have to get rid of the skrewts. Sorry . . . did I say worst? I meant best.

Session-405.Scene: “An ugly old bat in outsize specs?” Ron muttered under his breath.

Dialogue.Dialogue: An ugly old bat in outsize specs?
It’d be a bit more impressive if she hadn’t done it about eighty times before, But if I’d dropped dead every time she’s told me I’m going to, I’d be a medical miracle.

Session-406.Scene: “Wonder where she’s got to?” Ron said as he and Harry went back to Gryffindor Tower.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Wonder where she’s got to?
Dunno . . . balderdash.
What’s the matter?
Okay,
Yeah, thanks!
Hermione, where are we going?
You’ll see, you’ll see in a minute!
D-Dobby?
What?
Winky? She’s here too?
Hello, Winky,
Oh dear, Winky, don’t cry, please don’t . . .
Okay,
Good service!
How long have you been here, Dobby?
Good for you, Dobby!
That’s not very much!
And how much is Professor Dumbledore paying you, Winky?
Ashamed? But — Winky, come on! It’s Mr. Crouch who should be ashamed, not you! You didn’t do anything wrong, he was really horrible to you —
Can’t house-elves speak their minds about their masters, then?
But you can say what you like about the Malfoys now?
You just need a bit of practice,
Winky, I’m quite sure Mr. Crouch is getting along perfectly well without you. We’ve seen him, you know —
Yes, he and Mr. Bagman are judges in the Triwizard Tournament.
Bagman — bad?

Tell you what, Dobby, I’ll give you the one my mum knits me this Christmas, I always get one from her. You don’t mind maroon, do you? We might have to shrink it a bit to fit you, but it’ll go well with your tea cozy.
Thanks a lot! See you, Dobby! ’Course you can,
You know what? All these years I’ve been really impressed with Fred and George, nicking food from the kitchens — well, it’s not exactly difficult, is it? They can’t wait to give it away!

I think this is the best thing that could have happened to those elves, you know, Dobby coming to work here, I mean. The other elves will see how happy he is, being free, and slowly it’ll dawn on them that they want that too!
Let’s hope they don’t look too closely at Winky,
Oh she’ll cheer up, Once the shock’s worn off, and she’s got used to Hogwarts, she’ll see how much better off she is without that Crouch man.
She seems to love him,
Doesn’t think much of Bagman, though, does she? Wonder what Crouch says at home about him?
Probably says he’s not a very good Head of Department, and let’s face it . . . he’s got a point, hasn’t he?
I’d still rather work for him than old Crouch, At least Bagman’s got a sense of humor.
Don’t let Percy hear you saying that,
Yeah, well, Percy wouldn’t want to work for anyone with a sense of humor, would he? Percy wouldn’t recognize a joke if it danced naked in front of him wearing Dobby’s tea cozy.

Session-408.Scene: “She was quite good-looking,” said Ron fairly, after he’d stopped laughing.

Dialogue.Dialogue: She was quite good-looking,
She was a foot taller than me, Imagine what I’d look like trying to dance with her.

Session-409.Scene: “She didn’ seem very int’rested in magical creatures, ter tell yeh the truth,” Hagrid said, when Harry, Ron, and Hermione asked him how his interview with Rita Skeeter had gone during the last Care of Magical Creatures lesson of the term. To their very great relief, Hagrid had given up on direct contact with the skrewts now, and they were merely sheltering behind his cabin today, sitting at a trestle table and preparing a fresh selection of food with which to tempt the skrewts.

Dialogue.Dialogue: ’Course she did, She can’t keep writing about what a tragic little hero I am, it’ll get boring.
She wants a new angle, Hagrid, You were supposed to say Harry’s a mad delinquent!
She should’ve interviewed Snape, He’d give her the goods on me any day. ‘Potter has been crossing lines ever since he first arrived at this school. . . .’
Cheers, Hagrid,
You coming to this ball thing on Christmas Day, Hagrid?
No one, yet,

Session-410.Scene: “Evil, he is,” Ron said bitterly that night in the Gryffindor common room. “Springing a test on us on the last day. Ruining the last bit of term with a whole load of studying.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Evil, he is, Springing a test on us on the last day. Ruining the last bit of term with a whole load of studying.
Mmm . . . you’re not exactly straining yourself, though, are you?
It’s Christmas, Hermione,
I’d have thought you’d be doing something constructive, Harry, even if you don’t want to learn your antidotes!
Like what?
That egg!
Come on, Hermione, I’ve got till February the twenty-fourth,
But it might take weeks to work it out! You’re going to look a real idiot if everyone else knows what the next task is and you don’t!
Leave him alone, Hermione, he’s earned a bit of a break,

Session-411.Scene: The Hogwarts staff, demonstrating a continued desire to impress the visitors from Beauxbatons and Durmstrang, seemed determined to show the castle at its best this Christmas. When the decorations went up, Harry noticed that they were the most stunning he had yet seen inside the school. Everlasting icicles had been attached to the banisters of the marble staircase; the usual twelve Christmas trees in the Great Hall were bedecked with everything from luminous holly berries to real, hooting, golden owls, and the suits of armor had all been bewitched to sing carols whenever anyone passed them. It was quite something to hear “O Come, All Ye Faithful” sung by an empty helmet that only knew half the words. Several times, Filch the caretaker had to extract Peeves from inside the armor, where he had taken to hiding, filling in the gaps in the songs with lyrics of his own invention, all of which were very rude.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I suppose there’s always Moaning Myrtle,
Harry — we’ve just got to grit our teeth and do it, When we get back to the common room tonight, we’ll both have partners — agreed?
All right, then, I’ll meet you at dinner,

Session-412.Scene: “Er — Cho? Could I have a word with you?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Er — Cho? Could I have a word with you?
Er, Wangoballwime?
D’you — d’you want to go to the ball with me?
Oh, Oh okay, no problem. That’s okay,
no problem. That’s okay,
Yeah,
Who’re you going with?
All right, then,

Session-413.Scene: “Fairy lights,” he said dully to the Fat Lady — the password had been changed the previous day.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Fairy lights,

Session-414.Scene: “What’s up, Ron?” said Harry, joining them.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What’s up, Ron?
Why did I do it? I don’t know what made me do it!
Like what?
You what?

I don’t know what made me do it! What was I playing at? There were people — all around — I’ve gone mad — everyone watching! I was just walking past her in the entrance hall — she was standing there talking to Diggory — and it sort of came over me — and I asked her! She looked at me like I was a sea slug or something. Didn’t even answer. And then — I dunno — I just sort of came to my senses and ran for it.

She’s part veela, You were right — her grandmother was one. It wasn’t your fault, I bet you just walked past when she was turning on the old charm for Diggory and got a blast of it — but she was wasting her time. He’s going with Cho Chang. I asked her to go with me just now, and she told me.
This is mad, We’re the only ones left who haven’t got anyone — well, except Neville. Hey — guess who he asked?
Like what?
he said, He told me after Potions! Ha! As if! She just didn’t want to go with Neville . . . I mean, who would?
Why weren’t you two at dinner?
Thanks a bunch, Ginny,
All the good-looking ones taken, Ron? Eloise Midgen starting to look quite pretty now, is she? Well, I’m sure you’ll find someone somewhere who’ll have you. Oh well spotted,
Well — you can come with one of us!
No, I can’t,
Oh come on, we need partners, we’re going to look really stupid if we haven’t got any, everyone else has . . .
I can’t come with you, because I’m already going with someone.
No, you’re not! You just said that to get rid of Neville!
Oh did I? Just because it’s taken you three years to notice, Ron, doesn’t mean no one else has spotted I’m a girl!
Okay, okay, we know you’re a girl, That do? Will you come now? She’s lying,
Who is it then?
Right, this is getting stupid. Ginny, you can go with Harry, and I’ll just —
What’s got into them?

Session-415.Scene: “Wait here,” he said to Ron, and he stood up, walked straight up to Parvati, and said, “Parvati? Will you go to the ball with me?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Wait here, Parvati? Will you go to the ball with me?
Thanks, Lavender — will you go with Ron?
Can’t you think of anyone who’d go with Ron? She’s going with someone else.
No idea, So what about Ron?
Yeah, that would be great, Let me know, will you?

Session-416.Scene: Congratulations on getting past the Horntail. Whoever put your name in that goblet shouldn’t be feeling too happy right now! I was going to suggest a Conjunctivitis Curse, as a dragon’s eyes are its weakest point — “That’s what Krum did!” Hermione whispered — but your way was better, I’m impressed.

Dialogue.Dialogue: That’s what Krum did! But he’s right, Harry, you have still got two tasks to do. You really ought to have a look at that egg, you know, and start working out what it means. . . .
Hermione, Want a game of chess, Harry?
Yeah, okay, Come on, how’m I supposed to concentrate with all this noise going on? I won’t even be able to hear the egg over this lot.
Oh I suppose not,

Session-417.Scene: “Dobby!” Harry yelled, scrambling away from the elf so fast he almost fell out of bed. “Don’t do that!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Dobby! Don’t do that!
It’s okay, Just — just prod me or something in future, all right, don’t bend over me like that. . . .
No, it’s just Dobby, Go back to sleep.
’Course you can, Er . . . I’ve got something for you too. Sorry, I forgot to wrap them. . . .
Ah, no, Harry, how come you didn’t spot that? Tell you what, Dobby — here you go — take these two, and you can mix them up properly. And here’s your sweater.
They’re only socks, Wow, Harry — Cool!
They’re . . . they’re really . . . well, thanks, Dobby,

Session-418.Scene: “Lairy fights, that’s the one!” she giggled when they gave the password, and she swung forward to let them inside.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Animal magnetism,
You — er — look nice,
Hermione Where’s Hermione? Okay,
Right,

Session-419.Scene: Then Professor McGonagall’s voice called, “Champions over here, please!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hi, Hi, Parvati!
Why didn’t he come?

Session-420.Scene: “Vell, ve have a castle also, not as big as this, nor as comfortable, I am thinking,” he was telling Hermione. “Ve have just four floors, and the fires are lit only for magical purposes. But ve have grounds larger even than these — though in vinter, ve have very little daylight, so ve are not enjoying them. But in summer ve are flying every day, over the lakes and the mountains —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Her-my-oh-nee,
Close enough,
Oh — yeah, Dobby the house-elf knitted them for me,
Let’s sit down, shall we?
No, I don’t like it, How’s it going?
What?
Hi,
It’s hot, isn’t it? Viktor’s just gone to get some drinks.
Viktor? Hasn’t he asked you to call him Vicky yet?
What about them?
If you don’t know, I’m not going to tell you.
Ron, what — ?
He’s from Durmstrang! He’s competing against Harry! Against Hogwarts! You — you’re — fraternizing with the enemy, that’s what you’re doing!
Don’t be so stupid! The enemy! Who was the one who wanted his autograph? Who’s got a model of him up in their dormitory?
I s’pose he asked you to come with him while you were both in the library?
How’s it going? So what?
What happened — trying to get him to join spew, were you?
No, I wasn’t! If you really want to know, he — he said he’d been coming up to the library every day to try and talk to me, but he hadn’t been able to pluck up the courage!
Yeah, well — that’s his story,
And what’s that supposed to mean?

Obvious, isn’t it? He’s Karkaroff’s student, isn’t he? He knows who you hang around with. . . . He’s just trying to get closer to Harry — get inside information on him — or get near enough to jinx him —
For your information, he hasn’t asked me one single thing about Harry, not one —
Then he’s hoping you’ll help him find out what his egg means! I suppose you’ve been putting your heads together during those cozy little library sessions —
I’d never help him work out that egg!
You’ve got a funny way of showing it,
This whole tournament’s supposed to be about getting to know foreign wizards and making friends with them!
No it isn’t! It’s about winning!
Hermione
Why don’t you go and find Vicky, he’ll be wondering where you are,
Don’t call him Vicky!
No,

Session-421.Scene: “. . . don’t see what there is to fuss about, Igor.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: We’re walking, Not against the law, is it?
What’s got Karkaroff all worried?
And since when have he and Snape been on first-name terms?

Session-422.Scene: She stormed away; great multicolored swarms of fairies rose into the air as she passed, angrily pushing aside bushes. Hagrid was still sitting on the bench, staring after her. It was much too dark to make out his expression. Then, after about a minute, he stood up and strode away, not back to the castle, but off out into the dark grounds in the direction of his cabin.

Dialogue.Dialogue: So? What’s the problem with giants?
Well, they’re . . . they’re . . . . . . not very nice,
Who cares? There’s nothing wrong with Hagrid!
I know there isn’t, but . . . blimey, no wonder he keeps it quiet, I always thought he’d got in the way of a bad Engorgement Charm when he was a kid or something. Didn’t like to mention it. . . .
But what’s it matter if his mother was a giantess?

But . . . Harry, they’re just vicious, giants. It’s like Hagrid said, it’s in their natures, they’re like trolls . . . they just like killing, everyone knows that. There aren’t any left in Britain now, though.
What happened to them?
Well, they were dying out anyway, and then loads got themselves killed by Aurors. There’re supposed to be giants abroad, though. . . . They hide out in mountains mostly. . . .
I don’t know who Maxime thinks she’s kidding, If Hagrid’s half-giant, she definitely is. Big bones . . . the only thing that’s got bigger bones than her is a dinosaur.

Session-423.Scene: The Fat Lady and her friend Vi were snoozing in the picture over the portrait hole. Harry had to yell “Fairy lights!” before he woke them up, and when he did, they were extremely irritated. He climbed into the common room and found Ron and Hermione having a blazing row. Standing ten feet apart, they were bellowing at each other, each scarlet in the face.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Fairy lights!
Well, if you don’t like it, you know what the solution is, don’t you?
Oh yeah? What’s that?
Next time there’s a ball, ask me before someone else does, and not as a last resort!
Well,

Session-424.Scene: When they arrived at Hagrid’s cabin, however, they found an elderly witch with closely cropped gray hair and a very prominent chin standing before his front door.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hurry up, now, the bell rang five minutes ago,
Who’re you? Where’s Hagrid?
Where’s Hagrid?
“What’s wrong with Hagrid?”
“I do mind, though,”  What’s up with him?”

Session-425.Scene: “What d’you reckon’s wrong with him? You don’t think a skrewt — ?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: “What d’you reckon’s wrong with him? You don’t think a skrewt — ?” “What d’you mean?”
“How did she find out?”
You --
“What about Hagrid?
good
“Look at this!”
“How did that horrible Skeeter woman find out? You don’t think Hagrid told her?” “Maybe she heard him telling Madame Maxime at the ball,” “Like you and Ron did, you mean,”
“We weren’t trying to hear him!”
“I — well, I’m not going to pretend it didn’t make a nice change, having a proper Care of Magical Creatures lesson for once — but I do want Hagrid back, of course I do!”

Session-427.Scene: Harry’s insides gave a guilty squirm, but he ignored them. He still had five weeks to work out that egg clue, after all, and that was ages . . . whereas if he went into Hogsmeade, he might run into Hagrid, and get a chance to persuade him to come back.

Dialogue.Dialogue: “I just thought you’d want to take advantage of the common room being quiet, Really get to work on that egg.”
“Oh I — I reckon I’ve got a pretty good idea what it’s about now,”
“Well done!”
“Yeah, but there’s still the giant squid,”

Session-428.Scene: “In a moment, in a moment!” Harry heard him say brusquely to the goblins, and Bagman hurried through the pub toward Harry, his boyish grin back in place.

Dialogue.Dialogue: “Fine, thanks,”
Er — okay,
“Thanks,”
What do they want?
Why are they looking for him here? He’s at the Ministry in London, isn’t he?
Er . . . not bad, We’re supposed to work out the clues alone, aren’t we?
Have you offered Cedric help?
Well, thanks,

Session-429.Scene: “Hello, Mr. Bagman,” said Fred brightly. “Can we buy you a drink?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What did he want?
He offered to help me with the golden egg,
He shouldn’t be doing that! He’s one of the judges! And anyway, you’ve already worked it out — haven’t you?
Er . . . nearly, He’s not, I asked,
Who cares if Diggory’s getting help?
Those goblins didn’t look very friendly, What were they doing here?
said Bagman. He’s still ill. Hasn’t been into work.
Maybe Percy’s poisoning him, Probably thinks if Crouch snuffs it he’ll be made Head of the Department of International Magical Cooperation.
Funny, goblins looking for Mr. Crouch. . . . They’d normally deal with the Department for the Regulation and Control of Magical Creatures.
Crouch can speak loads of different languages, though, Maybe they need an interpreter.
Worrying about poor ’ickle goblins, now, are you? Thinking of starting up S.P. U.G. or something? Society for the Protection of Ugly Goblins?
Ha, ha, ha, Goblins don’t need protection. Haven’t you been listening to what Professor Binns has been telling us about goblin rebellions?
No,
Well, they’re quite capable of dealing with wizards, They’re very clever. They’re not like house-elves, who never stick up for themselves.
Uh-oh,

Session-430.Scene: As if this were not enough, the Daily Prophet has now unearthed evidence that Hagrid is not — as he has always pretended — a pure-blood wizard. He is not, in fact, even pure human. His mother, we can exclusively reveal, is none other than the giantess Fridwulfa, whose whereabouts are currently unknown.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hi, Hagrid,
Of course we still want to know you! You don’t think anything that Skeeter cow — sorry, Professor,
Er — right, I just meant — Hagrid, how could you think we’d care what that — woman — wrote about you?
Hagrid, look what I’ve got for relatives! Look at the Dursleys!
Come back and teach, Hagrid, please come back, we really miss you.
Yeah, he is, Can I have one of these cakes, Hagrid?
’Lo, Really great.

Session-431.Scene: On Thursday night, Harry sneaked up to bed, put on the Cloak, crept back downstairs, and, just as he had done on the night when Hagrid had shown him the dragons, waited for the portrait hole to open. This time it was Ron who waited outside to give the Fat Lady the password (“banana fritters”). “Good luck,” Ron muttered, climbing into the room as Harry crept out past him.

Dialogue.Dialogue: banana fritters
Good luck,
“Pine fresh,”

Session-432.Scene: “I’d try putting it in the water, if I were you.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Myrtle! I’m — I’m not wearing anything!
Yeah . . . well . . . I’m not supposed to come into your bathroom, am I? It’s a girls’ one.
I got told off for going in there, I thought I’d better not come back after that.
Have you been spying on him too?
I’m honored, You keep your eyes shut!

Yeah . . . ‘Come seek us where our voices sound . . .’ and if I need persuading . . . hang on, I need to listen again. . . . I’ve got to go and look for people who can’t use their voices above the ground. . . . Er . . . who could that be?
Underwater . . . Myrtle . . . what lives in the lake, apart from the giant squid?
Well, does anything in there have a human voice? Hang on — Myrtle, there aren’t merpeople in there, are there?
That’s it, isn’t it? The second task’s to go and find the merpeople in the lake and . . . and . . . Myrtle, how am I supposed to breathe?
What’s tactless?
Sorry, I didn’t mean — I just forgot . . .
We’ve taken what you’ll sorely miss,
Good, Well, I’m a lot further on than I was. . . . Shut your eyes again, will you? I’m getting out.
Er . . . I’ll try, See you, Myrtle . . . thanks for your help.
It’s mine! Mine!

Session-434.Scene: Filch’s footsteps halted; there was a clink of metal on metal and the wailing stopped — Filch had picked up the egg and closed it. Harry stood very still, one leg still jammed tightly in the magical step, listening. Any moment now, Filch was going to pull aside the tapestry, expecting to see Peeves . . . and there would be no Peeves . . . but if he came up the stairs, he would spot the Marauder’s Map . . . and Invisibility Cloak or not, the map would show “Harry Potter” standing exactly where he was.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah . . . I — er . . . thanks,
Map of Hogwarts,
Yeah, it’s . . . quite useful, Er — Professor Moody, d’you think you could help me — ?
Er . . . yeah, I did . . . It was Mr. Crouch.
Positive,
Er . . . Professor Moody . . . why d’you reckon Mr. Crouch wanted to look around Snape’s office?
Professor Moody? D’you think . . . could this have anything to do with . . . maybe Mr. Crouch thinks there’s something going on. . . .
I don’t know, odd stuff’s been happening lately, hasn’t it? It’s been in the Daily Prophet . . . the Dark Mark at the World Cup, and the Death Eaters and everything. . . .
Oh! Yeah, okay.

Session-435.Scene: “You ever thought of a career as an Auror, Potter?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: No,
Er — no, I’ve been working out the clue.

Session-436.Scene: You said you’d already worked out that egg clue!” said Hermione indignantly.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You said you’d already worked out that egg clue!
Keep your voice down! I just need to — sort of fine-tune it, all right? Just forget the egg for a minute, all right? I’m trying to tell you about Snape and Moody. . . .
Snape said Moody’s searched his office as well? What . . . d’you reckon Moody’s here to keep an eye on Snape as well as Karkaroff?
Well, I dunno if that’s what Dumbledore asked him to do, but he’s definitely doing it, Moody said Dumbledore only lets Snape stay here because he’s giving him a second chance or something. . . .
What? Harry . . . maybe Moody thinks Snape put your name in the Goblet of Fire!

Oh Ron, we thought Snape was trying to kill Harry before, and it turned out he was saving Harry’s life, remember? I don’t care what Moody says, Dumbledore’s not stupid. He was right to trust Hagrid and Professor Lupin, even though loads of people wouldn’t have given them jobs, so why shouldn’t he be right about Snape, even if Snape is a bit —
— evil, Come on, Hermione, why are all these Dark wizard catchers searching his office, then?
Why has Mr. Crouch been pretending to be ill? It’s a bit funny, isn’t it, that he can’t manage to come to the Yule Ball, but he can get up here in the middle of the night when he wants to?
You just don’t like Crouch because of that elf, Winky,
You just want to think Snape’s up to something,
I just want to know what Snape did with his first chance, if he’s on his second one,

Session-437.Scene: “Of course, the ideal solution would be for you to Transfigure yourself into a submarine or something,” Hermione said. “If only we’d done human Transfiguration already! But I don’t think we start that until sixth year, and it can go badly wrong if you don’t know what you’re doing. . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Of course, the ideal solution would be for you to Transfigure yourself into a submarine or something, If only we’d done human Transfiguration already! But I don’t think we start that until sixth year, and it can go badly wrong if you don’t know what you’re doing. . . .
Yeah, I don’t fancy walking around with a periscope sticking out of my head, I s’pose I could always attack someone in front of Moody; he might do it for me. . . .

I don’t think he’d let you choose what you wanted to be turned into, though, No, I think your best chance is some sort of charm. Weekend after next, Here — take my quill and send this owl back straight away.
What’s he want to know about the next Hogsmeade weekend for?
Dunno, Come on . . . Care of Magical Creatures.

Session-438.Scene: “I don’t reckon it can be done,” said Ron’s voice flatly from the other side of the table. “There’s nothing. Nothing. Closest was that thing to dry up puddles and ponds, that Drought Charm, but that was nowhere near powerful enough to drain the lake.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I don’t reckon it can be done, There’s nothing.
There must be something, They’d never have set a task that was undoable.
Harry, Harry, just go down to the lake tomorrow, right, stick your head in, yell at the merpeople to give back whatever they’ve nicked, and see if they chuck it out. Best you can do, mate.
There’s a way of doing it! There just has to be!
Yeah, you could’ve turned into a goldfish any time you wanted!
Or a frog,

It takes years to become an Animagus, and then you have to register yourself and everything, Professor McGonagall told us, remember . . . you’ve got to register yourself with the Improper Use of Magic Office . . . what animal you become, and your markings, so you can’t abuse it. . . .
Hermione, I was joking, I know I haven’t got a chance of turning into a frog by tomorrow morning. . . .
Oh this is no use, Who on earth wants to make their nose hair grow into ringlets?
What? “What’re you two doing here?”
What? “What’re you two doing here?”
Harry, Bring as many of these books as you can, okay?
Right,

Session-439.Scene: “Lumos,” Harry whispered fifteen minutes later as he opened the library door.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Lumos,
I can’t, Give it to me! That hurts — get off — ouch — Stop poking me — Stop poking me — Stop poking me — Ten minutes? Ten — ten minutes?
It’s too late, Dobby, I’m not doing the task, I don’t know how —
What?
What?
What? What?
What? They’ve got . . . they’ve got Ron? — ‘the prospect’s black,’ ‘Too late, it’s gone, it won’t come back. ’ Dobby — what’ve I got to do?
What’s it do? Dobby, listen — are you sure about this?
See you later, Dobby!

Session-440.Scene: “I’m . . . here . . .” Harry panted, skidding to a halt in the mud and accidentally splattering Fleur’s robes.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I’m . . . here . . .
Dunno,

Session-441.Scene: “Relashio!” Harry shouted, except that no sound came out. . . . A large bubble issued from his mouth, and his wand, instead of sending sparks at the grindylows, pelted them with what seemed to be a jet of boiling water, for where it struck them, angry red patches appeared on their green skin. Harry pulled his ankle out of the grindylow’s grip and swam, as fast as he could, occasionally sending more jets of hot water over his shoulder at random; every now and then he felt one of the grindylows snatch at his foot again, and he kicked out, hard; finally, he felt his foot connect with a horned skull, and looking back, saw the dazed grindylow floating away, cross-eyed, while its fellows shook their fists at Harry and sank back into the weed.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Relashio!
Myrtle!
Come ON!
No way!
She’s my friend too! And I don’t want them to die either!
Get out of the way! You’ve got until three! One . . . two . . .

Session-442.Scene: Merpeople were rising with him. He could see them swirling around him with ease, watching him struggle through the water. . . . Would they pull him back down to the depths when the time was up? Did they perhaps eat humans? Harry’s legs were seizing up with the effort to keep swimming; his shoulders were aching horribly with the effort of dragging Ron and the girl. . . .

Dialogue.Dialogue: What? What did you bring her for?
Fleur didn’t turn up, I couldn’t leave her,
Harry, you didn’t take that song thing seriously, did you? Dumbledore wouldn’t have let any of us drown!
The song said —
It was only to make sure you got back inside the time limit! I hope you didn’t waste time down there acting the hero!
C’mon, help me with her, I don’t think she can swim very well.

Session-443.Scene: “Gabrielle! Gabrielle! Is she alive? Is she ’urt?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: She’s fine!
Gerroff, Percy, I’m all right!
Harry, You did it, you found out how all by yourself!
Yeah, that’s right,
Harry,
No . . . I found you okay. . . .
Yeah, Yeah,
Yeah, Yeah, yeah, a bit —

Session-444.Scene: Miss Granger, a plain but ambitious girl, seems to have a taste for famous wizards that Harry alone cannot satisfy. Since the arrival at Hogwarts of Viktor Krum, Bulgarian Seeker and hero of the last World Quidditch Cup, Miss Granger has been toying with both boys’ affections. Krum, who is openly smitten with the devious Miss Granger, has already invited her to visit him in Bulgaria over the summer holidays, and insists that he has “never felt this way about any other girl.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Scarlet woman? If that’s the best Rita can do, she’s losing her touch, What a pile of old rubbish. There’s something funny, though,
Known what? You haven’t been mixing up Love Potions, have you?
Don’t be stupid, No, it’s just . . . how did she know Viktor asked me to visit him over the summer?
Known what?

He asked me right after he’d pulled me out of the lake, After he’d got rid of his shark’s head. Madam Pomfrey gave us both blankets and then he sort of pulled me away from the judges so they wouldn’t hear, and he said, if I wasn’t doing anything over the summer, would I like to —
And what did you say?

And he did say he’d never felt the same way about anyone else, She wasn’t there ... or was she?  Maybe she has got an Invisibility Cloak;maybe she sneaked onto the grounds to watch the second task. . . .
And what did you say?
Well, I was too busy seeing whether you and Harry were okay to —
I haven’t been anywhere near your office!
I don’t know what you’re talking about,
Right, I’ll bear that in mind if I ever get the urge to go in there.
No,

Session-445.Scene: “Enter,” said Snape in his usual voice.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Clearing up my armadillo bile, Professor,

Session-446.Scene: “Chicken!” he said hoarsely after removing the old Daily Prophets from his mouth and throwing them down onto the cave floor.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What’re you doing here, Sirius?
What if they catch you? What if you’re seen?
They’re making it sound like he’s dying, But he can’t be that ill if he managed to get up here. . . .
My brother’s Crouch’s personal assistant, He says Crouch is suffering from overwork.
Mind you, he did look ill, last time I saw him up close, The night my name came out of the goblet. . . .
Getting his comeuppance for sacking Winky, isn’t he? I bet he wishes he hadn’t done it now — bet he feels the difference now she’s not there to look after him.
Hermione’s obsessed with house-elves,
Yeah, at the Quidditch World Cup,
Right,
No, I think he said he’d been too busy.

No, No, I didn’t need to use it before we got in the forest. And then I put my hand in my pocket, and all that was in there were my Omnioculars. Are you saying whoever conjured the Mark stole my wand in the Top Box?
Winky didn’t steal that wand!
Loads of people,
The Malfoys!
No one, Oh yeah . . .
He’s okay, He keeps offering to help me with the Triwizard Tournament.
Says he’s taken a liking to me,
We saw him in the forest just before the Dark Mark appeared, Remember?
Yeah, but he didn’t stay in the forest, did he? The moment we told him about the riot, he went off to the campsite.
How d’you know? How d’you know where he Disapparated to?
Come off it,
It’s more likely he did it than Winky,
Went to look in the bushes, but there wasn’t anyone else there.
Yes, he sacked her, just because she hadn’t stayed in her tent and let herself get trampled —
Hermione, will you give it a rest with the elf!
D’you know Crouch, then?
Known what?
You’re kidding!
Crouch’s son was caught?
Was his son a Death Eater?
Did Crouch try and get his son off?
He gave his own son to the dementors?
So he’s still in Azkaban?
He died?
Moody says Crouch is obsessed with catching Dark wizards,
And he sneaked up here to search Snape’s office!
Yeah, it does!
So you think Snape could be up to something, then?
Look, I don’t care what you say, Dumbledore trusts Snape —
Oh give it a rest, Hermione, I know Dumbledore’s brilliant and everything, but that doesn’t mean a really clever Dark wizard couldn’t fool him —
Why did Snape save Harry’s life in the first year, then? Why didn’t he just let him die?
I dunno — maybe he thought Dumbledore would kick him out —
Snape knows Karkaroff pretty well, but he wants to keep that quiet,
Yep, Karkaroff wanted to talk to Snape, he says Snape’s been avoiding him. Karkaroff looked really worried. He showed Snape something on his arm, but I couldn’t see what it was.
Why are Moody and Crouch so keen to get into Snape’s office then?
I can try, Better not make it sound like I reckon Crouch is up to anything dodgy, though. Percy loves Crouch.
Bagman told me they hadn’t,
It’s half past three,
No one’s tried to attack me so far, except a dragon and a couple of grindylows,

Session-447.Scene: “You saved my life with that gillyweed, Dobby, you really did,” said Harry.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You saved my life with that gillyweed, Dobby, you really did,
No chance of more of those eclairs, is there?
You’ve just had breakfast!
We should get some stuff to send up to Snuffles,
Good idea, Give Pig something to do. You couldn’t give us a bit of extra food, could you?
Dobby, where’s Winky?
Oh dear,
Well, it’s not strong, that stuff,
Hey, Winky, you don’t know what Mr. Crouch might be up to, do you? Because he’s stopped turning up to judge the Triwizard Tournament.
Yeah, we haven’t seen him since the first task. The Daily Prophet’s saying he’s ill.
But we’re not sure if that’s true,
Other people manage to do their own housework, you know, Winky,
What?
She’s unhappy! Why don’t you try and cheer her up instead of covering her up?

Oh for heaven’s sake! Listen to me, all of you! You’ve got just as much right as wizards to be unhappy! You’ve got the right to wages and holidays and proper clothes, you don’t have to do everything you’re told — look at Dobby!
You couldn’t keep your mouth shut, could you, Hermione? They won’t want us visiting them now! We could’ve tried to get more stuff out of Winky about Crouch!
Oh as if you care about that! You only like coming down here for the food!

Session-448.Scene: “These’re nifflers,” said Hagrid, when the class had gathered around. “Yeh find ’em down mines mostly. They like sparkly stuff. . . . There yeh go, look.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: She had to go to the hospital wing,
We’ll explain later,
Can you buy these as pets, Hagrid?

Session-449.Scene: “What yeh done ter your hands, Hermione?” said Hagrid, looking concerned.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oh for heaven’s sake!
You missed a really good lesson, They’re good, nifflers, aren’t they, Ron? What’s up? Wrong flavor?
No, Why didn’t you tell me about the gold?
What gold?
The gold I gave you at the Quidditch World Cup, The leprechaun gold I gave you for my Omnioculars. In the Top Box. Why didn’t you tell me it disappeared?
Oh . . . I dunno . . . I never noticed it had gone. I was more worried about my wand, wasn’t I?

Session-450.Scene: “Must be nice,” Ron said abruptly, when they had sat down and started serving themselves roast beef and Yorkshire puddings. “To have so much money you don’t notice if a pocketful of Galleons goes missing.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Must be nice, To have so much money you don’t notice if a pocketful of Galleons goes missing.
Listen, I had other stuff on my mind that night! We all did, remember?
I didn’t know leprechaun gold vanishes, I thought I was paying you back. You shouldn’t’ve given me that Chudley Cannon hat for Christmas.
Forget it, all right?
I hate being poor. It’s rubbish, I don’t blame Fred and George for trying to make some extra money. Wish I could. Wish I had a niffler.

Well, we know what to get you next Christmas, Come on, Ron, it could be worse. At least your fingers aren’t full of pus. I hate that Skeeter woman! I’ll get her back for this if it’s the last thing I do!

Session-451.Scene: “It’ll die down, though,” he told Hermione, “if we just ignore it. . . . People got bored with that stuff she wrote about me last time —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: It’ll die down, though, if we just ignore it. . . . People got bored with that stuff she wrote about me last time —
I want to know how she’s listening into private conversations when she’s supposed to be banned from the grounds!

Session-452.Scene: “Well, Rita’s definitely not using an Invisibility Cloak!” Hermione panted five minutes later, catching up with Harry and Ron in the entrance hall and pulling Harry’s hand away from one of his wiggling ears so that he could hear her. “Moody says he didn’t see her anywhere near the judges’ table at the second task, or anywhere near the lake!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Well, Rita’s definitely not using an Invisibility Cloak! Moody says he didn’t see her anywhere near the judges’ table at the second task, or anywhere near the lake!
Hermione, is there any point in telling you to drop this?
No! I want to know how she heard me talking to Viktor! And how she found out about Hagrid’s mum!
Maybe she had you bugged,
Bugged? What . . . put fleas on her or something?
Aren’t you two ever going to read Hogwarts: A History?
What’s the point? You know it by heart, we can just ask you.

All those substitutes for magic Muggles use — electricity, computers, and radar, and all those things — they all go haywire around Hogwarts, there’s too much magic in the air. No, Rita’s using magic to eavesdrop, she must be. . . . If I could just find out what it is . . . ooh, if it’s illegal, I’ll have her . . .
Haven’t we got enough to worry about?
I’m not asking you to help! I’ll do it on my own!

Session-453.Scene: Hedwig didn’t return until the end of the Easter holidays. Percy’s letter was enclosed in a package of Easter eggs that Mrs. Weasley had sent. Both Harry’s and Ron’s were the size of dragon eggs and full of homemade toffee. Hermione’s, however, was smaller than a chicken egg. Her face fell when she saw it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Your mum doesn’t read Witch Weekly, by any chance, does she, Ron?
Yeah, Gets it for the recipes.
“Don’t you want to see what Percy’s written?”

Session-454.Scene: “What d’you reckon it’s going to be?” he asked Harry as they went together down the stone steps, out into the cloudy night. “Fleur keeps going on about underground tunnels; she reckons we’ve got to find treasure.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: That wouldn’t be too bad,

Session-455.Scene: “What’ve they done to it?” Cedric said indignantly, stopping dead.

Dialogue.Dialogue: They’re hedges!
Yeah, all right,
Okay,
No, it’s okay, Mr. Bagman, I think I can find the castle on my own, thanks. What’re we going this way for?

Session-457.Scene: “I vant to know,” he said, glowering, “vot there is between you and Hermy-own-ninny.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Nothing, We’re friends. She’s not my girlfriend and she never has been. It’s just that Skeeter woman making things up.
Yeah, because we’re friends.
No,
Thanks, I saw you at the Quidditch World Cup. The Wronski Feint, you really —
Mr. Crouch?
Mr. Crouch? Are you all right?
No idea, Listen, you’d better go and get someone —

Session-459.Scene: “Mr. Crouch?” Harry said loudly. “Are you all right?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Okay, if you get up, Mr. Crouch, we can go up to the —
I’m a student at the school,
No
That’s right,
I’ll get Dumbledore if you let go of me, Just let go, Mr. Crouch, and I’ll get him. . . .
You stay here with him! I’ll get Dumbledore, I’ll be quicker, I know where his office is —
Just stay with him,
I’ll get Dumbledore if you let me go, Mr. Crouch! Help me, will you? Just keep him here, I’ll be back with Dumbledore.

Session-460.Scene: “Over here,” said Harry, moving in front of Dumbledore, leading the way through the trees. He couldn’t hear Crouch’s voice anymore, but he knew where he was going; it hadn’t been much past the Beauxbatons carriage . . . somewhere around here. . . .

Dialogue.Dialogue: Over here, Viktor? They were here, They were definitely somewhere around here. . . .
Should I go and get someone? Madam Pomfrey?
Er — yes,
Krum’s all right! He wasn’t trying to jinx me, he just wanted to talk about Hermione —
You were getting on all right with Madame Maxime,

Session-461.Scene: “It must’ve been Crouch,” said Ron at once. “That’s why he was gone when Harry and Dumbledore got there. He’d done a runner.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: It must’ve been Crouch, That’s why he was gone when Harry and Dumbledore got there. He’d done a runner.
I don’t think so, He seemed really weak — I don’t reckon he was up to Disapparating or anything.
You can’t Disapparate on the Hogwarts grounds, haven’t I told you enough times?
Okay . . . how’s this for a theory, Krum attacked Crouch — no, wait for it — and then Stunned himself!
And Mr. Crouch evaporated, did he?
Oh yeah . . .
Just go through it again, Harry, What did Mr. Crouch actually say?
I’ve told you, he wasn’t making much sense, He said he wanted to warn Dumbledore about something.
Well, that was his fault,
He was out of his mind, Half the time he seemed to think his wife and son were still alive, and he kept talking to Percy about work and giving him instructions.
And . . . remind me what he said about You-Know-Who?
I’ve told you, He said he’s getting stronger.
He was out of his mind,

He was sanest when he was trying to talk about Voldemort, He was having real trouble stringing two words together, but that was when he seemed to know where he was, and know what he wanted to do. He just kept saying he had to see Dumbledore. If Snape hadn’t held me up,we might’ve got there in time.  The headmaster is busy, Potter . . . what’s this rubbish, Potter? ’ Why couldn’t he have just got out of the way?
Maybe he didn’t want you to get there! Maybe — hang on — how fast d’you reckon he could’ve gotten down to the forest? D’you reckon he could’ve beaten you and Dumbledore there?
Not unless he can turn himself into a bat or something,
Wouldn’t put it past him,
We need to see Professor Moody, We need to find out whether he found Mr. Crouch.
If he had the Marauder’s Map on him, it would’ve been easy,
Unless Crouch was already outside the grounds, because it only shows up to the boundaries, doesn’t —
Shh!

Session-462.Scene: “What’re you doing here?” Ron and Fred said at the same time.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Who’re you blackmailing?
Didn’t sound like that,
It’s my business if you’re blackmailing someone, George’s right, you could end up in serious trouble for that.
No, I won’t!
You don’t think they know something about all this, do you? About Crouch and everything?
No, If it was something that serious, they’d tell someone. They’d tell Dumbledore.
What’s the matter?
Well . . . I dunno if they would. They’re . .
We weren’t talking. Yeah, but blackmail . . .
It’s this joke shop idea they’ve got, I thought they were only saying it to annoy Mum, but they really mean it, they want to start one.
Yes, but . . . they wouldn’t do anything against the law to get gold.
Wouldn’t they? I dunno . . . they don’t exactly mind breaking rules, do they?
Yes, but this is the law, This isn’t some silly school rule. . . . They’ll get a lot more than detention for blackmail! Ron . . . maybe you’d better tell Percy. . . .
Are you mad? Tell Percy? He’d probably do a Crouch and turn them in. Come on, let’s get some breakfast.
D’you think it’s too early to go and see Professor Moody?
Yes, He’d probably blast us through the door if we wake him at the crack of dawn; he’ll think we’re trying to attack him while he’s asleep. Let’s give it till break.

Session-463.Scene: “We need to see Professor Moody,” said Hermione. “We need to find out whether he found Mr. Crouch.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Professor Moody?
Did you find him?
Did you use the map?
So he did Disapparate?
You can’t Disapparate on the grounds, Ron! There are other ways he could have disappeared, aren’t there, Professor?
Well, he wasn’t invisible, The map shows invisible people. He must’ve left the grounds, then.
But under his own steam? or because someone made him?
Yeah, someone could’ve — could’ve pulled him onto a broom and flown off with him, couldn’t they?
So, said Ron, d’you reckon he’s somewhere in Hogsmeade?
What? Oh yeah . . .
We helped, Me and Hermione helped.

Session-464.Scene: Your name didn’t get into the Goblet of Fire by accident. If someone’s trying to attack you, they’re on their last chance. Stay close to Ron and Hermione, do not leave Gryffindor Tower after hours, and arm yourself for the third task. Practice Stunning and Disarming. A few hexes wouldn’t go amiss either. There’s nothing you can do about Crouch. Keep your head down and look after yourself. I’m waiting for your letter giving me your word you won’t stray out-of-bounds again.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Ha! She hasn’t got wind of Crouch!
“Who’s he, to lecture me about being out-of-bounds?” After all the stuff he did at school!” Look
“They couldn’t have made it look like an accident if they’d murdered you in the forest! But if you die during a task —”

Session-465.Scene: “It must’ve been Crouch,” said Ron at once. “That’s why he was gone when Harry and Dumbledore got there. He’d done a runner.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry! Harry! You all right?
Nothing,
I need to go to the hospital wing, I think, Bad headache.
I don’t want to see anything except a headache cure, See you later,
Yes, I didn’t see Madame Maxime anywhere, though, and she’d have a job hiding, wouldn’t she?
Wait here for me, Harry, he said. Our examination of the grounds will not take long. Hello, Fawkes,

Session-467.Scene: “Bring them in,” he said, and his voice echoed through the silent dungeon.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Professor,
What is it?
Er,
You mean . . . that stuff’s your thoughts?
I’m sorry,
Bertha?
No, Professor — I was in Divination just now, and — er — I fell asleep.
Well, I had a dream, A dream about Lord Voldemort. He was torturing Wormtail . . . you know who Wormtail —

Voldemort got a letter from an owl. He said something like, Wormtail’s blunder had been repaired. He said someone was dead. Then he said, Wormtail wouldn’t be fed to the snake — there was a snake beside his chair. He said — he said he’d be feeding me to it, instead. Then he did the Cruciatus Curse on Wormtail — and my scar hurt, Harry said. It woke me up, it hurt so badly. Er — that’s all,
No, I — how did you know it woke me up over the summer?
Professor? I’m sorry, D’you — d’you know why my scar’s hurting me?
But . . . why?
So you think . . . that dream . . . did it really happen?
No, Just the back of his chair. But — there wouldn’t have been anything to see, would there? I mean, he hasn’t got a body, has he? But . . . but then how could he have held the wand?
Professor, do you think he’s getting stronger?
Professor?
Er . . . could I ask you about . . . that court thing I was in . . . in the Pensieve?
You know — you know the trial you found me in? The one with Crouch’s son? Well . . . were they talking about Neville’s parents?
So they’re dead?
Then Mr. Crouch’s son might not have been involved?
Er, Mr. Bagman . . .
I see, And . . . er . . .
Yes, Professor,

Session-468.Scene: Dumbledore reckons You-Know-Who’s getting stronger again as well?” Ron whispered.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Dumbledore reckons You-Know-Who’s getting stronger again as well?  And he trusts Snape? He really trusts Snape, even though he knows he was a Death Eater?
Yes,
How can you be worrying about her now?

I’m not worrying about her, I’m just thinking . . . remember what she said to me in the Three Broomsticks? ’ This is what she meant, isn’t it? She reported his trial, she knew he’d passed information to the Death Eaters. ’ Mr. Crouch would have been furious he got off, he would have talked about it at home.
Yeah, but Bagman didn’t pass information on purpose, did he? And Fudge reckons Madame Maxime attacked Crouch?
Yeah, but he’s only saying that because Crouch disappeared near the Beauxbatons carriage.
We never thought of her, did we? Mind you, she’s definitely got giant blood, and she doesn’t want to admit it —

Of course she doesn’t, Look what happened to Hagrid when Rita found out about his mother. Look at Fudge, jumping to conclusions about her, just because she’s part giant. Who needs that sort of prejudice? I’d probably say I had big bones if I knew that’s what I’d get for telling the truth. We haven’t done any practicing! We were going to do the Impediment Curse! We’ll have to really get down to it tomorrow! Come on, Harry, you need to get some sleep.

Session-469.Scene: “Come and look at this,” said Ron, who was standing by the window. He was staring down onto the grounds. “What’s Malfoy doing?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What?
“He looks like he’s using a walkie-talkie,”

Session-470.Scene: “What?” said Harry and Ron together, staring at her.

Dialogue.Dialogue: “What?”
“No, “No,
“It’s about me, isn’t it?”
“No,” “No,”
“Gone off me a bit, hasn’t she?”
“Are you all right?”
“Yes,”
“S’pose so,
“But the task’s not till tonight!” “She doesn’t expect the Dursleys to turn up, does she?”

Session-471.Scene: “Surprise!” Mrs. Weasley said excitedly as he smiled broadly and walked over to them. “Thought we’d come and watch you, Harry!” She bent down and kissed him on the cheek.

Dialogue.Dialogue: This is really nice of you,
Oh yeah,
Yeah, okay,
“What?” “What?”
Didn’t bother to correct her, though, did he? Still . . . you’ll show him, Ced. Beaten him once before, haven’t you?

Session-472.Scene: “Didn’t bother to correct her, though, did he?” said Amos Diggory, loudly enough for Harry to hear as he started to walk out of the door with Mrs. Weasley and Bill. “Still . . . you’ll show him, Ced. Beaten him once before, haven’t you?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: How’s Percy?

Session-473.Scene: “Mum — Bill!” said Ron, looking stunned, as he joined the Gryffindor table. “What’re you doing here?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Mum — Bill! What’re you doing here?
Oh . . . okay, Couldn’t remember all the goblin rebels’ names, so I invented a few. It’s all right,
Are you going to tell us — ?
Hello,
Because Hermione’s not my girlfriend.

Session-474.Scene: “Ladies and gentlemen, in five minutes’ time, I will be asking you to make your way down to the Quidditch field for the third and final task of the Triwizard Tournament. Will the champions please follow Mr. Bagman down to the stadium now.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I’m okay,

Session-475.Scene: “Ladies and gentlemen, the third and final task of the Triwizard Tournament is about to begin! Let me remind you how the points currently stand! Tied in first place, with eighty-five points each — Mr. Cedric Diggory and Mr. Harry Potter, both of Hogwarts School!” The cheers and applause sent birds from the Forbidden Forest fluttering into the darkening sky. “In second place, with eighty points — Mr. Viktor Krum, of Durmstrang Institute!” More applause. “And in third place — Miss Fleur Delacour, of Beauxbatons Academy!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Lumos, See you, Point Me,
Expecto Patronum! Hang on! You’re a boggart! Riddikulus! Reducto! Fleur? Stupefy! Impedimenta!
Stupefy! Stupefy! Stupefy! “Are you all right?”
I can’t believe this . . . I thought he was all right,
Did you hear Fleur scream earlier?
I don’t know,
No, I reckon we should send up red sparks. Someone’ll come and collect him . . . otherwise he’ll probably be eaten by a skrewt.
What? Oh . . . yeah . . . right . . .
So . . . so will you move, please?
Okay, Can I hear the riddle? Could I have it again . . . more slowly? All the clues add up to a creature I wouldn’t want to kiss?

A person in disguise, who lies . . . er . . . that’d be a — an imposter. No, that’s not my guess! A — a spy? I’ll come back to that . . . could you give me the next clue again, please? ‘The last thing to mend,’ Er . . . no idea . . . ‘middle of middle’ . . . could I have the last bit again? Spy . . . er . . . spy . . . er . . . A creature I wouldn’t want to kiss . . . a spider! . . a spider! Thanks! Point Me! Cedric! On your left! Stupefy! Stupefy! Stupefy! Impedimenta! Stupefy! Impedimenta! Stupefy!
Expelliarmus! Stupefy! Stupefy! Stupefy!
No  Take it, then, Go on, take it. You’re there.
That’s not how it’s supposed to work, The one who reaches the cup first gets the points.That’s you.  I’m telling you, I’m not going to win any races on this leg.
Take it, then, Just take it, then we can get out of here.
I had help on that too, You helped me with the egg — we’re square.
We’re still square,
I was the only one who was thick enough to take that song seriously! Just take the cup!
Both of us,
We’ll take it at the same time. It’s still a Hogwarts victory. We’ll tie for it.
Yeah, Yeah . . . we’ve helped each other out, haven’t we? We both got here. Let’s just take it together.
On three, right?
Where are we?
Nope, Is this supposed to be part of the task?
Yeah, Someone’s coming,
You!

Session-477.Scene: “We bow to each other, Harry,” said Voldemort, bending a little, but keeping his snakelike face upturned to Harry. “Come, the niceties must be observed. . . . Dumbledore would like you to show manners. . . . Bow to death, Harry. . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I WON’T!
Expelliarmus!
Yes,
I will,
NOW!
Impedimenta!
Accio!
He’s back, He’s back. Voldemort.
He wanted me to bring him back, He wanted me to bring him back to his parents. . . .
Dumbledore said stay,
Cup was a Portkey, Took me and Cedric to a graveyard . . . and Voldemort was there . . . Lord Voldemort . . .
Killed Cedric . . . they killed Cedric. . . .
Made a potion . . . got his body back. . . .
And the Death Eaters came . . . and then we dueled. . . .
Got away . . . my wand . . . did something funny. . . . I saw my mum and dad . . . they came out of his wand. . . .

Session-479.Scene: “Drink it . . . you’ll feel better . . . come on, now, Harry, I need to know exactly what happened. . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: He took stuff from his father’s grave, and from Wormtail, and me,
Blood,
Yes, Loads of them . . .
There’s a Death Eater at Hogwarts! There’s a Death Eater here — they put my name in the Goblet of Fire, they made sure I got through to the end —
Karkaroff? Where is he? Have you got him? Is he locked up? Karkaroff?
Karkaroff’s gone? He ran away? But then — he didn’t put my name in the goblet?
No, you didn’t, You didn’t do that . . . you can’t have done . . .
