What
You fired . . . What are you talking about . . . ?
You didn’t . . . it — it can’t be you. . . .
No,

Session-480.Scene: “The Dark Lord didn’t manage to kill you, Potter, and he so wanted to,” whispered Moody. “Imagine how he will reward me when he finds I have done it for him. I gave you to him — the thing he needed above all to regenerate — and then I killed you for him. I will be honored beyond all other Death Eaters. I will be his dearest, his closest supporter . . . closer than a son. . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: You’re mad, you’re mad!

Session-481.Scene: “Stupefy!” There was a blinding flash of red light, and with a great splintering and crashing, the door of Moody’s office was blasted apart —

Dialogue.Dialogue: Moody, How can it have been Moody?

Session-482.Scene: “Minerva, could I ask you to stand guard here while I take Harry upstairs?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Professor, where are Mr. and Mrs. Diggory?

Session-483.Scene: “Harry, are you all right? I knew it — I knew something like this — what happened?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: ’Lo, Fawkes,
He said my blood would make him stronger than if he’d used someone else’s, He said the protection my — my mother left in me — he’d have it too.
My wand’s feather came from Fawkes?
He spoke to me, The . . . the ghost Cedric, or whatever he was, spoke.
An old man,
Yes,
Is he okay?

Session-485.Scene: “Where’s Dumbledore?” Fudge demanded of Mrs. Weasley.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Look, I saw Voldemort come back! I saw the Death Eaters! I can give you their names!
Macnair!
Avery — Nott — Crabbe — Goyle —

Session-486.Scene: “And now,” he said, “it is time for two of our number to recognize each other for what they are. Sirius . . . if you could resume your usual form.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Mum, shut up! It’s okay!
but —
Yeah, Yeah . . . of course I do.

Session-487.Scene: “I must go downstairs,” he said finally. “I must see the Diggorys. Harry — take the rest of your potion. I will see all of you later.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I don’t want that gold, You have it. Anyone can have it. I shouldn’t have won it. It should’ve been Cedric’s.
I told him to take the Cup with me,

Session-488.Scene: “He suffered very little then,” she said, when Harry had told her how Cedric had died. “And after all, Amos . . . he died just when he’d won the tournament. He must have been happy.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: You take this, It should’ve been Cedric’s, he got there first, you take it —

Session-489.Scene: “Who’s that?” called Hagrid, coming to the door. “Harry!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Who?
You two made up, have you?
Yeah,
What’s Dumbledore asked you to do, Hagrid? He sent Professor McGonagall to ask you and Madame Maxime to meet him — that night.
Is it to do with Voldemort?

Session-490.Scene: “It is my belief — and never have I so hoped that I am mistaken — that we are all facing dark and difficult times. Some of you in this Hall have already suffered directly at the hands of Lord Voldemort. Many of your families have been torn asunder. A week ago, a student was taken from our midst.

Dialogue.Dialogue: It’s very good already,
Wonder how the Durmstrang students are getting back, D’you reckon they can steer that ship without Karkaroff?
Oh . . . yes . . . all right,
You’d better hurry up! The carriages’ll be here in a minute!
Have you got a new headmaster yet?

Session-491.Scene: When Hermione returned from the trolley and put her money back into her schoolbag, she dislodged a copy of the Daily Prophet that she had been carrying in there. Harry looked at it, unsure whether he really wanted to know what it might say, but Hermione, seeing him looking at it, said calmly, “There’s nothing in there. You can look for yourself, but there’s nothing at all. I’ve been checking every day. Just a small piece the day after the third task saying you won the tournament. They didn’t even mention Cedric. Nothing about any of it. If you ask me, Fudge is forcing them to keep quiet.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: There’s nothing in there. You can look for yourself, but there’s nothing at all. I’ve been checking every day. Just a small piece the day after the third task saying you won the tournament. They didn’t even mention Cedric. Nothing about any of it. If you ask me, Fudge is forcing them to keep quiet.
He’ll never keep Rita quiet, Not on a story like this.
Oh, Rita hasn’t written anything at all since the third task, As a matter of fact, Not unless she wants me to spill the beans on her.
What are you talking about?
I found out how she was listening in on private conversations when she wasn’t supposed to be coming onto the grounds,
How was she doing it?
How did you find out?
Well, it was you, really, who gave me the idea, Harry,
Did I? How?
Bugging,
But you said they didn’t work —
Oh not electronic bugs, She can turn — — into a beetle.
You’re kidding, You haven’t . . . she’s not . . .
Oh yes she is,
That’s never — you’re kidding —
No, I’m not, I caught her on the windowsill in the hospital wing. Look very closely, and you’ll notice the markings around her antennae are exactly like those foul glasses she wears.
There was a beetle on the statue the night we heard Hagrid telling Madame Maxime about his mum!

Exactly, And Viktor pulled a beetle out of my hair after we’d had our conversation by the lake. And unless I’m very much mistaken, Rita was perched on the windowsill of the Divination class the day your scar hurt. She’s been buzzing around for stories all year.
When we saw Malfoy under that tree . . .

He was talking to her, in his hand, He knew, of course. That’s how she’s been getting all those nice little interviews with the Slytherins. They wouldn’t care that she was doing something illegal, as long as they were giving her horrible stuff about us and Hagrid. I’ve told her I’ll let her out when we get back to London, I’ve put an Unbreakable Charm on the jar, you see, so she can’t transform. And I’ve told her she’s to keep her quill to herself for a whole year. See if she can’t break the habit of writing horrible lies about people.
Get out,

Session-492.Scene: “Exploding Snap, anyone?” said Fred, pulling out a pack of cards.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Who? Who you were blackmailing?
Bagman?
Well, what, then?
Yeah,
So?
But — it must’ve been an accident, mustn’t it?
He didn’t refuse!
But that was all your savings!
How?
Oh, Well — I did win, didn’t I? So he can pay you your gold!

Session-493.Scene: “At the Polkisses’,” said Aunt Petunia fondly. “He’s got so many little friends, he’s so popular . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I didn’t make that noise, Listening to the news, Well, it changes every day, you see, That’s all you know,
The owls . . . aren’t bringing me news,
Well, that’s news to me,

Session-494.Scene: There was something in the alleyway apart from themselves, something that was drawing long, hoarse, rattling breaths. Harry felt a horrible jolt of dread as he stood trembling in the freezing air.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Dudley, shut —

Session-495.Scene: “I’m a Squib, as Mundungus knows full well, so how on earth was I supposed to help you fight off dementors? He left you completely without cover when I warned him —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I’ll do it.
I’ve got an owl, you can borrow her,
So,
I want to know —

Session-496.Scene: “Who did it, son? Give us names. We’ll get them, don’t worry.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Nothing, I didn’t do anything to him, it wasn’t me, it was —

Session-497.Scene: “You’re going to stay here and explain how my son —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: If you don’t get out of the way I’m going to jinx you, The madhouse has chucked me out, So I can do whatever I like. You’ve got three seconds.

Session-498.Scene: “Go on, son,” said Uncle Vernon, “what did he do?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Right, I’ve changed my mind, I’m staying. “Ministry of Magic The second one was from my friend Ron’s dad, he works at the Ministry.
Because I did magic.
Nothing,
Yeah, I did, but I didn’t use —
As if you’d never be happy again, It wasn’t me! Two of them.

Session-499.Scene: “I’ve got to go to a hearing,” said Harry.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I’ve got to go to a hearing, I suppose so.
Right, Dudley and I were in the alleyway between Magnolia Crescent and Wisteria Walk, Dudley thought he’d be smart with me, I pulled out my wand but didn’t use it. Then two dementors turned up —

Of course they didn’t get his soul, you’d know if they had, You can’t give a dementor the old one-two, Because I used the Patronus — I can’t stop the owls coming, I did the Patronus Charm to get rid of the dementors, It’s the only thing that works against them. Couldn’t tell you, No idea. I don’t know why they were here . . . Yes, Yes. Of course I’m not, He must have sent them, Lord Voldemort,
Murdered my parents, yes,
He’s back, Him. He came back a month ago. I saw him.
Yes, Yes. Yes, Yes. Looks like it,
Fine,
Okay.
Right.
Okay.
You do that.

Session-501.Scene: “Lower your wand, boy, before you take someone’s eye out,” said a low, growling voice.

Dialogue.Dialogue: A stag,
F-fine . . .
“Yeah, I know,”

Session-502.Scene: “Funny place,” she said, “it’s a bit too clean, d’you know what I mean? Bit unnatural. Oh, this is better,” she added, as they entered Harry’s bedroom and he turned on the light.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Er — yeah,
No, I wouldn’t mind,

Session-503.Scene: “Excellent,” said Lupin, looking up as Tonks and Harry entered. “We’ve got about a minute, I think. We should probably get out into the garden so we’re ready. Harry, I’ve left a letter telling your aunt and uncle not to worry —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: They won’t, That’ll just depress them.

Session-504.Scene: Harry touched down right behind her and dismounted on a patch of unkempt grass in the middle of a small square. Tonks was already unbuckling Harry’s trunk. Shivering, Harry looked around. The grimy fronts of the surrounding houses were not welcoming; some of them had broken windows, glimmering dully in the light from the streetlamps, paint was peeling from many of the doors, and heaps of rubbish lay outside several sets of front steps.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Where are we?

Session-505.Scene: What’s the Order of the — ?” Harry began.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What’s the Order of the — ?
But where’s — ?

Session-506.Scene: “Oh, Harry, it’s lovely to see you!” she whispered, pulling him into a rib-cracking hug before holding him at arm’s length and examining him critically. “You’re looking peaky; you need feeding up, but you’ll have to wait a bit for dinner, I’m afraid . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Why?
What d’you — ?
“Mrs. Weasley, why — ?”

Session-507.Scene: “HARRY! Ron, he’s here, Harry’s here! We didn’t hear you arrive! Oh, how are you? Are you all right? Have you been furious with us? I bet you have, I know our letters were useless — but we couldn’t tell you anything, Dumbledore made us swear we wouldn’t, oh, we’ve got so much to tell you, and you’ve got to tell us — the dementors! When we heard — and that Ministry hearing — it’s just outrageous, I’ve looked it all up, they can’t expel you, they just can’t, there’s provision in the Decree for the Restriction of Underage Sorcery for the use of magic in life-threatening situations —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: HARRY! Ron, he’s here, Harry’s here! We didn’t hear you arrive! Oh, how are you? Are you all right? Have you been furious with us?
Let him breathe, Hermione,
“Hedwig!”
She’s been in a right state, Pecked us half to death when she brought your last letters, look at this —
Oh yeah, Sorry about that, but I wanted answers, you know . . .
We wanted to give them to you, mate,
— swear not to tell me, Yeah, Hermione’s already said.
He seemed to think it was best, Dumbledore, I mean.
Right,
I think he thought you were safest with the Muggles —
Yeah? Have either of you been attacked by dementors this summer?
Well, no — but that’s why he’s had people from the Order of the Phoenix tailing you all the time —
Didn’t work that well, though, did it? Had to look after myself after all, didn’t I?
He was so angry, Dumbledore. We saw him. When he found out Mundungus had left before his shift had ended. He was scary.
Well, I’m glad he left, If he hadn’t, I wouldn’t have done magic and Dumbledore would probably have left me at Privet Drive all summer.
Aren’t you . . . aren’t you worried about the Ministry of Magic hearing?
No, So why’s Dumbledore been so keen to keep me in the dark? Did you — er — bother to ask him at all?
We told Dumbledore we wanted to tell you what was going on, We did, mate.
He could still’ve kept me informed if he’d wanted to, You’re not telling me he doesn’t know ways to send messages without owls.
I thought that too. But he didn’t want you to know anything.
Maybe he thinks I can’t be trusted,
Don’t be thick,
Or that I can’t take care of myself —
Of course he doesn’t think that!
So how come I have to stay at the Dursleys’ while you two get to join in everything that’s going on here? How come you two are allowed to know everything that’s going on — ?
We’re not! Mum won’t let us near the meetings, she says we’re too young —

SO YOU HAVEN’T BEEN IN THE MEETINGS, BIG DEAL! YOU’VE STILL BEEN HERE, HAVEN’T YOU? YOU’VE STILL BEEN TOGETHER! ME, I’VE BEEN STUCK AT THE DURSLEYS’ FOR A MONTH! AND I’VE HANDLED MORE THAN YOU TWO’VE EVER MANAGED AND DUMBLEDORE KNOWS IT — WHO SAVED THE SORCERER’S STONE? WHO GOT RID OF RIDDLE? WHO SAVED BOTH YOUR SKINS FROM THE DEMENTORS? WHO HAD TO GET PAST DRAGONS AND SPHINXES AND EVERY OTHER FOUL THING LAST YEAR? WHO SAW HIM COME BACK? WHO HAD TO ESCAPE FROM HIM? ME! BUT WHY SHOULD I KNOW WHAT’S GOING ON? WHY SHOULD ANYONE BOTHER TO TELL ME WHAT’S BEEN HAPPENING?
Harry, we wanted to tell you, we really did —
CAN’T’VE WANTED TO THAT MUCH, CAN YOU, OR YOU’D HAVE SENT ME AN OWL, BUT DUMBLEDORE MADE YOU SWEAR —
Well, he did —
FOUR WEEKS I’VE BEEN STUCK IN PRIVET DRIVE, NICKING PAPERS OUT OF BINS TO TRY AND FIND OUT WHAT’S BEEN GOING ON —
We wanted to —
I SUPPOSE YOU’VE BEEN HAVING A REAL LAUGH, HAVEN’T YOU, ALL HOLED UP HERE TOGETHER —
No, honest — Harry, we’re really sorry! You’re absolutely right, Harry — I’d be furious if it was me!
What is this place anyway?
Headquarters of the Order of the Phoenix,
Is anyone going to bother telling me what the Order of the Phoenix — ?
It’s a secret society, Dumbledore’s in charge, he founded it. It’s the people who fought against You-Know-Who last time.
Who’s in it?
Quite a few people —
— we’ve met about twenty of them, but we think there are more . . .
Well?
Er, Well what?
Voldemort! What’s happening? What’s he up to? Where is he? What are we doing to stop him?
Fred and George have invented Extendable Ears, see, They’re really useful.
Extendable — ?

Ears, yeah. Only we’ve had to stop using them lately because Mum found out and went berserk. Fred and George had to hide them all to stop Mum binning them. But we got a good bit of use out of them before Mum realized what was going on. We know some of the Order are following known Death Eaters, keeping tabs on them, you know —
— some of them are working on recruiting more people to the Order —
— and some of them are standing guard over something, They’re always talking about guard duty.
Couldn’t have been me, could it?
Oh yeah,
So what have you two been doing, if you’re not allowed in meetings? You said you’d been busy.

We have, We’ve been decontaminating this house, it’s been empty for ages and stuff’s been breeding in here. We’ve managed to clean out the kitchen, most of the bedrooms, and I think we’re doing the drawing room tomo — AARGH!

Session-508.Scene: Every bitter and resentful thought that Harry had had in the past month was pouring out of him; his frustration at the lack of news, the hurt that they had all been together without him, his fury at being followed and not told about it: All the feelings he was half-ashamed of finally burst their boundaries. Hedwig took fright at the noise and soared off on top of the wardrobe again; Pigwidgeon twittered in alarm and zoomed even faster around their heads.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Stop doing that!
You two passed your Apparation tests, then?
It would have taken you about thirty seconds longer to walk down the stairs,
Snape? Is he here?
He’s on our side now,
Doesn’t stop him being a git. The way he looks at us when he sees us . . .
Is Bill here? I thought he was working in Egypt.
What d’you mean?
Couldn’t Percy do that?
Whatever you do, don’t mention Percy in front of Mum and Dad,
Why not?
What’s happened?
Order of the Phoenix We were about to come and join the Order. Percy came home and told us he’d been promoted.
You’re kidding?
So how come they promoted him?

That’s exactly what we wondered, He came home really pleased with himself — even more pleased than usual if you can imagine that — and told Dad he’d been offered a position in Fudge’s own office. He expected Dad to be all impressed, I think.
Why not?
But what’s this got to do with Percy?
“Bet Percy loved that.”
What?

I know, And it got worse. He said Dad was an idiot to run around with Dumbledore, that Dumbledore was heading for big trouble and Dad was going to go down with him, and that he — Percy — knew where his loyalty lay and it was with the Ministry. And if Mum and Dad were going to become traitors to the Ministry he was going to make sure everyone knew he didn’t belong to our family anymore. And he packed his bags the same night and left. He’s living here in London now. Mum’s been in a right state, You know — crying and stuff. She came up to London to try and talk to Percy but he slammed the door in her face. I dunno what he does if he meets Dad at work — ignores him, I s’pose.
But Percy must know Voldemort’s back, He’s not stupid, he must know your mum and dad wouldn’t risk everything without proof —
Yeah, Percy said the only evidence was your word and . . . I dunno . . . he didn’t think it was good enough.
Percy takes the Daily Prophet seriously,
What are you talking about?
Haven’t — haven’t you been getting the Daily Prophet?
Yeah,
Have you — er — been reading it thoroughly?
Not cover to cover, If they were going to report anything about Voldemort it would be headline news, wouldn’t it!
Well, you’d need to read it cover to cover to pick it up, but they — um — they mention you a couple of times a week.
But I’d have seen —
Not if you’ve only been reading the front page, you wouldn’t, I’m not talking about big articles. They just slip you in, like you’re a standing joke.
What d’you — ?
It’s quite nasty, actually, They’re just building on Rita’s stuff.
But she’s not writing for them anymore, is she?
Oh no, she’s kept her promise — not that she’s got any choice, But she laid the foundation for what they’re trying to do now.
What?
Okay, you know she wrote that you were collapsing all over the place and saying your scar was hurting and all that?
Yeah
Well, they’re writing about you as though you’re this deluded, attention-seeking person who thinks he’s a great tragic hero or something, They keep slipping in snide comments about you.
I don’t want anyone to worship —

I know, I know, Harry. But you see what they’re doing? They want to turn you into someone nobody will believe. Fudge is behind it, I’ll bet anything. They want wizards on the street to think you’re just some stupid boy who’s a bit of a joke, who tells ridiculous tall stories because he loves being famous and wants to keep it going.
I didn’t ask — I didn’t want — Voldemort killed my parents! I got famous because he murdered my family but couldn’t kill me! Who wants to be famous for that? Don’t they think I’d rather it’d never —
And of course, they didn’t report a word about the dementors attacking you,

Session-509.Scene: “The meeting’s over, you can come down and have dinner now, everyone’s dying to see you, Harry. And who’s left all those Dungbombs outside the kitchen door?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: “Look …”
“We knew you’d be angry, Harry, we really don’t blame you, but you’ve got to understand, we did try and persuade Dumble-dore —”
Yeah, I know, Who’s Kreacher?
The house-elf who lives here,
He’s not a nutter, Ron —
His life’s ambition is to have his head cut off and stuck up on a plaque just like his mother, Is that normal, Hermione?
Well — well, if he is a bit strange, it’s not his fault — It’s not ‘spew’!
Yeah, C’mon, I’m starving. Hold it! They’re still in the hall, we might be able to hear something —
Snape never eats here,
And don’t forget to keep your voice down in the hall, Harry,
“Your — ?”
But what’s a portrait of your mother doing here?

Session-511.Scene: “But what’s a portrait of your mother doing here?” Harry asked, bewildered, as they went through the door from the hall and led the way down a flight of narrow stone steps, the others just behind them.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah,

Session-512.Scene: “And if you want dinner before midnight I’ll need a hand,” Mrs. Weasley said to the room at large. “No, you can stay where you are, Harry dear, you’ve had a long journey —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: No, I haven’t seen anyone.
No, it’s been lousy,
“What?”
How come?
At least you’ve known what’s been going on,
What cleaning?
Do that one like a pig snout, Tonks . . .

Session-514.Scene: “They’re not giving anything away yet,” said Bill. “I still can’t work out whether they believe he’s back or not. ’Course, they might prefer not to take sides at all. Keep out of it.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: How come he’s in the Order?
I did! I asked Ron and Hermione but they said we’re not allowed in the Order, so —
What’s wrong with that?
I want to know what’s been going on,

Session-515.Scene: “Very well,” said Mrs. Weasley, her voice cracking. “Ginny — Ron — Hermione — Fred — George — I want you out of this kitchen, now.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: If Harry’s allowed, why can’t I?
Harry’ll tell me and Hermione everything you say anyway! Won’t — won’t you?
’Course I will,
What?
How come he’s stopped killing people?
How?
How has that helped?
So what’s the Order been doing?
How d’you know what his plans are?
So what does Dumbledore reckon he’s planning?
So you’re trying to stop him getting more followers?
How?
Why?
Why? Why’s he being so stupid? If Dumbledore —
Frightened of Dumbledore?
But Dumbledore doesn’t want —
How can he think that? How can he think Dumbledore would just make it all up — that I’d make it all up?
But you’re telling people, aren’t you? You’re letting people know he’s back?
But if none of you’s putting the news out that Voldemort’s back —
What d’you mean?
But if Voldemort’s trying to recruit more Death Eaters, it’s bound to get out that he’s come back, isn’t it?
What’s he after apart from followers? When he was powerful before?
Like what kind of weapon? Something worse than the Avada Kedavra — ?

Session-516.Scene: “I want you all to go straight to bed, no talking,” she said as they reached the first landing. “We’ve got a busy day tomorrow. I expect Ginny’s asleep,” she added to Hermione, “so try not to wake her up.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: ’Night,
We can’t let them out to hunt every night, Dumbledore doesn’t want too many owls swooping around the square, thinks it’ll look suspicious. Oh yeah . . . I forgot . . .
What’re you doing that for?
Kreacher, First night I was here he came wandering in at three in the morning. Trust me, you don’t want to wake up and find him prowling around your room. Anyway . . . What d’you reckon?

Well, they didn’t tell us much we couldn’t have guessed, did they? I mean, all they’ve really said is that the Order’s trying to stop people joining Vol — — demort , When are you going to start using his name? Sirius and Lupin do.
Yeah, OUCH!
You two just Apparated on my knees!
The weapon Sirius mentioned?
What d’you reckon it is?
But there can’t be anything worse than the Avada Kedavra curse, can there? What’s worse than death?
Maybe it’s some particularly painful way of killing people,
He’s got the Cruciatus Curse for causing pain, He doesn’t need anything more efficient than that.
I hope it’s our side,
Where? Hogwarts?
A weapon’s going to be a lot bigger than the Stone, though!
What d’you mean?
She doesn’t trust us at all, you know,

Session-517.Scene: “Cover your faces and take a spray,” Mrs. Weasley said to Harry and Ron the moment she saw them, pointing to two more bottles of black liquid standing on a spindle-legged table. “It’s Doxycide. I’ve never seen an infestation this bad — what that house-elf’s been doing for the last ten years —”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Kreacher’s really old, he probably couldn’t manage —
What are Skiving Snackboxes?
Testers?
Joke shop still on, then?

Session-518.Scene: “Mundungus!” said Hermione. “What’s he brought all those cauldrons for?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Mundungus! What’s he brought all those cauldrons for?
Probably looking for a safe place to keep them, Isn’t that what he was doing the night he was supposed to be tailing me? Picking up dodgy cauldrons?
Kreacher, Harry Potter.
It doesn’t matter, he’s not in his right mind, he doesn’t know what he’s —

Session-519.Scene: “Stand up straight,” said Sirius impatiently. “Now, what are you up to?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Sirius, he’s not right in the head, I don’t think he realizes we can hear him.
If you just set him free,
You’re not on here!
You ran away from home?
Where did you go?
But . . . why did you . . . ?
But he died,
You’re kidding!
Were — were your parents Death Eaters as well?
Was he killed by an Auror?
You and Tonks are related?
You’re related to the Malfoys!
Lestrange . . .
You never said she was your —
Sorry? I didn’t mean — I was just surprised, that’s all —
But if they do expel me, can I come back here and live with you?
I’d feel a lot better about the hearing if I knew I didn’t have to go back to the Dursleys,

Session-521.Scene: He felt as though a brick had dropped into his stomach when Mrs. Weasley turned to him during dinner on Wednesday evening and said quietly, “I’ve ironed your best clothes for tomorrow morning, Harry, and I want you to wash your hair tonight too. A good first impression can work wonders.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: How am I getting there?
“When did Dumbledore tell you that?”

Session-522.Scene: “Breakfast,” she said as she pulled out her wand and hurried over to the fire.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah,
Just — just toast, thanks,
Okay,
Right, Well . . . see you later then.

Session-523.Scene: “You don’t normally walk to work, do you?” Harry asked him, as they set off briskly around the square.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You don’t normally walk to work, do you?
They’re out of order,

Session-524.Scene: “Where are we?” said Mr. Weasley blankly, and for one heart-stopping moment Harry thought they had gotten off at the wrong station despite Mr. Weasley’s continual references to the map; but a second later he said, “Ah yes . . . this way, Harry,” and led him down a side road.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Mr. Weasley, I think this might be out of order too,
Yes,
thanks

Session-526.Scene: “This is us, Harry,” said Mr. Weasley, and they followed the witch out of the lift into a corridor lined with doors. “My office is on the other side of the floor.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Mr. Weasley, aren’t we underground?

Session-527.Scene: “We haven’t got a window,” said Mr. Weasley apologetically, taking off his bomber jacket and placing it on the back of his chair. “We’ve asked, but they don’t seem to think we need one. Have a seat, Harry, doesn’t look as if Perkins is in yet.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: A regurgitating toilet?
Plumbers?
Will it be Aurors who catch them?

Session-528.Scene: “Why have they changed the time?” Harry said breathlessly as they hurtled past the Auror cubicles; people poked out their heads and stared as they streaked past. Harry felt as though he had left all his insides back at Perkins’s desk.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Why have they changed the time?
Sorry, I-I didn’t know the time had changed.
Yes.
Yes, Yes, Yes, but — Yes, but —
Yes, Yes, Yes, but — Yes, but —
Yes, Yes, Yes, but — Yes, but —
Yes, Yes, Yes, but — Yes, but —
Yes,
Yes,
A — what?
Yes, it’s a stag, it’s always a stag.
Yes,
Yes,
Yes,
I did it because of the dementors!
I mean there were two dementors down that alleyway and they went for me and my cousin!
I’m not lying! There were two of them, coming from opposite ends of the alley, everything went dark and cold and my cousin felt them and ran for it —
That wasn’t me, it was a house-elf!
Cleared, of all charges!
I think so,
So what will you have to do about the toilet?

Session-531.Scene: “Well, well, well . . . Patronus Potter,” said Lucius Malfoy coolly.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah, yeah, I’m good at escaping . . .
What are you doing here anyway?
Why wasn’t he waiting outside Fudge’s office if they’ve got business to do together? What was he doing down here?
What private business have they got together anyway?
Mr. Weasley, if Fudge is meeting Death Eaters like Malfoy, if he’s seeing them alone, how do we know they haven’t put the Imperius Curse on him?

Session-532.Scene: “Wait . . .” he told Mr. Weasley, and pulling his money bag from his pocket, he turned back to the fountain.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Wait . . .
I knew it! You always get away with stuff!
They were bound to clear you, There was no case against you, none at all . . .
Everyone seems quite relieved, though, considering they all knew I’d get off,
’Course, once Dumbledore turned up on your side, there was no way they were going to convict you,
Yeah,
What’s up?
Scar, But it’s nothing. . . . It happens all the time now . . .
I bet Dumbledore turns up this evening to celebrate with us, you know.

Session-533.Scene: “Don’t you go feeling guilty!” said Hermione sternly, after Harry had confided some of his feelings to her and Ron while they scrubbed out a moldy cupboard on the third floor a few days later. “You belong at Hogwarts and Sirius knows it. Personally, I think he’s being selfish.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Don’t you go feeling guilty! You belong at Hogwarts and Sirius knows it. Personally, I think he’s being selfish.
That’s a bit harsh you wouldn’t want to be stuck inside this house without company.
He’ll have company! It’s headquarters to the Order of the Phoenix, isn’t it? He just got his hopes up that Harry would be coming to live here with him.
I don’t think that’s true, He wouldn’t give me a straight answer when I asked him if I could.

He just didn’t want to get his own hopes up even more, And he probably felt a bit guilty himself, because I think a part of him was really hoping you’d be expelled. Then you’d both be outcasts together.
Come off it!
Suit yourselves. But I sometimes think Ron’s mum’s right, and Sirius gets confused about whether you’re you or your father, Harry.
So you think he’s touched in the head?
No, I just think he’s been very lonely for a long time,
I thought you might be here to tell us to have a break! D’you know how much mold we’ve got rid of since we arrived here?
I feel like a house-elf,

Yeah, You know, maybe it wouldn’t be a bad idea to show people exactly how horrible it is to clean all the time — we could do a sponsored scrub of Gryffindor common room, all proceeds to S.P. E.W., it would raise awareness as well as funds —
I’ll sponsor you to shut up about spew,

Session-534.Scene: “Booklists have arrived,” he said, throwing one of the envelopes up to Harry, who was standing on a chair. “About time, I thought they’d forgotten, they usually come much earlier than this . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Booklists have arrived, About time, I thought they’d forgotten, they usually come much earlier than this . . .
Only two new ones, The Standard Book of Spells, Grade 5, by Miranda Goshawk and Defensive Magical Theory, by Wilbert Slinkhard.
What d’you mean?
Yeah, Yeah, I see what you mean.
Did you — did you get — ? I knew it! Me too, Harry, me too!
No, It’s Ron, not me.
What?
Ron’s prefect, not me,
Ron? But . . . are you sure? I mean —
It’s my name on the letter,
I . . . I . . . well . . . wow! Well done, Ron! That’s really —
No, no, it’s not . . . Ron’s done loads of . . . he’s really . . .

Session-535.Scene: “Ginny said the booklists had come at last,” she said, glancing around at all the envelopes as she made her way over to the bed and started sorting the robes into two piles. “If you give them to me I’ll take them over to Diagon Alley this afternoon and get your books while you’re packing. Ron, I’ll have to get you more pajamas, these are at least six inches too short, I can’t believe how fast you’re growing . . . what color would you like?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Mum . . . don’t . . . Mum, get a grip . . .
What?
Mum, can I have a new broom? Not a really good one! Just — just a new one for a change . . .
SHUT UP!
He could if you don’t watch out!
Drop it, Hermione.
Those two! Don’t pay any attention to them, Ron, they’re only jealous!

I don’t think they are, They’ve always said only prats become prefects. . . . Still, they’ve never had new brooms! I wish I could go with Mum and choose. . . . She’ll never be able to afford a Nimbus, but there’s the new Cleansweep out, that’d be great. . . . Yeah, I think I’ll go and tell her I like the Cleansweep, just so she knows .
Harry?
Well done, Great.
Thanks, They’ll be really pleased — I mean, prefect is something they can understand —
Yeah, no problem, Take her!
Just caught her! She says she’ll get the Cleansweep if she can.
Cool, Listen — Ron — well done, mate.
I never thought it would be me! I thought it would be you!
No,
Yeah, yeah, I suppose. . . . Well, we’d better get our trunks packed, hadn’t we?

Session-536.Scene: Mrs. Weasley and Bill were having their usual argument about Bill’s hair.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oh — I dunno —

Session-537.Scene: “Look what Dung’s gotten us,” said George, holding out his hand to Harry. It was full of what looked like shriveled black pods. A faint rattling noise was coming from them, even though they were completely stationary.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Be careful,
But Moody could have his eye on you,
. . . the handle’s made of Spanish oak with anti-jinx varnish and in-built vibration control —
Yeah, fine,
Yeah, Er . . . listen, I’ve just remembered, I haven’t packed my . . .
Hello

Session-539.Scene: “Original Order of the Phoenix,” growled Moody. “Found it last night when I was looking for my spare Invisibility Cloak, seeing as Podmore hasn’t had the manners to return my best one. . . . Thought people might like to see it.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Mrs. Weasley?
Mrs. Weasley, just get out of here!
Don’t be stupid,

Session-540.Scene: Without warning, the scar on his forehead seared with pain again and his stomach churned horribly.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Cut it out,

Session-541.Scene: “. . . better hurry up, Mum’s going ballistic, she says we’re going to miss the train . . .”

Dialogue.Dialogue: . . . better hurry up, Mum’s going ballistic, she says we’re going to miss the train . . .
Mrs. Weasley’s patched her up, But now Mad-Eye’s complaining that we can’t leave unless Sturgis Podmore’s here, otherwise the guard will be one short.
Guard? We have to go to King’s Cross with a guard?
You have to go to King’s Cross with a guard,
Why? I thought Voldemort was supposed to be lying low, or are you telling me he’s going to jump out from behind a dustbin to try and do me in?
I don’t know, it’s just what Mad-Eye says, But if we don’t leave soon we’re definitely going to miss the train . . .

Session-542.Scene: “Where’s Tonks?” Harry said, looking around as they went down the stone steps of number twelve, which vanished the moment they reached the pavement.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Where’s Tonks?

Session-543.Scene: “I hope the others make it in time,” said Mrs. Weasley anxiously, staring behind her at the wrought-iron arch spanning the platform, through which new arrivals would come.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Thanks, Lee,

Session-544.Scene: “See you!” Harry called out of the open window as the train began to move, while Ron, Hermione, and Ginny waved beside him. The figures of Tonks, Lupin, Moody, and Mr. and Mrs. Weasley shrank rapidly but the black dog was bounding alongside the window, wagging its tail; blurred people on the platform were laughing to see it chasing the train, and then they turned the corner, and Sirius was gone.

Dialogue.Dialogue: See you!
He shouldn’t have come with us,
Oh lighten up, he hasn’t seen daylight for months, poor bloke.
Shall we go and find a compartment, then?
Er,
We’re — well — Ron and I are supposed to go into the prefect carriage,
Oh, Right. Fine.
I don’t think we’ll have to stay there all journey, Our letters said we just get instructions from the Head Boy and Girl and then patrol the corridors from time to time.
Fine, Well, I-I might see you later, then.
Yeah, definitely, It’s a pain having to go down there, I’d rather — but we have to — I mean, I’m not enjoying it, I’m not Percy,
I know you’re not,
Right,
I know I am,

Session-545.Scene: “Guess what I got for my birthday?” said Neville.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Another Remembrall?
Does it — er — do anything?
Oh . . . hi,

Session-546.Scene: “I’m starving,” said Ron, stowing Pigwidgeon next to Hedwig, grabbing a Chocolate Frog from Harry and throwing himself into the seat next to him. He ripped open the wrapper, bit off the Frog’s head, and leaned back with his eyes closed as though he had had a very exhausting morning.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I’m starving,
Well, there are two fifth-year prefects from each House, Boy and girl from each.
And guess who’s a Slytherin prefect?
Malfoy,
’Course,
And that complete cow Pansy Parkinson, How she got to be a prefect when she’s thicker than a concussed troll . . .
Who’s Hufflepuff?
Ernie Macmillan and Hannah Abbott,
And Anthony Goldstein and Padma Patil for Ravenclaw,
Yes,
We’re supposed to patrol the corridors every so often, and we can give out punishments if people are misbehaving. I can’t wait to get Crabbe and Goyle for something . . .
You’re not supposed to abuse your position, Ron!
Yes,
So you’re going to descend to his level?
No, I’m just going to make sure I get his mates before he gets mine.
For heaven’s sake, Ron —
I’ll make Goyle do lines, it’ll kill him, he hates writing, I . . . must . . . not . . . look . . . like . . . a . . . baboon’s . . . backside . . .
Are you taking the mickey?
Can I have a look at this?
Anything good in there?
Of course not, The Quibbler’s rubbish, everyone knows that.
I — oh, Well . . . it’s got some interesting . . . I mean, it’s quite . . .

Session-547.Scene: “Yeah,” said Harry, “but you, unlike me, are a git, so get out and leave us alone.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What?
Yeah, but you, unlike me, are a git, so get out and leave us alone.
Malfoy,
Get out!
Chuck us another Frog,
We’d better change,
Thanks,

Session-548.Scene: But it did not come. Instead a quite different voice, a brisk female one, was calling, “First years line up over here, please! All first years to me!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Where’s Hagrid?
Oh,

Session-549.Scene: He looked around for Ron or Hermione, wanting to know what they thought about the reappearance of Professor Grubbly-Plank, but neither of them was anywhere near him, so he allowed himself to be shunted forward onto the dark rain-washed road outside Hogsmeade station.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Where’s Pig? — Hagrid is? I dunno, He’d better be okay . . .
Ginny’s got him, There she is . . .
Come on, Come on, let’s get a carriage together before they all fill up . . .
I haven’t got Pig yet!
What are those things, d’you reckon? What things?
What are those things, What things?
Those horse —
Well, Well, come on then, let’s get in. . . . what were you saying, Harry?
I was saying, what are those horse things?
What horse things?
The horse things pulling the carriages!
What are you talking about?
I’m talking about — look!
What am I supposed to be looking at?
At the — there, between the shafts! Harnessed to the coach! It’s right there in front — Can’t . . . can’t you see them?
See what?
Can’t you see what’s pulling the carriages?
Are you feeling all right, Harry?
I . . . yeah . . .
“Shall we get in, then?”
“Yeah,”
“Can you?”

Session-550.Scene: “Oh . . . yeah,” said Harry quickly, and they joined the crowd hurrying up the stone steps into the castle.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oh . . . yeah, “He’s not there.”
He can’t have left,
Of course he hasn’t,
You don’t think he’s . . . hurt, or anything, do you?
Of course he hasn’t,
But where is he, then?
Maybe he’s not back yet. You know — from his mission — the thing he was doing over the summer for Dumbledore.
Yeah . . . yeah, that’ll be it,
Who’s that?
It’s that Umbridge woman!
Who?
She was at my hearing, she works for Fudge!
Nice cardigan,
She works for Fudge? What on earth’s she doing here, then?
Dunno . . .
No, no, surely not . . .

Session-551.Scene: “Branched out a bit this year, hasn’t it?” said Ron, his eyebrows raised.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Branched out a bit this year, hasn’t it?
Too right it has,
I wonder if it’s ever given warnings before?

Session-552.Scene: “Excellent,” said Ron, with a kind of groan of longing, and he seized the nearest plate of chops and began piling them onto his plate, watched wistfully by Nearly Headless Nick.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Excellent,
What were you saying before the Sorting? About the hat giving warnings?
Ow kunnit nofe skusin danger ifzat?
And it wants all the Houses to be friends? Fat chance.
Only because you’re terrified of him,
What blood? Surely you haven’t still got — ?
Nick, he wasn’t really laughing at you!
“node iddum eentup sechew,”
Well done, Ron,
What? I’m not allowed to ask a simple question?
Oh forget it,

Session-553.Scene: “Yes, it certainly was illuminating,” said Hermione in a low voice.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yes, it certainly was illuminating,
You’re not telling me you enjoyed it? That was about the dullest speech I’ve ever heard, and I grew up with Percy.
I said illuminating, not enjoyable, It explained a lot.
Did it? Sounded like a load of waffle to me. Was there?
There was some important stuff hidden in the waffle,
Did it?
How about ‘progress for progress’s sake must be discouraged’? How about ‘pruning wherever we find practices that ought to be prohibited’?
Well, what does that mean?
I’ll tell you what it means, It means the Ministry’s interfering at Hogwarts. Ron, we’re supposed to show the first years where to go!
Oh yeah, Hey — hey you lot! Midgets!
Well done, Ron,
Well, they are, they’re titchy . . .
I know, but you can’t call them midgets. . . . First years! This way, please!
See you later,

Session-554.Scene: A group of new students walked shyly up the gap between the Gryffindor and Hufflepuff tables, all of them trying hard not to lead the group. They did indeed seem very small; Harry was sure he had not appeared that young when he had arrived here. He grinned at them. A blond boy next to Euan Abercrombie looked petrified, nudged Euan, and whispered something in his ear. Euan Abercrombie looked equally frightened and stole a horrified look at Harry, who felt the grin slide off his face like Stinksap.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Erm . .

Session-555.Scene: The Gryffindor common room looked as welcoming as ever, a cozy circular tower room full of dilapidated squashy armchairs and rickety old tables. A fire was crackling merrily in the grate and a few people were warming their hands before going up to their dormitories; on the other side of the room Fred and George Weasley were pinning something up on the notice board. Harry waved good night to them and headed straight for the door to the boys’ dormitories; he was not in much of a mood for talking at the moment. Neville followed him.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hi,
Not bad, You?
“What?”
But — why?
What d’you mean?
She believes the Daily Prophet? She thinks I’m a liar and Dumbledore’s an old fool?
“I’ll have a go at anyone who calls me a liar,”

Session-556.Scene: Seamus dressed at top speed next morning and left the dormitory before Harry had even put on his socks.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Does he think he’ll turn into a nutter if he stays in a room with me too long?

Session-557.Scene: “What are you still getting that for?” said Harry irritably, thinking of Seamus, as Hermione placed a Knut in the leather pouch on the owl’s leg and it took off again. “I’m not bothering . . . load of rubbish.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: What are you still getting that for? I’m not bothering . . . load of rubbish.
It’s best to know what the enemy are saying, Nothing, Nothing about you or Dumbledore or anything.

Look at today! History of Magic, double Potions, Divination, and double Defense Against the Dark Arts . . . Binns, Snape, Trelawney, and that Umbridge woman all in one day! I wish Fred and George’d hurry up and get those Skiving Snackboxes sorted . . .
Look what we’ve got today, That’s the worst Monday I’ve ever seen.
Why’s it cheap? Cheers, but I think I’ll take the lessons.
And speaking of your Skiving Snackboxes, you can’t advertise for testers on the Gryffindor notice board.
Says me, And Ron.
Leave me out of it,
And why would starting fifth year mean I want a Skiving Snackbox?
So?
Yeah . . . you got, what was it, three O. W.L.s each?
But where are you going to get the gold to start a joke shop? You’re going to need all the ingredients and materials — and premises too, I suppose . . .
What did that mean? ‘Ask us no questions . . . ’ Does that mean they’ve already got some gold to start a joke shop?
You know, I’ve been wondering about that, They bought me a new set of dress robes this summer, and I couldn’t understand where they got the Galleons . . .
D’you reckon it’s true this year’s going to be really tough? Because of the exams?

Oh yeah, Bound to be, isn’t it? O.W.L.s are really important, affect the jobs you can apply for and everything. We get career advice too, later this year, Bill told me. So you can choose what N. E.W.T.s you want to do next year.
D’you know what you want to do after Hogwarts?
Not really, Except . . . well . . .
Why?
Well, it’d be cool to be an Auror,
Yeah, it would,
But they’re, like, the elite, You’ve got to be really good. What about you, Hermione?
I don’t know, I think I’d really like to do something worthwhile.
An Auror’s worthwhile!
Yes, it is, but it’s not the only worthwhile thing, I mean, if I could take S.P. E.W. further . . . if I refused to lend you my notes this year?
We’d fail our O. W.L.s, If you want that on your conscience, Hermione . . .
Well, you’d deserve it, You don’t even try to listen to him, do you?
We do try, We just haven’t got your brains or your memory or your concentration — you’re just cleverer than we are — is it nice to rub it in?

Session-558.Scene: “Oh, don’t give me that rubbish,” said Hermione, but she looked slightly mollified as she led the way out into the damp courtyard.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oh, don’t give me that rubbish,
Hi,
Yeah, it would, So did you . . . er . . . have a good summer?
Is that a Tornados badge? You don’t support them, do you?
Have you always supported them, or just since they started winning the league?
You are so tactless!
What? I only asked her if —
Couldn’t you tell she wanted to talk to Harry on her own?
So? She could’ve done, I wasn’t stopping —
What on earth were you attacking her about her Quidditch team for? Attacking?
Attacking? I wasn’t attacking her, I was only — Who cares if she supports the Tornados?
Oh, come on, half the people you see wearing those badges only bought them last season —
But what does it matter?
It means they’re not real fans, they’re just jumping on the bandwagon —
That’s the bell,

Session-559.Scene: “Settle down,” said Snape coldly, shutting the door behind him.

Dialogue.Dialogue: The Draught of Peace,
Yes, I can,
‘Add powdered moonstone, stir three times counterclockwise, allow to simmer for seven minutes, then add two drops of syrup of hellebore.
No,
No, I forgot the hellebore . . .

Session-560.Scene: “That was really unfair,” said Hermione consolingly, sitting down next to Harry and helping herself to shepherd’s pie. “Your potion wasn’t nearly as bad as Goyle’s, when he put it in his flagon the whole thing shattered and set his robes on fire.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: That was really unfair, Your potion wasn’t nearly as bad as Goyle’s, when he put it in his flagon the whole thing shattered and set his robes on fire.
Yeah, well, since when has Snape ever been fair to me?
I did think he might be a bit better this year, I mean . . . you know . . . . . . Now he’s in the Order and everything.
Poisonous toadstools don’t change their spots,
I think Dumbledore’s probably got plenty of evidence, even if he doesn’t share it with you, Ron,
Oh, shut up, the pair of you, Can’t you give it a rest? You’re always having a go at each other, it’s driving me mad.

Session-561.Scene: “Hermione and me have stopped arguing,” he said, sitting down beside Harry.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hermione and me have stopped arguing,
Good,
said Hermione.
I’m not —
I’m just passing on the message, But I reckon she’s right. It’s not our fault how Seamus and Snape treat you.
I never said it —

Session-562.Scene: “Good day,” said Professor Trelawney in her usual misty, dreamy voice, and Harry broke off, feeling both annoyed and slightly ashamed of himself again. “And welcome back to Divination. I have, of course, been following your fortunes most carefully over the holidays, and am delighted to see that you have all returned to Hogwarts safely — as, of course, I knew you would.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I never remember my dreams, You say one.
You must remember one of them,
What? What d’you reckon that means?
Probably that you’re going to be eaten by a giant marshmallow or something,

D’you realize how much homework we’ve got already?  now we’ve got a month’s dream diary from Trelawney!  Fred and George weren’t wrong about O.W.L. year, were they? That Umbridge woman had better not give us any . . .
Not about the chapter, no,
I’ve got a query about your course aims,
Hermione Granger,
Well, I don’t, There’s nothing written up there about using defensive spells.
We’re not going to use magic?
Weasley,
Defense Against the Dark Arts Surely the whole point of Defense Against the Dark Arts is to practice defensive spells?
No,
No,
And what good’s theory going to be in the real world?
So we’re not supposed to be prepared for what’s waiting out there?
Oh yeah?
Hmm, let’s think . . . maybe Lord Voldemort?
Yep, but yeah, he’s returned!
It is NOT a lie! I saw him, I fought him!
Harry, no!
So, according to you, Cedric Diggory dropped dead of his own accord, did he?
It was murder,

Session-563.Scene: “Why, it’s Potty Wee Potter!” cackled Peeves, allowing two of the inkwells to fall to the ground where they smashed and spattered the walls with ink; Harry jumped backward out of the way with a snarl.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Get out of it, Peeves.
I said, leave me ALONE!
SHUT UP!

Session-564.Scene: “Why, it’s Potty Wee Potter!” cackled Peeves, allowing two of the inkwells to fall to the ground where they smashed and spattered the walls with ink; Harry jumped backward out of the way with a snarl.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I’ve been sent to see you,
Is what true? Professor?
Yes, Yes. Yes.
Yes, Yes. Yes.
Yes, Yes. Yes.
What?
What do you — ?
Every evening this week! But, Professor, couldn’t you — ?
“But —”
But I was telling the truth!
No, thanks,
No, thanks,

Session-565.Scene: “How can Dumbledore have let this happen?” Hermione cried suddenly, making Harry and Ron jump; Crookshanks leapt off her, looking affronted. She pounded the arms of her chair in fury, so that bits of stuffing leaked out of the holes. “How can he let that terrible woman teach us? And in our O.W.L. year too!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: How can Dumbledore have let this happen? And in our O.W.L. year too!
Well, we’ve never had great Defense Against the Dark Arts teachers, have we? You know what it’s like, Hagrid told us, nobody wants the job, they say it’s jinxed.
Yes, but to employ someone who’s actually refusing to let us do magic! What’s Dumbledore playing at?
And she’s trying to get people to spy for her, Remember when she said she wanted us to come and tell her if we hear anyone saying You-Know-Who’s back?
Of course she’s here to spy on us all, that’s obvious, why else would Fudge have wanted her to come?
Don’t start arguing again, Can’t we just . . . Let’s just do that homework, get it out of the way . . .
Shall we do Snape’s stuff first? ‘The properties . . . of moonstone . . . and its uses . . . in potion-making . . .’ There. So what are the properties of moonstone and its uses in potion-making?
No, I’m sorry, they’ve gone too far, Come on, Ron.
I — what? No — come on, Hermione — we can’t tell them off for giving out sweets . . .
You know perfectly well that those are bits of Nosebleed Nougat or — or Puking Pastilles or —
Fainting Fancies?
She’s got it under control,
That’s enough!
I told you this morning, you can’t test your rubbish on students!
I don’t care, it could be dangerous!
It is NOT excellent!
You can’t do this, what if you made one of them really ill?
If you don’t stop doing it, I’m going to —
No, but I will write to your mother.
Oh, yes, I would, I can’t stop you eating the stupid things yourselves, but you’re not giving them to first years. Thank you for your support, Ron,
You handled it fine by yourself,
Oh, it’s no good, I can’t concentrate now. I’m going to bed.
What in the name of Merlin are you doing?
They’re hats for house-elves, I did them over the summer. I’m a really slow knitter without magic, but now I’m back at school I should be able to make lots more.
You’re leaving out hats for the house-elves? And you’re covering them up with rubbish first?
Yes,
That’s not on, You’re trying to trick them into picking up the hats. You’re setting them free when they might not want to be free.
Of course they want to be free! Don’t you dare touch those hats, Ron!
They should at least see what they’re picking up, Anyway . . . have you?”
I’m going to bed too.

Session-566.Scene: “Everyone here?” barked Professor Grubbly-Plank, once all the Slytherins and Gryffindors had arrived. “Let’s crack on then — who can tell me what these things are called?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: They’re tree-guardians, usually live in wand-trees.
Wood lice, But fairy eggs if they can get them.
Where’s Hagrid?
Maybe you will if you don’t shut up,

Dumbledore would know if something had happened to Hagrid, It’s just playing into Malfoy’s hands to look worried, it tells him we don’t know exactly what’s going on. We’ve got to ignore him, Harry. Here, hold the bowtruckle for a moment, just so I can draw its face . . .
Oooooh! If he calls Hagrid a moron one more time . . .
Harry, don’t go picking a row with Malfoy, don’t forget, he’s a prefect now, he could make life difficult for you . . .
Wow, I wonder what it’d be like to have a difficult life? I just wish Hagrid would hurry up and get back, that’s all, And don’t say that Grubbly-Plank woman’s a better teacher!

Session-567.Scene: “I wasn’t going to,” said Hermione calmly.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I wasn’t going to,
Because she’ll never be as good as Hagrid,
Yes,
Well, they were right, weren’t they? There weren’t any such things as the Blibbering Humdinger or the Crumple-Horned Snorkack.

Session-568.Scene: “D’you mind not offending the only people who believe me?” Harry asked Hermione as they made their way into class.

Dialogue.Dialogue: D’you mind not offending the only people who believe me?
Oh, for heaven’s sake, Harry, you can do better than her, Well, I wouldn’t expect anything else from someone whose father runs The Quibbler.
Er — thanks very much, Ernie,

Session-569.Scene: “Now he remembers!” snarled Angelina. “Didn’t I tell you I wanted to do a tryout with the whole team, and find someone who fitted in with everyone? Didn’t I tell you I’d booked the Quidditch pitch specially? And now you’ve decided you’re not going to be there!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: You know what?
What d’you reckon are the odds of Umbridge letting you off on Friday?

Less than zero, Better try, though, hadn’t I? I’ll offer to do two more detentions or something, I dunno . . . I hope she doesn’t keep me too long this evening. You realize we’ve got to write three essays, practice Vanishing Spells for McGonagall, work out a countercharm for Flitwick, finish the bowtruckle drawing, and start that stupid dream diary for Trelawney?
And it looks like it’s going to rain.
What’s that got to do with our homework?
Nothing,

Session-570.Scene: “What’s that got to do with our homework?” said Hermione, her eyebrows raised.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Come in,
Evening,
Er, Professor Umbridge? Er — before we start, I-I wanted to ask you a . . . a favor.

Well I’m . . . I’m on the Gryffindor Quidditch team. And I was supposed to be at the tryouts for the new Keeper at five o’clock on Friday and I was — was wondering whether I could skip detention that night and do it — do it another night . . . instead . . .
How many times?
You haven’t given me any ink,
Nothing,

Session-571.Scene: “How come you didn’t do it last night?” Harry asked, as Ron stared wildly around the common room for inspiration. Ron, who had been fast asleep when Harry got back to the dormitory, muttered something about “doing other stuff,” bent low over his parchment, and scrawled a few words.

Dialogue.Dialogue: How come you didn’t do it last night?

“doing other stuff,” That’ll have to do, I’ve said I dreamed I was buying a new pair of shoes, she can’t make anything weird out of that, can she? How was detention with Umbridge, anyway? What did she make you do?
Lines.
That’s not too bad, then, eh?
Nope,
Hey — I forgot — did she let you off for Friday?
No,
I’m in detention! D’you think I’d rather be stuck in a room with that old toad or playing Quidditch?
At least it’s only lines, It’s not as if it’s a dreadful punishment, really . . .
I can’t believe how much homework we’ve got,
Well, why didn’t you do any last night? Where were you anyway?
I was . . . I fancied a walk,

Session-573.Scene: His homework situation, however, was now desperate, and when he returned to the Gryffindor common room he did not, though exhausted, go to bed, but opened his books and began Snape’s moonstone essay. It was half-past two by the time he had finished it. He knew he had done a poor job, but there was no help for it; unless he had something to give in he would be in detention with Snape next. He then dashed off answers to the questions Professor McGonagall had set them, cobbled together something on the proper handling of bowtruckles for Professor Grubbly-Plank, and staggered up to bed, where he fell fully clothed on top of the bed covers and fell asleep immediately.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Do I still have to come back tomorrow?
“Ron?”

Session-574.Scene: Harry opened his mouth, closed it again, and nodded. He was not really sure why he was not telling Ron and Hermione exactly what was happening in Umbridge’s room: He only knew that he did not want to see their looks of horror; that would make the whole thing seem worse and therefore more difficult to face. He also felt dimly that this was between himself and Umbridge, a private battle of wills, and he was not going to give her the satisfaction of hearing that he had complained about it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What? What are you doing?
What? Er — nothing. What are you doing?
Come on, you can tell me! What are you hiding here for?
I’m — I’m hiding from Fred and George, if you must know,
What?
Er, I-I thought I’d try out for Gryffindor Keeper now I’ve got a decent broom. There. Go on. Laugh.
I’m not laughing, It’s a brilliant idea! It’d be really cool if you got on the team! I’ve never seen you play Keeper, are you good?
I’m not bad, Charlie, Fred, and George always made me Keep for them when they were training during the holidays.
So you’ve been practicing tonight?

Every evening since Tuesday . . . just on my own,  I’ve been trying to bewitch Quaffles to fly at me, but it hasn’t been easy and I don’t know how much use it’ll be. Fred and George are going to laugh themselves stupid when I turn up for the tryouts. They haven’t stopped taking the mickey out of me since I got made a prefect.
I wish I was going to be there,
What?
It’s just a cut — it’s nothing — it’s —
I thought you said she was giving you lines? The old hag! She’s sick! Go to McGonagall, say something!
No, I’m not giving her the satisfaction of knowing she’s got to me.
Got to you? You can’t let her get away with this!
I don’t know how much power McGonagall’s got over her,
Dumbledore, then, tell Dumbledore!
No,
Why not?
He’s got enough on his mind,
Well, I reckon you should —

Session-575.Scene: “Harry, I did it, I’m in, I’m Keeper!”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry, I did it, I’m in, I’m Keeper!
What? Oh — brilliant!
Have a butterbeer. I can’t believe it — where’s Hermione gone?
Er,
Oh, Harry, it’s you. . . . Good about Ron, isn’t it? They’re disappearing like mad!
There. Listen, Hermione, I was just up in Umbridge’s office and she touched my arm . . .
You’re worried that You-Know-Who’s controlling her like he controlled Quirrell?
Ah, it’s a possibility, isn’t it?

I suppose so, He could have her under the Imperius Curse, I suppose . . . But last year your scar hurt when nobody was touching you, and didn’t Dumbledore say it had to do with what You-Know-Who was feeling at the time? I mean, maybe this hasn’t got anything to do with Umbridge at all, maybe it’s just coincidence it happened while you were with her?
She’s evil, Twisted.
Yes,
I’m not bothering him with this. Like you just said, it’s not a big deal. It’s been hurting on and off all summer — it was just a bit worse tonight, that’s all —
Harry, I’m sure Dumbledore would want to be bothered by this —
Ah, that’s the only bit of me Dumbledore cares about, isn’t it, my scar?
Don’t say that, it’s not true!
I think I’ll write and tell Sirius about it, see what he thinks —
Harry, you can’t put something like that in a letter! Don’t you remember, Moody told us to be careful what we put in writing! We just can’t guarantee owls aren’t being intercepted anymore!
All right, all right, I won’t tell him, then! I’m going to bed. Tell Ron for me, will you?
No,

Session-576.Scene: “I would not go that way if I were you,” said Nearly Headless Nick, drifting disconcertingly through a wall just ahead of him as he walked down the passage. “Peeves is planning an amusing joke on the next person to pass the bust of Paracelsus halfway down the corridor.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Does it involve Paracelsus falling on top of the person’s head?

Session-577.Scene: “That’s right, I saw him,” she said fiercely.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah . . . see you. Morning,
What are you looking so pleased about?
Erm . . . Quidditch later,
Oh . . . yeah . . . Listen . . . you don’t fancy going out a bit earlier with me, do you? Just to — er — give me some practice before training? So I can, you know, get my eye in a bit . . .
Yeah, okay,
Look, I don’t think you should,
Anything interesting?
No, just some guff about the bass player in the Weird Sisters getting married . . . Wait a moment, Oh no . . . Sirius!
What’s happened?
‘The Ministry of Magic has received a tip-off from a reliable source that Sirius Black, notorious mass murderer . . . blah blah blah . . . is currently hiding in London!’
Lucius Malfoy, I’ll bet anything, He did recognize Sirius on the platform . . .
What?
Shh!
. . . ‘Ministry warns Wizarding community that Black is very dangerous . . . killed thirteen people . . . broke out of Azkaban . . .’
Hey! Look at this!
I’ve got all the robes I want,
No, look . . . this little piece here . . .
Sturgis Podmore? but he’s that bloke who looks like his head’s been thatched, isn’t he? He’s one of the Ord —
Shh!
Six months in Azkaban! Just for trying to get through a door!
D’you reckon he was doing something for the Order?
Wait a moment . . . Sturgis was supposed to come and see us off, remember? Yeah,
Well, maybe they didn’t expect him to get caught,

It could be a frame-up! No — listen! The Ministry suspects he’s one of Dumbledore’s lot so — I dunno — they lured him to the Ministry, and he wasn’t trying to get through a door at all! Maybe they’ve just made something up to get him!

Do you know, I wouldn’t be at all surprised if that were true. Right, well, I think we should tackle that essay for Sprout on Self-Fertilizing Shrubs first, and if we’re lucky we’ll be able to start McGonagall’s Inanimatus Conjurus before lunch . . .
I mean, we can do it tonight, And we’ve got tomorrow. She gets too worked up about work, that’s her trouble . . . D’you think she meant it when she said we weren’t copying from her?
Yeah, Still, this is important too, we’ve got to practice if we want to stay on the Quidditch team . . .
Yeah, And we have got plenty of time to do it all . . .

Session-578.Scene: “All right, Ron?” said George, winking at him.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah,
Shut up,
Ignore them, We’ll see who’s laughing after we play them . . .
Sorry!
He’s just nervous, He was fine when I was practicing with him this morning.
Oh . . . sorry . . .
Oh . . . sorry . . .
What now?

Session-579.Scene: “How was practice?” asked Hermione rather coolly half an hour later, as Harry and Ron climbed through the portrait hole into the Gryffindor common room.

Dialogue.Dialogue: How was practice?
It was —
Completely lousy,
Well, it was only your first one,
Who said it was me who made it lousy?
No one,
You thought I was bound to be rubbish?
No, of course I didn’t! Look, you said it was lousy so I just —
I’m going to get started on some homework,
Was he lousy?
No, Well, I suppose he could’ve played better, but it was only the first training session, like you said . . .

Session-580.Scene: “You know, we probably should try and get more homework done during the week,” Harry muttered to Ron, as they finally laid aside Professor McGonagall’s long essay on the Inanimatus Conjurus spell and turned miserably to Professor Sinistra’s equally long and difficult essay about Jupiter’s moons.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You know, we probably should try and get more homework done during the week,
Yeah, Listen . . . shall we just ask Hermione if we can have a look at what she’s done?
No, you know she won’t let us.
Nearly done?
No,
Jupiter’s biggest moon is Ganymede, not Callisto, and it’s Io that’s got the volcanos.
Thanks,
Sorry, I only —
Yeah,
Ron —
I haven’t got time to listen to a sermon, all right, Hermione, I’m up to my neck in it here —
No — look! Isn’t that Hermes?
Blimey, it is! What’s Percy writing to me for? That’s definitely Percy’s handwriting,
Open it!
Well, if you want to — er — what is it? Oh yeah — ‘sever ties’ with me, I swear I won’t get violent.
Give it back, git. Come on, we’ve got to get this finished some time before dawn,
Oh, give them here,
What?
Give them to me, I’ll look through them and correct them,
Thanks a million, Hermione,
Okay, write that down, and then copy out this conclusion that I’ve written for you.
Hermione, you are honestly the most wonderful person I’ve ever met,
Harry
Harry  Why are you down there?
Because I’ve just seen Sirius’s head in the fire,
Sirius’s head? You mean like when he wanted to talk to you during the Triwizard Tournament? But he wouldn’t do that now, it would be too — Sirius!
You’ve been popping into the fire every hour?
But what if you’d been seen?
But Sirius, this is taking an awful risk —
You didn’t say you’d written to Sirius!
I forgot,
What about — ?
We’ll tell you afterward, go on, Sirius.
Yeah, So maybe he was just, I dunno, really angry or something the night I had that detention.
So you don’t think it had anything to do with Umbridge touching me when I was in detention with her? She’s foul enough to be one,
Does Lupin know her?
What’s she got against werewolves?
Sirius!
No, She’s not letting us use magic at all!
All we do is read the stupid textbook,
Trained in combat? What does he think we’re doing here, forming some sort of wizard army?
That’s the stupidest thing I’ve ever heard, including all the stuff that Luna Lovegood comes out with.
So we’re being prevented from learning Defense Against the Dark Arts because Fudge is scared we’ll use spells against the Ministry?
Percy  Only Ron’s brother Percy reckons there will be —
So you haven’t had any news about Hagrid, either?
But if he was supposed to be back by now . . . Yeah,
NO!
Sirius, didn’t you see the Daily Prophet?
Yeah, but we think this time they have,
I would, I just don’t want you chucked back in Azkaban!
Look —

Session-581.Scene: They had expected to have to comb Hermione’s Daily Prophet carefully next morning to find the article Percy had mentioned in his letter. However, the departing delivery owl had barely cleared the top of the milk jug when Hermione let out a huge gasp and flattened the newspaper to reveal a large photograph of Dolores Umbridge, smiling widely and blinking slowly at them from beneath the headline:

Dialogue.Dialogue: UMBRIDGE ‘High Inquisitor’? What does that mean? She’s been a WHAT?
Wait, there’s more,

So now we know how we ended up with Umbridge! Fudge passed this ‘Educational Decree’ and forced her on us! And now he’s given her the power to inspect other teachers! I can’t believe this. It’s outrageous . . .
I know it is, What?
Oh, I can’t wait to see McGonagall inspected, Umbridge won’t know what’s hit her.
Well, come on, we’d better get going, if she’s inspecting Binns’s class we don’t want to be late . . .

Session-582.Scene: “Good afternoon, Professor Trelawney,” said Professor Umbridge with her wide smile. “You received my note, I trust? Giving the time and date of your inspection?”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Think of a dream, quick, in case the old toad comes our way.
I did it last time, it’s your turn, you tell me one.
Oh, I dunno . . . Let’s say I dreamed I was . . . drowning Snape in my cauldron. Yeah, that’ll do . . .
Okay, we’ve got to add your age to the date you had the dream, the number of letters in the subject . . . would that be ‘drowning’ or ‘cauldron’ or ‘Snape’?
It doesn’t matter, pick any of them,
What night did you dream this again?
I dunno, last night, whenever you like,

Session-583.Scene: “Wands away,” she instructed them all smilingly, and those people who had been hopeful enough to take them out sadly returned them to their bags. “As we finished chapter one last lesson, I would like you all to turn to page nineteen today and commence chapter two, ‘Common Defensive Theories and Their Derivation.’ There will be no need to talk.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I’ve already read chapter two,
I’ve read that too. I’ve read the whole book.
He says that counterjinxes are improperly named, He says ‘counterjinx’ is just a name people give their jinxes when they want to make them sound more acceptable. But I disagree,
Yes, I do, Mr. Slinkhard doesn’t like jinxes, does he? But I think they can be very useful when they’re used defensively.
I — but — but . . . wait!
What for?
Don’t you get involved!
Yeah, Quirrell was a great teacher, there was just that minor drawback of him having Lord Voldemort sticking out of the back of his head.
Professor Umbridge.
Yes,
But — what? Professor, no! I’m already being punished by her, why do you have to take points as well?
She’s taken points off Gryffindor because I’m having my hand sliced open every night! How is that fair, how?
I know, mate, she’s bang out of order.
You think McGonagall was right, do you?
I wish she hadn’t taken points from you, but I think she’s right to warn you not to lose your temper with Umbridge,

Session-584.Scene: “Excellent,” whispered Ron, as they sat down in their usual seats. “Let’s see Umbridge get what she deserves.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: Excellent, Let’s see Umbridge get what she deserves.
How she can lecture me about not losing my temper with Umbridge!
Well, it’s a start,

Session-585.Scene: “You do not usually take this class, is that correct?” Harry heard her ask as they arrived at the trestle table where the group of captive bowtruckles were scrabbling around for wood lice like so many living twigs.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You do not usually take this class, is that correct?
Only because he was too stupid to listen to what Hagrid told him to do,

Session-586.Scene: Harry saw Malfoy look up eagerly.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Here, soak your hand in that, it’s a solution of strained and pickled murtlap tentacles, it should help.
Thanks,
I still reckon you should complain about this,
No,
McGonagall would go nuts if she knew —
Yeah, she probably would, And how long d’you reckon it’d take Umbridge to pass another Decree saying anyone who complains about the High Inquisitor gets sacked immediately?
She’s an awful woman,
I suggested poison,
No . . . I mean, something about what a dreadful teacher she is, and how we’re not going to learn any defense from her at all,
Well, what can we do about that? ’S too late, isn’t it?
Well, You know, I was thinking today . . . I was thinking that — maybe the time’s come when we should just — just do it ourselves.
Do what ourselves?
Well — learn Defense Against the Dark Arts ourselves,
Come off it, You want us to do extra work? D’you realize Harry and I are behind on homework again and it’s only the second week?
But this is much more important than homework!
I didn’t think there was anything in the universe more important than homework,

Don’t be silly, of course there is! It’s about preparing ourselves, like Harry said in Umbridge’s first lesson, for what’s waiting out there. It’s about making sure we really can defend ourselves. If we don’t learn anything for a whole year —
We can’t do much by ourselves, I mean, all right, we can go and look jinxes up in the library and try and practice them, I suppose —
No, I agree, we’ve gone past the stage where we can just learn things out of books, We need a teacher, a proper one, who can show us how to use the spells and correct us if we’re going wrong.
If you’re talking about Lupin . . .
No, no, I’m not talking about Lupin, He’s too busy with the Order and anyway, the most we could see him is during Hogsmeade weekends and that’s not nearly often enough.
Who, then?
Isn’t it obvious? I’m talking about you, Harry.
What?
I’m talking about you teaching us Defense Against the Dark Arts.
That’s an idea.
What’s an idea?
You, Teaching us to do it.
I — but — but . . . wait! But I’m not a teacher, I can’t —
Harry, you’re the best in the year at Defense Against the Dark Arts,
Me? No I’m not, you’ve beaten me in every test —

Actually, I haven’t, You beat me in our third year — the only year we both sat the test and had a teacher who actually knew the subject. But I’m not talking about test results, Harry. Look what you’ve done!
How d’you mean?
You know what, I’m not sure I want someone this stupid teaching me, Let’s think, Uh . . . first year — you saved the Stone from You-Know-Who.
But that was luck,
Second year, you killed the basilisk and destroyed Riddle.
Yeah, but if Fawkes hadn’t turned up I —
Third year,
You know that was a fluke, if the Time-Turner hadn’t —
Last year,

Listen to me! Just listen to me, all right? It sounds great when you say it like that, but all that stuff was luck — I didn’t know what I was doing half the time, I didn’t plan any of it, I just did whatever I could think of, and I nearly always had help — That was me, I know what went on, all right? And I didn’t get through any of that because I was brilliant at Defense Against the Dark Arts, I got through it all because — because help came at the right time, or because I guessed right — but I just blundered through it all, I didn’t have a clue what I was doing — STOP LAUGHING! That was me, You — neither of you — you’ve never had to face him, have you? You think it’s just memorizing a bunch of spells and throwing them at him, like you’re in class or something? The whole time you know there’s nothing between you and dying except your own — your own brain or guts or whatever — like you can think straight when you know you’re about a second from being murdered, or tortured, or watching your friends die — they’ve never taught us that in their classes, what it’s like to deal with things like that — and you two sit there acting like I’m a clever little boy to be standing here, alive, like Diggory was stupid, like he messed up — you just don’t get it, that could just as easily have been me, it would have been if Voldemort hadn’t needed me —
We weren’t saying anything like that, mate, We weren’t having a go at Diggory, we didn’t — you’ve got the wrong end of the —
Harry, don’t you see?   This . . . this is exactly why we need you. . . We need to know what it’s r-really like . . . facing him . . . facing V-Voldemort. “Well …
“Coming?”
“Reparo,

Session-587.Scene: “I was wondering,” Hermione said suddenly, “whether you’d thought any more about Defense Against the Dark Arts, Harry.”

Dialogue.Dialogue: I was wondering, whether you’d thought any more about Defense Against the Dark Arts, Harry.
’Course I have, Can’t forget it, can we, with that hag teaching us —
oh, all right, the idea I had, then — about you teaching us.
Well, yeah, I — I’ve thought about it a bit.
And?
I dunno,
I thought it was a good idea from the start,
You did listen to what I said about a load of it being luck, didn’t you?

Yes, Harry, but all the same, there’s no point pretending that you’re not good at Defense Against the Dark Arts, because you are. You were the only person last year who could throw off the Imperius Curse completely, you can produce a Patronus, you can do all sorts of stuff that full-grown wizards can’t, Viktor always said —
Yeah? What did Vicky say?
Ho ho, He said Harry knew how to do stuff even he didn’t, and he was in the final year at Durmstrang.
You’re not still in contact with him, are you?
So what if I am?
He didn’t only want to be your pen pal,
Well, what do you think? Will you teach us?
Just you and Ron, yeah?
Well,
Yeah, but I doubt anyone except you two would want to be taught by me. I’m a nutter, remember?

Well, I think you might be surprised how many people would be interested in hearing what you’ve got to say, Look, you know the first weekend in October’s a Hogsmeade weekend? How would it be if we tell anyone who’s interested to meet us in the village and we can talk it over?
Why do we have to do it outside school?
Because, I don’t think Umbridge would be very happy if she found out what we were up to.

Well, you can’t blame him for wanting to get out and about, I mean, he’s been on the run for over two years, hasn’t he, and I know that can’t have been a laugh, but at least he was free, wasn’t he? And now he’s just shut up all the time with that lunatic elf.

The trouble is, until V-Voldemort — oh for heaven’s sake, Ron — comes out into the open, Sirius is going to have to stay hidden, isn’t he? I mean, the stupid Ministry isn’t going to realize Sirius is innocent until they accept that Dumbledore’s been telling the truth about him all along. And once the fools start catching real Death Eaters again it’ll be obvious Sirius isn’t one . . . I mean, he hasn’t got the Mark, for one thing.
I don’t reckon he’d be stupid enough to turn up, Dumbledore’d go mad if he did and Sirius listens to Dumbledore even if he doesn’t like what he hears.

Listen, Ron and I have been sounding out people who we thought might want to learn some proper Defense Against the Dark Arts, and there are a couple who seem interested. We’ve told them to meet us in Hogsmeade.
Right,
Don’t worry, Harry, You’ve got enough on your plate without Sirius too.

Session-588.Scene: “Er — why was Filch sniffing you?” asked Ron, as he, Harry, and Hermione set off at a brisk pace down the wide drive to the gates.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Er — why was Filch sniffing you?
I suppose he was checking for the smell of Dungbombs, I forgot to tell you . . .
He said he was tipped off you were ordering Dungbombs? But who had tipped him off?
I dunno, Maybe Malfoy, he’d think it was a laugh.
Malfoy? Well . . . yes . . . maybe . . .
Where are we going anyway? The Three Broomsticks?

Oh — no, no, it’s always packed and really noisy. I’ve told the others to meet us in the Hog’s Head, that other pub, you know the one, it’s not on the main road.
